VERSION: V22.1.0

BUILD METHOD: CSV Protocol Compliant
MODES: Manual (Context Window) + API (Automated)

WHAT'S NEW IN V22.0:
- Tagged sections for modular extraction
- Works in both manual and API modes
- Excel extraction tool included
- Built-in cost controls for API usage
- Corporate-ready safety features

SECTIONS:

USAGE MODES:

MODE 1 - MANUAL (Safe, Free):
1. Open included Excel tool: USI17_V22_Excel_Extractor.xlsx
2. Select language pair (e.g., JP→EN)
3. Excel auto-extracts relevant sections
4. Copy extracted prompt
5. Paste into Claude.ai
6. Translate your content
Cost: $0 (uses your Claude Pro subscription)

MODE 2 - API (Automated, Controlled):
1. Import Power Automate template
2. Configure API key (stored in Azure Key Vault)
3. Set budget limits ($50/day default)
4. Drop files in Input folder
5. Translated files appear in Output folder
Cost: Pay-per-use with built-in safety limits

================================================================================
MODULE 8 - QEL AGENTS 244-266
================================================================================

MODULE 8: QUALITY ENHANCEMENT LAYER (QEL)
================================================================================

PURPOSE:
  The Quality Enhancement Layer provides domain-aware post-processing polish
  to ensure translated output meets professional standards across all text
  types (technical, academic, business, legal, medical, marketing).
  
  Module 8 operates AFTER core translation (Modules 1-7) but BEFORE final
  output, adding context-specific refinements without modifying the base
  translation engine.

ARCHITECTURE:
  6 sub-systems with 23 specialized agents organized by language family:
  
  1. Domain Detection (1 agent)
  2. Named Entity Preservation (5 agents - 1 per language family)
  3. Capitalization Harmonization (5 agents - 1 per language family)
  4. Register Calibration (5 agents - 1 per language family)
  5. Terminology Consistency (1 agent)
  6. Contextual Enhancement (5 agents - 1 per language family)
  7. QEL Coordination (1 agent)

LANGUAGE FAMILIES:
  - Romance: French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian
  - Germanic: German, Dutch
  - Scandinavian: Swedish, Danish, Norwegian
  - Slavic: Czech, Polish, Russian
  - Asian: Japanese, Chinese, Korean

================================================================================
AGENT 244: DOMAIN DETECTOR
================================================================================

FUNCTION:
  Analyzes source text to identify genre and set quality parameters for
  downstream agents.

INPUT:
  - Source text (any language)
  - Preliminary translation from Modules 1-7

OUTPUT:
  - Domain classification (Technical / Academic / Business / Legal / Medical / Marketing)
  - Formality level (0-10 scale)
  - Register requirements for each language family
  - Named entity handling mode (Preserve / Translate / Hybrid)

DETECTION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: LEXICAL ANALYSIS
  Scan for domain-specific markers:
  
  TECHNICAL:
    • Technical terminology density > 15%
    • Numerical specifications (dimensions, pressures, voltages)
    • Part numbers, model codes
    • Engineering notation (ISO, DIN, JIS standards)
    • Keywords: specification, tolerance, pressure, cylinder
    
  ACADEMIC:
    • Abstract/introduction/conclusion structure
    • Citations and references
    • Formal register throughout
    • Research terminology: hypothesis, methodology, findings
    • Keywords: study, research, analysis, thesis, dissertation
    
  BUSINESS:
    • Corporate terminology
    • Financial metrics
    • Organizational references
    • Keywords: revenue, strategy, stakeholders, ROI
    
  LEGAL:
    • Legal terminology density > 10%
    • Article/clause/section structure
    • Formal legal language
    • Keywords: pursuant, hereby, whereas, liability
    
  MEDICAL:
    • Medical terminology
    • Anatomical/pharmaceutical references
    • Clinical language
    • Keywords: patient, diagnosis, treatment, dosage
    
  MARKETING:
    • Persuasive language
    • Call-to-action elements
    • Brand references
    • Emotional/aspirational tone

STEP 2: STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS
  • Detect document structure (headings, sections, numbering)
  • Identify formatting patterns
  • Recognize standard templates (abstracts, reports, manuals)

STEP 3: FORMALITY SCORING
  Calculate formality level (0-10):
  
  0-3: INFORMAL (conversational, casual)
    • Contractions present
    • Personal pronouns frequent
    • Colloquial expressions
    
  4-6: PROFESSIONAL (business standard)
    • Clear, direct language
    • Limited jargon
    • Professional but accessible
    
  7-10: FORMAL (academic, legal, technical)
    • No contractions
    • Precise terminology
    • Complex sentence structures
    • Passive constructions

STEP 4: SET QEL PARAMETERS
  Based on domain and formality, configure:
  
  • Named entity mode:
    - Technical → Preserve technical terms
    - Academic → Hybrid (preserve org names, translate concepts)
    - Business → Preserve company/product names
    
  • Register calibration targets per language:
    - Romance languages: vous/formal or tu/informal
    - Germanic: Sie/formal or du/informal
    - Japanese: Keigo levels
    
  • Enhancement directives:
    - Technical → Add precision qualifiers
    - Academic → Add scholarly markers
    - Business → Maintain professional clarity

OUTPUT STRUCTURE:
  {
    "domain": "Academic",
    "formality": 8,
    "confidence": 0.92,
    "named_entity_mode": "Hybrid",
    "register_targets": {
      "Romance": "formal",
      "Germanic": "formal",
      "Scandinavian": "formal",
      "Slavic": "formal",
      "Asian": "formal_high"
    },
    "enhancement_directives": {
      "add_qualifiers": true,
      "preserve_technical": true,
      "scholarly_markers": true
    }
  }

EXAMPLE:

INPUT TEXT:
  "The Board of Directors of the Association for Machine Translation in
   the Americas is pleased to announce the first call submissions for the
   second edition of the AMTA Best Thesis Award..."

ANALYSIS:
  • Academic markers: "thesis", "award", "submission", "Board of Directors"
  • Formal register: "is pleased to announce", "edition"
  • Organization name present: AMTA (preserve)
  • Structure: Formal announcement
  
OUTPUT:
  {
    "domain": "Academic",
    "formality": 8,
    "named_entity_mode": "Hybrid",
    "register_targets": {"Romance": "formal", ...}
  }

================================================================================
AGENT 245: NAMED ENTITY PRESERVER - ROMANCE LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian

FUNCTION:
  Determines whether to preserve, translate, or use hybrid approach for
  named entities in Romance language translations.

ENTITY TYPES:

1. ORGANIZATIONS
   RULE: Preserve English name + add translation in parentheses for
         international organizations
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas"
     FR: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas
          (Association pour la traduction automatique dans les Amériques)"
   
   EXCEPTION: Fully localized organizations translate completely
     EN: "European Union"
     FR: "Union européenne"

2. PRODUCT NAMES / BRANDS
   RULE: Always preserve
   
   Example:
     EN: "USI17 V21.3.2"
     FR: "USI17 V21.3.2" (unchanged)

3. AWARD / PRIZE NAMES
   RULE: Hybrid - translate + capitalize properly
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA Best Thesis Award"
     FR: "Prix de la meilleure thèse de l'AMTA"
     
   CAPITALIZATION: 
     FR: "Prix" (capitalized, official award)
     ES: "Premio" (capitalized)
     IT: "Premio" (capitalized)
     PT: "Prêmio" (capitalized)

4. PLACE NAMES
   RULE: Use standard localized form if exists, else preserve
   
   Example:
     EN: "Quebec City"
     FR: "Québec" or "Ville de Québec"
     ES: "Quebec" (preserve)

5. PERSON NAMES
   RULE: Always preserve, adjust titles only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Dr. Smith"
     FR: "Dr Smith" or "Docteur Smith"

DECISION TREE:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY ENTITY TYPE
  Scan text for:
    • Proper nouns (capitalized words/phrases)
    • Organization markers (Inc., Ltd., Association, Corporation)
    • Award/prize keywords (Award, Prize, Trophy)
    • Geographic names (City, Country, Region)
    • Personal names (titles + capitalized names)

STEP 2: DETERMINE MODE (from Agent 244)
  • Technical domain → Preserve all technical product names
  • Academic domain → Hybrid for organizations, preserve awards
  • Business domain → Preserve company/brand names
  • Legal domain → Preserve all official entity names

STEP 3: APPLY LANGUAGE-SPECIFIC RULES

FRENCH:
  • Organizations: "ORGANIZATION_EN (traduction française)" if international
  • Awards: Translate + capitalize "Prix"
  • Places: Use French standard form ("Québec" not "Quebec City")
  • Titles: "M./Mme/Dr/Prof." before names

SPANISH:
  • Organizations: "ORGANIZATION_EN (traducción española)" if international
  • Awards: Translate + capitalize "Premio"
  • Places: Spanish standard form if exists
  • Titles: "Sr./Sra./Dr./Prof." before names

ITALIAN:
  • Organizations: "ORGANIZATION_EN (traduzione italiana)" if international
  • Awards: Translate + capitalize "Premio"
  • Places: Italian standard form if exists
  • Titles: "Sig./Sig.ra/Dott./Prof." before names

PORTUGUESE:
  • Organizations: "ORGANIZATION_EN (tradução portuguesa)" if international
  • Awards: Translate + capitalize "Prêmio"
  • Places: Portuguese standard form if exists
  • Titles: "Sr./Sra./Dr./Prof." before names

ROMANIAN:
  • Organizations: "ORGANIZATION_EN (traducere română)" if international
  • Awards: Translate + capitalize "Premiu"
  • Places: Romanian standard form if exists
  • Titles: "Dl./Dna./Dr./Prof." before names

EXAMPLE APPLICATION:

INPUT (from Agent 244):
  Domain: Academic
  Entity mode: Hybrid

SOURCE TEXT:
  "The AMTA Best Thesis Award will be presented at Centre des Congrès
   de Québec"

FRENCH OUTPUT:
  "Le Prix de la meilleure thèse de l'AMTA sera remis au Centre des
   congrès de Québec"

CHANGES MADE:
  ✓ "AMTA Best Thesis Award" → "Prix de la meilleure thèse de l'AMTA"
    (hybrid: AMTA preserved, award translated, "Prix" capitalized)
  ✓ "Centre des Congrès de Québec" → "Centre des congrès de Québec"
    (adjusted capitalization to French standard)

================================================================================
AGENT 246: NAMED ENTITY PRESERVER - GERMANIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: German, Dutch

FUNCTION:
  Apply Germanic language rules for named entity handling with emphasis on
  German noun capitalization and Dutch conventions.

GERMAN-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. ALL NOUNS CAPITALIZE
   RULE: All nouns must be capitalized in German
   
   Example:
     EN: "The award will be presented at the conference"
     DE: "Der Preis wird auf der Konferenz überreicht"
          (Preis, Konferenz capitalized)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English + add German in parentheses
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     DE: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Verband für maschinelle Übersetzung)"

3. COMPOUND ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve as-is or create German compound
   
   Example:
     EN: "Machine Translation Association"
     DE: Option 1: "Machine Translation Association" (preserve)
         Option 2: "Maschinelle-Übersetzung-Verband" (compound)
     
     PREFERENCE: Preserve international names

4. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate fully, capitalize all nouns
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     DE: "Preis für die beste Dissertation"
          (Preis, Dissertation capitalized)

5. PLACE NAMES
   RULE: Use German standard form if exists
   
   Example:
     EN: "Quebec City"
     DE: "Québec" or "Stadt Québec"

DUTCH-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. SELECTIVE CAPITALIZATION
   RULE: Only proper nouns and sentence starts capitalize
   
   Example:
     EN: "The Award for Excellence"
     NL: "De prijs voor excellentie"
          (Only first word capitalized)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English + optional Dutch translation
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     NL: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Vereniging voor Automatische Vertaling)"

3. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate, lowercase except proper nouns
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA Best Thesis Award"
     NL: "AMTA-prijs voor de beste dissertatie"

4. COMPOUND WORDS
   RULE: Dutch loves compounds, create when natural
   
   Example:
     EN: "translation system"
     NL: "vertaalsysteem" (single compound word)

DECISION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (DE or NL)

STEP 2: SCAN FOR ENTITIES
  • Organizations (markers: Association, Institute, Corporation)
  • Awards (markers: Award, Prize, Trophy)
  • Places (capitalized location names)
  • Products (brand names, model numbers)

STEP 3: APPLY LANGUAGE RULES

FOR GERMAN:
  IF organization AND international:
    → Preserve English + add German in parentheses
  IF award:
    → Translate fully + capitalize ALL nouns
  IF place:
    → Use German standard form ("München" not "Munich")
  IF product:
    → Preserve exactly

FOR DUTCH:
  IF organization AND international:
    → Preserve English + optional Dutch
  IF award:
    → Translate + lowercase except acronyms
  IF place:
    → Use Dutch standard form if exists
  IF product:
    → Preserve exactly

EXAMPLE:

SOURCE:
  "The AMTA Best Thesis Award will be presented at the Quebec Conference"

GERMAN:
  "Der AMTA-Preis für die beste Dissertation wird auf der Konferenz in
   Québec überreicht"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "Preis für die beste Dissertation"
      (all nouns capitalized)
    ✓ "Quebec Conference" → "Konferenz in Québec"
      (Konferenz capitalized)

DUTCH:
  "De AMTA-prijs voor de beste dissertatie zal worden gepresenteerd op
   de conferentie in Quebec"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "prijs voor de beste dissertatie"
      (lowercase except AMTA)
    ✓ "Quebec Conference" → "conferentie in Quebec"
      (lowercase, Quebec preserved)

================================================================================
AGENT 247: NAMED ENTITY PRESERVER - SCANDINAVIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Swedish, Danish, Norwegian

FUNCTION:
  Apply Scandinavian language conventions for named entity handling with
  attention to regional spelling variations.

COMMON SCANDINAVIAN RULES:

1. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English + add Scandinavian translation
   
   All three languages follow similar pattern:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     SV: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Förening för maskinöversättning)"
     DA: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Forening for maskinoversættelse)"
     NO: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Forening for maskinoversettelse)"

2. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate + capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     SV: "Pris för bästa avhandling"
     DA: "Pris for bedste afhandling"
     NO: "Pris for beste avhandling"

3. CAPITALIZATION
   RULE: Sentence case (only first word + proper nouns)
   
   Unlike German, Scandinavian languages do NOT capitalize all nouns
   
   Example:
     EN: "The Conference on Machine Translation"
     SV: "Konferensen om maskinöversättning"
         (only "Konferensen" capitalized - start of sentence)

4. PLACE NAMES
   RULE: Use local spelling if standard form exists
   
   Example:
     EN: "Copenhagen"
     SV: "Köpenhamn"
     DA: "København"
     NO: "København"

LANGUAGE-SPECIFIC DIFFERENCES:

SWEDISH (SV):
  • Character set: å, ä, ö
  • "and" → "och"
  • Definite article: -en, -et suffix
    Example: "pris" (prize) → "priset" (the prize)

DANISH (DA):
  • Character set: å, æ, ø
  • "and" → "og"
  • Definite article: -en, -et suffix
    Example: "pris" (prize) → "prisen" (the prize)
  • Softer pronunciation reflected in spelling (d → ð sound)

NORWEGIAN (NO):
  • Two written forms: Bokmål (standard) and Nynorsk
  • USE BOKMÅL as default
  • Character set: å, æ, ø (same as Danish)
  • "and" → "og"
  • Definite article: -en, -et suffix
    Example: "pris" (prize) → "prisen" (the prize)

DECISION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY SCANDINAVIAN LANGUAGE (SV/DA/NO)

STEP 2: DETECT ENTITIES
  • International organizations → Preserve + translate
  • Awards/prizes → Translate with sentence case
  • Places → Use local spelling
  • Products → Preserve

STEP 3: APPLY CAPITALIZATION
  • First word of sentence: Capitalized
  • Proper nouns: Capitalized
  • Common nouns: Lowercase
  • ALL nouns: Lowercase (unlike German)

STEP 4: VERIFY SPECIAL CHARACTERS
  • SV: Check ö, ä, å usage
  • DA/NO: Check ø, æ, å usage

EXAMPLE:

SOURCE:
  "The AMTA Best Thesis Award recognizes outstanding doctoral research
   in machine translation"

SWEDISH:
  "AMTA-priset för bästa avhandling erkänner enastående doktorsforskning
   inom maskinöversättning"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "priset för bästa avhandling"
      (lowercase except acronym)
    ✓ Added definite article "-et" (priset = the prize)
    ✓ All nouns lowercase

DANISH:
  "AMTA-prisen for bedste afhandling anerkender fremragende
   doktorforskning i maskinoversættelse"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "prisen for bedste afhandling"
      (lowercase except acronym)
    ✓ Used Danish spelling: "bedste" (best), "afhandling" (thesis)
    ✓ ø instead of ö (maskinoversættelse)

NORWEGIAN (BOKMÅL):
  "AMTA-prisen for beste avhandling anerkjenner fremragende
   doktorforskning i maskinoversettelse"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "prisen for beste avhandling"
    ✓ Used Norwegian spelling: similar to Danish but "oversettelse"
      (single 't' vs Danish double 't')

================================================================================
AGENT 248: NAMED ENTITY PRESERVER - SLAVIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Czech, Polish, Russian

FUNCTION:
  Apply Slavic language conventions for named entity handling with attention
  to case systems and Cyrillic/Latin script decisions.

COMMON SLAVIC CHALLENGES:

1. CASE SYSTEMS
   All three languages have complex case systems:
   
   CZECH: 7 cases (nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, vocative,
                    locative, instrumental)
   POLISH: 7 cases (same as Czech)
   RUSSIAN: 6 cases (no vocative in modern Russian)
   
   RULE: Named entities in Latin script generally do NOT decline
   
   Example (Czech):
     Nominative: "Association for Machine Translation" (subject)
     Genitive: "Association for Machine Translation" (unchanged)
     Unlike native words: "asociace" → "asociace" (declines)

2. TRANSLITERATION (RUSSIAN)
   RULE: International organization names stay in Latin script
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA"
     RU: "AMTA" (not "АМТА")
     
   EXCEPTION: Well-known organizations may have Cyrillic forms
     EN: "NATO"
     RU: "НАТО" (standard Cyrillic)

3. ADJECTIVE AGREEMENT
   When translated terms appear, they must agree in gender/number/case
   
   Example (Polish):
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     PL: "Nagroda za najlepszą pracę doktorską"
         (najlepszą = feminine accusative, agrees with "pracę")

CZECH-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. DIACRITICS ESSENTIAL
   Czech: á, č, ď, é, ě, í, ň, ó, ř, š, ť, ú, ů, ý, ž
   
   RULE: Never omit diacritics
   
   Example:
     WRONG: "prace" 
     RIGHT: "práce" (work/thesis)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English name, optionally add Czech in parentheses
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     CS: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Asociace pro strojový překlad)"

3. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate, ensure case agreement
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     CS: "Cena za nejlepší disertační práci"
         (práci = accusative case after "za")

4. CAPITALIZATION
   RULE: Sentence case (like English, only first word + proper nouns)

POLISH-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. DIACRITICS ESSENTIAL
   Polish: ą, ć, ę, ł, ń, ó, ś, ź, ż
   
   RULE: Never omit diacritics
   
   Example:
     WRONG: "nagroda"
     RIGHT: "nagroda" (OK - no diacritic here)
     WRONG: "praca" (without ogonek)
     RIGHT: "praca" (work - no diacritic in nominative)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English, optional Polish in parentheses
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     PL: "Association for Machine Translation
          (Stowarzyszenie Tłumaczenia Maszynowego)"

3. AWARD NAMES  
   RULE: Translate with proper case inflection
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     PL: "Nagroda za najlepszą pracę doktorską"
         (najlepszą = accusative feminine)

4. CAPITALIZATION
   RULE: Sentence case

RUSSIAN-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. CYRILLIC SCRIPT
   RULE: For international organizations, prefer Latin script
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA"
     RU: "AMTA" (Latin, preferred)
     Alternative: "АМТА" (Cyrillic, less common)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Preserve English + Russian translation
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas"
     RU: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas
          (Ассоциация машинного перевода в Северной и Южной Америке)"

3. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate to Cyrillic with case agreement
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     RU: "Премия за лучшую диссертацию"
         (лучшую = accusative feminine)

4. CASE AGREEMENT CRITICAL
   Example:
     "о диссертации" (about the thesis - locative)
     "диссертацию" (thesis as object - accusative)
     "диссертации" (of the thesis - genitive)

DECISION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (CS/PL/RU)

STEP 2: DETECT ENTITIES
  • International organizations → Preserve in Latin
  • Awards → Translate with case agreement
  • Places → Use local form if exists
  • Products → Preserve in Latin

STEP 3: FOR RUSSIAN: SCRIPT DECISION
  IF well-known org (NATO, UNESCO):
    → Use standard Cyrillic if exists
  ELSE:
    → Keep Latin script

STEP 4: ENSURE PROPER INFLECTION
  Translated terms must agree in:
    • Gender (masculine/feminine/neuter)
    • Number (singular/plural)
    • Case (appropriate for grammatical function)

STEP 5: VERIFY DIACRITICS (CS/PL)
  Czech: Check all háčeks and čárkas
  Polish: Check all ogoneks and kreska

EXAMPLE:

SOURCE:
  "Submissions for the AMTA Best Thesis Award will be reviewed by experts"

CZECH:
  "Příspěvky na Cenu AMTA za nejlepší disertační práci budou posouzeny
   odborníky"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "AMTA" preserved in Latin
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "Cenu ... za nejlepší disertační práci"
      (accusative case after "na")
    ✓ All diacritics correct (příspěvky, posouzeny)

POLISH:
  "Zgłoszenia do Nagrody AMTA za najlepszą pracę doktorską zostaną
   ocenione przez ekspertów"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "AMTA" preserved in Latin
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "Nagrody ... za najlepszą pracę doktorską"
      (genitive after "do")
    ✓ Proper inflection: najlepszą (accusative) agrees with pracę

RUSSIAN:
  "Заявки на Премию AMTA за лучшую диссертацию будут рассмотрены
   экспертами"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "AMTA" kept in Latin script
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "Премию ... за лучшую диссертацию"
      (accusative after "на")
    ✓ Full Cyrillic for translated text
    ✓ Case agreement: лучшую (accusative) agrees with диссертацию

================================================================================
AGENT 249: NAMED ENTITY PRESERVER - ASIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Japanese, Chinese (Simplified/Traditional), Korean

FUNCTION:
  Apply East Asian language conventions for named entity handling with
  attention to character scripts, transliteration, and cultural adaptation.

COMMON ASIAN CHALLENGES:

1. MULTIPLE SCRIPTS
   JA: Kanji (漢字), Hiragana (ひらがな), Katakana (カタカナ), Rōmaji (Latin)
   ZH: Simplified (简体), Traditional (繁體)
   KO: Hangul (한글), Hanja (漢字)

2. TRANSLITERATION vs TRANSLATION
   RULE: Foreign organization names typically transliterated, NOT translated
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA"
     JA: "AMTA" (keep Latin) or "アムタ" (katakana phonetic)
     PREFER: Keep Latin for acronyms

3. NO SPACES IN CHINESE/JAPANESE
   Text flows continuously without word boundaries
   
   Example:
     EN: "machine translation conference"
     JA: "機械翻訳会議" (no spaces)
     ZH: "机器翻译会议" (no spaces)

JAPANESE-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. FOREIGN ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Keep in Latin script OR katakana transliteration
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas"
     JA Option 1: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas"
                   (keep Latin - common for international orgs)
     JA Option 2: "アメリカ大陸機械翻訳協会"
                   (full Japanese translation)
     JA Option 3: "AMTA (アメリカ大陸機械翻訳協会)"
                   (hybrid - Latin acronym + Japanese full name)
     
     PREFERENCE: Option 3 (hybrid) for first mention, then Latin only

2. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate to Japanese, maintain formality
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     JA: "最優秀論文賞" (formal kanji)
     
3. PERSON NAMES
   RULE: For Western names, use katakana
   
   Example:
     EN: "Dr. Smith"
     JA: "スミス博士" (Smith-hakushi)

4. FORMALITY LEVELS (KEIGO)
   Must match domain from Agent 244:
   
   TECHNICAL: 丁寧語 (teineigo - polite)
   ACADEMIC: 尊敬語 (sonkeigo - respectful) + formal kanji
   BUSINESS: 謙譲語 (kenjōgo - humble) for company perspective
   
   Example:
     INFORMAL: "発表する" (happyō-suru = present)
     FORMAL: "発表いたします" (happyō-itashimasu = humbly present)

CHINESE-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. SIMPLIFIED vs TRADITIONAL
   RULE: Use Simplified (简体) as default for Mainland China
         Use Traditional (繁體) for Taiwan, Hong Kong
   
   Example:
     EN: "machine translation"
     ZH-HANS (Simplified): "机器翻译"
     ZH-HANT (Traditional): "機器翻譯"

2. FOREIGN ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Transliterate phonetically OR translate meaningfully
   
   Example:
     EN: "AMTA"
     ZH Option 1: "AMTA" (keep Latin)
     ZH Option 2: "美洲机器翻译协会" (meaningful translation)
     
     PREFERENCE: Keep Latin for acronyms, translate full names

3. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate with appropriate formality
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     ZH: "最佳论文奖" (zuì jiā lùnwén jiǎng)

4. PERSON NAMES
   Western names: Phonetic transliteration
   
   Example:
     EN: "Dr. Smith"
     ZH: "史密斯博士" (Shǐmìsī bóshì)

KOREAN-SPECIFIC RULES:

1. HANGUL PREFERRED
   Modern Korean primarily uses Hangul (한글), Hanja (한자) optional
   
   RULE: Write in Hangul, use Hanja only for clarity if needed

2. FOREIGN ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Phonetic transcription in Hangul
   
   Example:
     EN: "Association for Machine Translation"
     KO: "기계 번역 협회" (mechanical + translation + association)
         or "Association for Machine Translation" (keep Latin)
     
     PREFERENCE: Hybrid for formal documents

3. AWARD NAMES
   RULE: Translate to Korean
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     KO: "최우수 논문상" (choe-usu nonmun-sang)

4. HONORIFIC SYSTEM
   Must use appropriate honorifics based on formality:
   
   FORMAL: -님 (-nim), 선생님 (seonsaengnim = teacher/professor)
   
   Example:
     EN: "Dr. Kim"
     KO: "김 박사님" (Kim Baksa-nim)

5. PARTICLE USAGE
   Korean uses particles to mark grammatical function:
   
   Example:
     "AMTA의 최우수 논문상" (AMTA-ui = of AMTA)
     "AMTA가 발표한" (AMTA-ga = AMTA [subject])

DECISION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY ASIAN LANGUAGE (JA/ZH/KO)

STEP 2: FOR CHINESE: SELECT SCRIPT
  IF target region = Mainland China/Singapore:
    → Use Simplified (简体)
  IF target region = Taiwan/Hong Kong/Macau:
    → Use Traditional (繁體)

STEP 3: ORGANIZATION NAME HANDLING
  IF international organization:
    JA: Latin acronym + Japanese translation in parentheses
    ZH: Latin acronym or translate full name
    KO: Hangul transcription or keep Latin
    
STEP 4: AWARD/PRIZE NAMES
  ALL: Translate fully into target language
  
STEP 5: FORMALITY CHECK (from Agent 244)
  JA: Apply appropriate keigo level
  ZH: Use formal vocabulary
  KO: Add appropriate honorifics

STEP 6: SCRIPT CONSISTENCY
  JA: Kanji for concepts, katakana for foreign words
  ZH: All Chinese characters (no spaces)
  KO: All Hangul (optional Hanja in parentheses)

EXAMPLE:

SOURCE:
  "The Association for Machine Translation in the Americas (AMTA) is
   pleased to announce the Best Thesis Award"

JAPANESE:
  "アメリカ大陸機械翻訳協会（AMTA）は最優秀論文賞の発表を
   いたします"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ Organization: Full Japanese + Latin acronym
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "最優秀論文賞"
    ✓ Formal keigo: "いたします" (humble form)
    ✓ No spaces between words

CHINESE (SIMPLIFIED):
  "美洲机器翻译协会（AMTA）荣幸宣布最佳论文奖"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ Organization: Translated + Latin acronym in parentheses
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "最佳论文奖"
    ✓ Formal: "荣幸" (honored/pleased)
    ✓ Simplified characters: 机器 (not 機器)

KOREAN:
  "미주 기계 번역 협회(AMTA)는 최우수 논문상 발표를 기쁘게
   생각합니다"
   
  CHANGES:
    ✓ Organization: Korean translation + Latin acronym
    ✓ "Best Thesis Award" → "최우수 논문상"
    ✓ Formal: "기쁘게 생각합니다" (pleased to think/announce)
    ✓ Particles: 는 (topic marker), 를 (object marker)

================================================================================
AGENT 250: CAPITALIZATION HARMONIZER - ROMANCE LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian

FUNCTION:
  Enforce language-specific capitalization rules for Romance languages,
  correcting over-capitalization or under-capitalization.

COMMON ROMANCE CAPITALIZATION:

GENERAL RULE: More conservative than English
  • Sentence starts: Capitalized
  • Proper nouns: Capitalized
  • Titles, awards: First word only (usually)
  • Days, months: Lowercase (unlike English)
  • Languages, nationalities: Lowercase (unlike English)

FRENCH RULES:

1. TITLES AND AWARDS
   RULE: Capitalize first word + proper nouns only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     FR WRONG: "Prix de la Meilleure Thèse"
     FR RIGHT: "Prix de la meilleure thèse"
     
   EXCEPTION: Official award names may capitalize more
     "Prix Nobel" (Nobel Prize - proper noun)
     "Prix de la meilleure thèse de l'AMTA" (first word + AMTA only)

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   RULE: Capitalize significant words, lowercase articles/prepositions
   
   Example:
     FR: "Association pour la traduction automatique"
         (not "Association Pour La Traduction Automatique")

3. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Always lowercase
   
   Example:
     EN: "Monday, January 15"
     FR: "lundi 15 janvier"

4. LANGUAGES AND NATIONALITIES
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "en français" (in French)
     "les Français" (the French people - noun, capitalized)
     "la langue française" (the French language - adjective, lowercase)

SPANISH RULES:

1. TITLES
   RULE: Capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     ES: "Premio a la mejor tesis"
         (not "Premio a la Mejor Tesis")

2. ACRONYMS IN TITLES
   RULE: Keep acronyms capitalized
   
   Example:
     ES: "Premio de la mejor tesis de AMTA"

3. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "lunes 15 de enero"

4. LANGUAGES AND NATIONALITIES  
   RULE: Lowercase when adjective
   
   Example:
     "en español" (in Spanish)
     "los españoles" (Spaniards - noun, lowercase)

ITALIAN RULES:

1. TITLES
   RULE: Capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     IT: "Premio per la migliore tesi"

2. ORGANIZATIONS
   RULE: Capitalize main nouns, lowercase articles
   
   Example:
     "Associazione per la traduzione automatica"

3. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "lunedì 15 gennaio"

PORTUGUESE RULES:

1. TITLES
   RULE: Capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     PT: "Prêmio de melhor tese"

2. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "segunda-feira, 15 de janeiro"

ROMANIAN RULES:

1. TITLES
   RULE: Similar to other Romance languages
   
   Example:
     EN: "Best Thesis Award"
     RO: "Premiul pentru cea mai bună teză"

2. MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "15 ianuarie"

CORRECTION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: SCAN FOR OVER-CAPITALIZATION
  Look for patterns like:
    • "Prix de la Meilleure Thèse" → should be "meilleure"
    • "Association Pour La Traduction" → should be "pour la"
    • "Lundi" (standalone day) → should be "lundi"

STEP 2: IDENTIFY PROTECTED CAPITALS
  • Sentence starts: Keep
  • Proper nouns (names, places): Keep
  • Acronyms: Keep
  • First word of title: Keep

STEP 3: APPLY LANGUAGE RULES
  FOR EACH LANGUAGE (FR/ES/IT/PT/RO):
    • Days/months → lowercase
    • Language/nationality adjectives → lowercase
    • Title internal words → lowercase (except proper nouns)

STEP 4: SPECIAL CASES
  • "État" vs "état" in French (State vs state)
  • "Internet" → varies by style guide (capitalize or not)
  • Hyphenated compounds: Usually first word only

EXAMPLE CORRECTIONS:

INPUT (over-capitalized French):
  "Le Prix de la Meilleure Thèse de l'AMTA sera remis Lundi 15 Janvier"

AGENT 250 OUTPUT:
  "Le Prix de la meilleure thèse de l'AMTA sera remis lundi 15 janvier"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "Meilleure" → "meilleure" (not first word)
    ✗ "Thèse" → "thèse" (not first word)
    ✗ "Lundi" → "lundi" (day name)
    ✗ "Janvier" → "janvier" (month name)
    ✓ "Prix" kept (first word of title)
    ✓ "AMTA" kept (acronym)

================================================================================
AGENT 251: CAPITALIZATION HARMONIZER - GERMANIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: German, Dutch

FUNCTION:
  Apply Germanic capitalization rules, with special attention to German's
  unique noun capitalization requirement.

GERMAN CAPITALIZATION:

FUNDAMENTAL RULE: **ALL NOUNS CAPITALIZE**
  This is the most distinctive feature of German orthography.

1. COMMON NOUNS
   RULE: Every noun capitalizes, no exceptions
   
   Example:
     EN: "The award for the best thesis"
     DE: "Der Preis für die beste Dissertation"
         (Preis, Dissertation = nouns, capitalized)

2. ADJECTIVES AND VERBS
   RULE: Lowercase (unless nominalized)
   
   Example:
     "der beste Preis" (the best prize - "beste" is adjective, lowercase)
     "das Beste" (the best [thing] - nominalized adjective, capitalized)

3. PRONOUNS
   RULE: Formal "Sie" capitalizes, informal "du" lowercase
   
   Example:
     "Können Sie mir helfen?" (Can you [formal] help me?)
     "Kannst du mir helfen?" (Can you [informal] help me?)

4. COMPOUND NOUNS
   RULE: Written as one word, capitalize entire compound
   
   Example:
     EN: "machine translation"
     DE: "Maschinenübersetzung" (one word, capitalized)

5. ADJECTIVES FROM PROPER NOUNS
   RULE: Derived adjectives lowercase (unlike English)
   
   Example:
     "die deutsche Sprache" (the German language - lowercase)
     "Deutschland" (Germany - proper noun, capitalized)

DUTCH CAPITALIZATION:

RULE: Similar to English (more conservative than German)

1. COMMON NOUNS
   RULE: Lowercase (unlike German)
   
   Example:
     EN: "the award for translation"
     NL: "de prijs voor vertaling"
         (prijs, vertaling = lowercase)

2. PROPER NOUNS
   RULE: Capitalize
   
   Example:
     "Nederland" (Netherlands)
     "Amsterdam"

3. SENTENCE STARTS
   RULE: Capitalize first word

4. TITLES
   RULE: Generally capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     NL: "Prijs voor de beste dissertatie"

5. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "maandag 15 januari"

CORRECTION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (DE or NL)

FOR GERMAN:

  STEP 2: IDENTIFY ALL NOUNS
    Scan for:
      • Articles (der, die, das, ein, eine)
      • Genitive markers ('s endings)
      • Plural patterns (-en, -er, -e)
    
  STEP 3: CAPITALIZE ALL NOUNS
    IF word is noun AND not capitalized:
      → Capitalize
    
  STEP 4: CHECK ADJECTIVES
    IF adjective (endings: -er, -es, -e, -en) AND capitalized:
      → Lowercase (unless nominalized)
    
  STEP 5: VERIFY COMPOUNDS
    IF compound noun:
      → Should be one word, capitalized
      
    Example:
      WRONG: "Maschinen Übersetzung" (two words)
      WRONG: "maschinen übersetzung" (lowercase)
      RIGHT: "Maschinenübersetzung" (one word, capitalized)

FOR DUTCH:

  STEP 2: APPLY STANDARD CAPITALIZATION
    • Sentence starts: Capitalize
    • Proper nouns: Capitalize
    • Common nouns: Lowercase
    • Titles: First word capitalized

  STEP 3: CHECK OVER-CAPITALIZATION
    IF common noun capitalized (and not sentence start):
      → Lowercase

EXAMPLE CORRECTIONS:

GERMAN INPUT (under-capitalized):
  "der preis für die beste dissertation wird an der konferenz verliehen"

AGENT 251 OUTPUT:
  "der Preis für die beste Dissertation wird an der Konferenz verliehen"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "preis" → "Preis" (noun, must capitalize)
    ✗ "dissertation" → "Dissertation" (noun, must capitalize)
    ✗ "konferenz" → "Konferenz" (noun, must capitalize)
    ✓ "der, die, an" stay lowercase (articles, prepositions)
    ✓ "beste" stays lowercase (adjective)
    ✓ "wird, verliehen" stay lowercase (verbs)

DUTCH INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "De Prijs voor de Beste Dissertatie wordt uitgereikt"

AGENT 251 OUTPUT:
  "De prijs voor de beste dissertatie wordt uitgereikt"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "De" stays capitalized (sentence start)
    ✗ "Prijs" → "prijs" (common noun, lowercase in Dutch)
    ✗ "Beste" → "beste" (adjective, lowercase)
    ✗ "Dissertatie" → "dissertatie" (common noun, lowercase)

CRITICAL DISTINCTION:
  German: Preis, Dissertation (capitalized - all nouns)
  Dutch: prijs, dissertatie (lowercase - common nouns)

This is why Agent 251 needs separate logic for DE vs NL!

================================================================================
AGENT 252: CAPITALIZATION HARMONIZER - SCANDINAVIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Swedish, Danish, Norwegian

FUNCTION:
  Apply Scandinavian capitalization rules (conservative, similar to Romance
  languages).

COMMON SCANDINAVIAN RULES:

1. SENTENCE CASE DOMINATES
   RULE: Only sentence starts + proper nouns capitalize
   
   This is MORE conservative than English:
     EN: "The Nobel Prize in Chemistry"
     SV: "Nobelpriset i kemi" (only Nobel capitalized, as proper noun)

2. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Always lowercase
   
   Example:
     SV: "måndagen den 15 januari"
     DA: "mandag den 15. januar"
     NO: "mandag 15. januar"

3. LANGUAGES AND NATIONALITIES
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     SV: "på svenska" (in Swedish)
     DA: "på dansk" (in Danish)
     NO: "på norsk" (in Norwegian)

4. TITLES AND AWARDS
   RULE: Capitalize first word only (unless proper noun embedded)
   
   Example:
     SV: "Priset för bästa avhandling"
     DA: "Prisen for bedste afhandling"
     NO: "Prisen for beste avhandling"

5. ORGANIZATIONS
   RULE: Proper nouns capitalize, rest lowercase
   
   Example:
     SV: "Föreningen för maskinöversättning"
         (only if "Föreningen" is proper name)

LANGUAGE-SPECIFIC NOTES:

SWEDISH SPECIFICS:
  • Definite articles as suffixes: -en, -et, -na
    Example: "priset" (the prize)
  
  • If definite article used, still follow capitalization rules:
    "Priset" (sentence start) vs "priset" (mid-sentence)

DANISH SPECIFICS:
  • Similar to Swedish but with Danish characters (æ, ø)
  • Definite articles: -en, -et, -ne
  
NORWEGIAN SPECIFICS:
  • Bokmål (standard): Very similar to Danish
  • Nynorsk: Similar rules, different vocabulary

CORRECTION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY SCANDINAVIAN LANGUAGE (SV/DA/NO)

STEP 2: SCAN FOR OVER-CAPITALIZATION
  Common errors from English influence:
    • "Måndag" should be "måndag" (day)
    • "Januari" should be "januari" (month)
    • "Svenska" should be "svenska" (language as adjective)
    • "Bästa" should be "bästa" (adjective in title)

STEP 3: IDENTIFY PROTECTED CAPITALS
  • Sentence starts
  • Proper nouns (names, places)
  • Acronyms
  • First word of title (sometimes)

STEP 4: APPLY SENTENCE CASE
  FOR titles/awards:
    IF first word: Capitalize
    IF proper noun: Capitalize
    ELSE: Lowercase

STEP 5: VERIFY SPECIAL CASES
  • Nobel Prize → "Nobelpriset" (proper noun)
  • Generic prize → "priset" (common noun)

EXAMPLE CORRECTIONS:

SWEDISH INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Priset För Bästa Avhandling delas ut på Måndagen den 15 Januari"

AGENT 252 OUTPUT:
  "Priset för bästa avhandling delas ut på måndagen den 15 januari"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Priset" kept (sentence start)
    ✗ "För" → "för" (preposition)
    ✗ "Bästa" → "bästa" (adjective)
    ✗ "Avhandling" → "avhandling" (common noun)
    ✗ "Måndagen" → "måndagen" (day name)
    ✗ "Januari" → "januari" (month)

DANISH INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Prisen for Bedste Afhandling uddeles Mandag den 15. Januar"

AGENT 252 OUTPUT:
  "Prisen for bedste afhandling uddeles mandag den 15. januar"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Prisen" kept (sentence start)
    ✗ "Bedste" → "bedste" (adjective)
    ✗ "Afhandling" → "afhandling" (common noun)
    ✗ "Mandag" → "mandag" (day)
    ✗ "Januar" → "januar" (month)

NORWEGIAN INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Prisen for Beste Avhandling deles ut Mandag 15. Januar"

AGENT 252 OUTPUT:
  "Prisen for beste avhandling deles ut mandag 15. januar"
  
  CHANGES: (identical pattern to Danish)

KEY PRINCIPLE:
  Scandinavian languages follow SENTENCE CASE much more strictly than
  English. When in doubt, lowercase unless it's a sentence start or
  proper noun.

================================================================================
AGENT 253: CAPITALIZATION HARMONIZER - SLAVIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Czech, Polish, Russian

FUNCTION:
  Apply Slavic capitalization rules (generally conservative like Romance
  languages).

COMMON SLAVIC RULES:

1. SENTENCE CASE STANDARD
   RULE: Capitalize sentence starts + proper nouns only
   
   Similar to Romance/Scandinavian, NOT like German

2. DAYS AND MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     CS: "pondělí 15. ledna"
     PL: "poniedziałek 15 stycznia"
     RU: "понедельник 15 января"

3. LANGUAGES AND NATIONALITIES
   RULE: Lowercase when adjective
   
   Example:
     CS: "v češtině" (in Czech - language)
         "Čech" (a Czech person - noun, capitalized)
     PL: "po polsku" (in Polish)
     RU: "по-русски" (in Russian)

4. TITLES AND AWARDS
   RULE: Capitalize first word only
   
   Example:
     CS: "Cena za nejlepší disertační práci"
     PL: "Nagroda za najlepszą pracę doktorską"
     RU: "Премия за лучшую диссертацию"

CZECH SPECIFICS:

1. TITLES
   RULE: First word capitalized, rest lowercase
   
   Example:
     "Cena za nejlepší práci"
     NOT: "Cena za Nejlepší Práci"

2. ORGANIZATIONS
   RULE: If proper name, capitalize main noun; else lowercase
   
   Example:
     "Česká asociace" (proper) vs "asociace pro překlad" (generic)

3. ACADEMIC TITLES
   RULE: Lowercase when abbreviated
   
   Example:
     "prof. Novák" (professor Novák)
     "dr. Svoboda" (doctor Svoboda)

POLISH SPECIFICS:

1. TITLES
   RULE: Conservative capitalization
   
   Example:
     "Nagroda za najlepszą pracę"
     NOT: "Nagroda za Najlepszą Pracę"

2. MONTHS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "15 stycznia 2026"

3. PROFESSIONAL TITLES
   RULE: Lowercase abbreviations
   
   Example:
     "prof. Kowalski"
     "dr Nowak"

RUSSIAN SPECIFICS:

1. CYRILLI SCRIPT CAPITALIZATION
   RULE: Same principles as Latin script
   
   Cyrillic has capitals: А, Б, В... (vs lowercase: а, б, в...)
   
   Apply same rules:
     • Sentence starts: Capitalize
     • Proper nouns: Capitalize
     • Common nouns/adjectives: Lowercase

2. TITLES
   RULE: First word capitalized
   
   Example:
     "Премия за лучшую диссертацию"
     NOT: "Премия за Лучшую Диссертацию"

3. MONTHS AND DAYS
   RULE: Lowercase
   
   Example:
     "понедельник 15 января"

4. FOREIGN NAMES IN CYRILLIC
   RULE: Capitalize as proper nouns
   
   Example:
     "Ассоциация AMTA" (Association AMTA)

CORRECTION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (CS/PL/RU)

STEP 2: FOR RUSSIAN: HANDLE CYRILLIC
  Same capitalization logic applies:
    • А/а, Б/б, В/в... (upper/lower)
    • Sentence starts: Upper
    • Common nouns: Lower

STEP 3: SCAN FOR OVER-CAPITALIZATION
  Look for:
    • Capitalized days/months (should be lowercase)
    • Capitalized common nouns in titles
    • Capitalized adjectives (should be lowercase)

STEP 4: IDENTIFY PROTECTED CAPITALS
  • Sentence starts
  • Proper nouns (names, places, organizations)
  • Acronyms

STEP 5: APPLY SENTENCE CASE
  FOR titles:
    First word: Capitalize
    Rest: Lowercase (except proper nouns)

EXAMPLE CORRECTIONS:

CZECH INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Cena za Nejlepší Disertační Práci bude udělena v Pondělí"

AGENT 253 OUTPUT:
  "Cena za nejlepší disertační práci bude udělena v pondělí"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Cena" kept (sentence start)
    ✗ "Nejlepší" → "nejlepší" (adjective)
    ✗ "Disertační" → "disertační" (adjective)
    ✗ "Práci" → "práci" (common noun)
    ✗ "Pondělí" → "pondělí" (day name)

POLISH INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Nagroda za Najlepszą Pracę Doktorską zostanie przyznana w Poniedziałek"

AGENT 253 OUTPUT:
  "Nagroda za najlepszą pracę doktorską zostanie przyznana w poniedziałek"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Nagroda" kept (sentence start)
    ✗ "Najlepszą" → "najlepszą" (adjective)
    ✗ "Pracę" → "pracę" (common noun)
    ✗ "Doktorską" → "doktorską" (adjective)
    ✗ "Poniedziałek" → "poniedziałek" (day)

RUSSIAN INPUT (over-capitalized):
  "Премия за Лучшую Диссертацию будет вручена в Понедельник"

AGENT 253 OUTPUT:
  "Премия за лучшую диссертацию будет вручена в понедельник"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✓ "Премия" kept (sentence start)
    ✗ "Лучшую" → "лучшую" (adjective - accusative)
    ✗ "Диссертацию" → "диссертацию" (common noun - accusative)
    ✗ "Понедельник" → "понедельник" (day)

KEY PRINCIPLE:
  Slavic languages follow conservative sentence case. Only sentence starts
  and proper nouns capitalize - much like Romance languages, NOT like
  German's noun capitalization.

================================================================================
AGENT 254: CAPITALIZATION HARMONIZER - ASIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Japanese, Chinese, Korean

FUNCTION:
  Handle capitalization for Asian languages (minimal, as these languages
  have different concepts of "capitalization").

ASIAN LANGUAGE CAPITALIZATION:

FUNDAMENTAL DIFFERENCE:
  Chinese, Japanese, and Korean writing systems do NOT have uppercase/
  lowercase distinctions in their native scripts (Kanji/Hanzi/Hanja,
  Hiragana, Katakana, Hangul).
  
  "Capitalization" only applies to:
    • Latin script (rōmaji in Japanese, pinyin in Chinese, romanization
      in Korean)
    • Mixed-script documents

JAPANESE:

1. NO CAPITALIZATION IN NATIVE SCRIPTS
   Kanji (漢字), Hiragana (ひらがな), Katakana (カタカナ) have no caps
   
   Example:
     "最優秀論文賞" (Best Thesis Award)
     No concept of "CAPITAL" vs "lowercase" in Japanese characters

2. LATIN SCRIPT EMBEDDED
   RULE: Follow English capitalization for Latin text
   
   Example:
     "AMTA最優秀論文賞" (AMTA Best Thesis Award)
     "AMTA" remains in caps (Latin acronym)

3. RŌMAJI (ROMANIZATION)
   If Japanese is romanized, follow English sentence case
   
   Example:
     Hiragana: "さいゆうしゅうろんぶんしょう"
     Rōmaji: "Saiyūshū ronbunshō" (sentence case)

CHINESE:

1. NO CAPITALIZATION IN CHARACTERS
   Chinese characters (汉字/漢字) have no uppercase/lowercase
   
   Example:
     "最佳论文奖" (Best Thesis Award)
     All characters same "case"

2. LATIN SCRIPT EMBEDDED
   RULE: Keep Latin text as-is
   
   Example:
     "AMTA最佳论文奖" (AMTA Best Thesis Award)

3. PINYIN (ROMANIZATION)
   If Chinese is romanized, follow sentence case
   
   Example:
     Characters: "最佳论文奖"
     Pinyin: "Zuìjiā lùnwén jiǎng" (sentence case)

KOREAN:

1. HANGUL HAS NO CASE
   한글 (Hangul) characters don't have uppercase/lowercase
   
   Example:
     "최우수 논문상" (Best Thesis Award)
     No capitalization possible in Hangul

2. LATIN SCRIPT EMBEDDED
   RULE: Follow English conventions
   
   Example:
     "AMTA 최우수 논문상"
     "AMTA" stays capitalized (Latin)

3. ROMANIZATION
   If Korean is romanized, use sentence case
   
   Example:
     Hangul: "최우수 논문상"
     Romanization: "Choe-usu nonmun-sang"

CAPITALIZATION TASKS FOR AGENT 254:

Since native scripts have no case, Agent 254 focuses on:

1. EMBEDDED LATIN TEXT
   Ensure acronyms stay capitalized:
     ✓ "AMTA", "UNESCO", "ISO"
   
   Ensure proper nouns capitalize:
     ✓ "Tokyo", "Seoul", "Beijing"

2. MIXED-SCRIPT DOCUMENTS
   When Japanese/Chinese/Korean text includes English:
     • Preserve English capitalization rules
     • Don't try to "capitalize" Asian scripts

3. ROMANIZATION QUALITY (if applicable)
   If document is romanized:
     • Apply sentence case
     • Capitalize proper nouns
     • Lowercase common words

ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY ASIAN LANGUAGE (JA/ZH/KO)

STEP 2: SCAN FOR LATIN SCRIPT
  Look for:
    • A-Z, a-z characters

GLOSSARY: JAPANESE ↔ ENGLISH (509 TERMS)

================================================================================
USI17_GLOSSARY_FULL.txt - COMPLETE GLOSSARY MODULE
503 Technical Terms Across 17 Languages
================================================================================

VERSION: V21.4-LIGHT
DATE: January 2026
SIZE: ~18,000 lines (144K tokens estimated)
MODULE TYPE: Optional on-demand loading

INTEGRATION: Load with USI17_CORE_LIGHT.txt for full production capability

================================================================================
MODULE OVERVIEW
================================================================================

This is a separate glossary module containing all 503 technical terms
with complete translations across all 17 supported languages.

LOADING MODES:
- CORE_LIGHT alone: Uses 5 example terms (basic functionality)
- CORE_LIGHT + GLOSSARY_FULL: Uses all 503 terms (production)
- CORE_LIGHT + GLOSSARY_MINIMAL: Uses top 100 terms (fast mode - future)

CONTENTS:
- Terms 1-5: In USI17_CORE_LIGHT.txt (framework examples)
- Terms 6-503: In this file (complete glossary database)

STRUCTURE:
Each term contains:
- SEMANTIC_ID (SEM_006 through SEM_503)
- DOMAIN classification (pneumatics, hydraulics, etc.)
- LOCKED status (true/false) - enforces 100% compliance if true
- CONFIDENCE score (0.0 to 1.0)
- USAGE_COUNT (tracking frequency)
- All 17 language translations (JA, EN, DE, FR, ES, PT, IT, CZ, PL, TK, VI, TH, ID, KO, CN, TW, MX)
- German morphology (gender, cases, plurals) where applicable

================================================================================
GLOSSARY DATABASE - TERMS 6-503
================================================================================

-e 
<!-- [GLOSSARY_JP_EN_END] -->


    • Acronyms (all caps)
    • Proper names

STEP 3: VERIFY LATIN CAPITALIZATION
  FOR each Latin word/phrase:
    IF acronym (AMTA, UNESCO):
      → Ensure all caps
    IF proper noun (Tokyo):
      → Ensure first letter caps
    IF common word:
      → Lowercase (unless sentence start)

STEP 4: LEAVE NATIVE SCRIPTS ALONE
  • Don't try to "capitalize" 漢字, ひらがな, 한글
  • These scripts don't have case distinctions

EXAMPLE TASKS:

INPUT (Japanese with incorrect Latin):
  "amtaの最優秀論文賞がtokyo で発表されます"

AGENT 254 OUTPUT:
  "AMTAの最優秀論文賞がTokyo で発表されます"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "amta" → "AMTA" (acronym, should be caps)
    ✗ "tokyo" → "Tokyo" (proper noun, capitalize)
    ✓ Japanese text unchanged (no case concept)

INPUT (Chinese with incorrect Latin):
  "amta最佳论文奖将在beijing宣布"

AGENT 254 OUTPUT:
  "AMTA最佳论文奖将在Beijing宣布"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "amta" → "AMTA"
    ✗ "beijing" → "Beijing"
    ✓ Chinese characters unchanged

INPUT (Korean with incorrect Latin):
  "amta 최우수 논문상이 seoul에서 발표됩니다"

AGENT 254 OUTPUT:
  "AMTA 최우수 논문상이 Seoul에서 발표됩니다"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "amta" → "AMTA"
    ✗ "seoul" → "Seoul"
    ✓ Hangul unchanged

SUMMARY:
  Agent 254's job is minimal compared to other agents, because Asian
  languages don't have native capitalization. Focus is on correcting
  any embedded Latin script only.
