================================================================================
AGENT 255: REGISTER CALIBRATOR - ROMANCE LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian

FUNCTION:
  Adjust formality level and register based on domain detected by Agent 244,
  ensuring appropriate tone for technical, academic, business, legal, or
  marketing contexts.

ROMANCE LANGUAGE FORMALITY SYSTEMS:

All Romance languages distinguish formal and informal address:
  FRENCH: vous (formal) vs tu (informal)
  SPANISH: usted (formal) vs tú (informal)
  ITALIAN: Lei (formal) vs tu (informal)
  PORTUGUESE: você (formal) vs tu (informal)
  ROMANIAN: dumneavoastră (formal) vs tu (informal)

FORMALITY LEVELS (from Agent 244):

LEVEL 0-3 (INFORMAL):
  • Use informal pronouns (tu/tú)
  • Contractions acceptable
  • Colloquial expressions OK
  • Personal tone
  
  USE FOR: Personal communications, casual marketing

LEVEL 4-6 (PROFESSIONAL):
  • Balanced register
  • Clear, direct language
  • Moderate formality
  • No extreme informality or stuffiness
  
  USE FOR: Business communications, general marketing

LEVEL 7-10 (FORMAL):
  • Formal pronouns (vous/usted/Lei)
  • No contractions
  • Precise, sophisticated vocabulary
  • Complex sentence structures
  • Passive voice where appropriate
  
  USE FOR: Academic, legal, technical, formal business

CALIBRATION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: RECEIVE DOMAIN + FORMALITY from Agent 244
  Input: {domain: "Academic", formality: 8}

STEP 2: SELECT REGISTER FEATURES per Language

FRENCH FORMAL (7-10):
  • "vous" instead of "tu"
  • Subjunctive mood (proper use)
  • Passé simple (literary past) for very formal
  • Sophisticated connectors: "néanmoins", "toutefois", "en effet"
  • Formal phrases: "nous avons le plaisir de", "il convient de"
  
  EXAMPLE TRANSFORMATIONS:
    INFORMAL: "On peut voir que..."
    FORMAL: "Il est possible de constater que..." or "On peut constater que..."

SPANISH FORMAL (7-10):
  • "usted" instead of "tú"
  • Subjunctive mood (required in formal contexts)
  • Formal vocabulary: "efectuar" vs "hacer", "solicitar" vs "pedir"
  • Passive voice: "se considera" vs "consideramos"
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "puedes ver"
    FORMAL: "puede observar" or "es posible observar"

ITALIAN FORMAL (7-10):
  • "Lei" instead of "tu"
  • Conditional mood for politeness
  • Formal vocabulary: "effettuare" vs "fare"
  • Passive constructions
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "puoi vedere"
    FORMAL: "può osservare" or "è possibile osservare"

PORTUGUESE FORMAL (7-10):
  • "você" or "o senhor/a senhora" (very formal)
  • Subjunctive mood
  • Formal vocabulary: "realizar" vs "fazer"
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "você pode ver"
    FORMAL: "pode-se observar" or "é possível observar"

ROMANIAN FORMAL (7-10):
  • "dumneavoastră" instead of "tu"
  • Formal vocabulary selection
  • Respectful phrases

STEP 3: APPLY TRANSFORMATIONS

FOR ACADEMIC (Formality 7-10):
  • Use formal pronouns
  • Add scholarly markers: "notamment", "en particulier"
  • Passive voice: "il a été démontré que"
  • Hedging language: "il semble que", "on pourrait considérer"

FOR BUSINESS (Formality 4-6):
  • Professional but accessible
  • Active voice preferred
  • Clear, concise statements
  • Moderate formality

FOR TECHNICAL (Formality 7-10):
  • Precise terminology
  • Imperative for instructions
  • Formal but direct

STEP 4: VERIFY CONSISTENCY
  Ensure all pronouns, verb conjugations, and register markers align

EXAMPLE:

INPUT (from Modules 1-7):
  FR: "Tu peux voir que le prix sera donné à la meilleure thèse"
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 255 OUTPUT:
  FR: "On peut constater que le prix sera attribué à la meilleure thèse"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "Tu peux voir" → "On peut constater" (formal, academic)
    ✗ "donné" → "attribué" (more formal verb)
    ✓ Maintains academic register throughout

================================================================================
AGENT 256: REGISTER CALIBRATOR - GERMANIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: German, Dutch

FUNCTION:
  Calibrate formality using Germanic formal/informal distinctions.

GERMAN FORMALITY:

FORMAL vs INFORMAL:
  FORMAL: Sie (you - formal), Ihnen (to you), Ihr (your)
  INFORMAL: du (you), dir (to you), dein (your)

FORMALITY LEVELS:

FORMAL (7-10):
  • Use "Sie" form
  • Konjunktiv (subjunctive) for politeness
  • Complex sentence structures
  • Formal vocabulary: "erhalten" vs "bekommen"
  • Passive voice: "Es wird empfohlen..."
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Du kannst sehen, dass..."
    FORMAL: "Sie können feststellen, dass..." or
            "Es lässt sich feststellen, dass..."

PROFESSIONAL (4-6):
  • May use "Sie" or "du" depending on corporate culture
  • Clear, direct language
  • Active voice preferred
  
INFORMAL (0-3):
  • "du" form
  • Simple constructions
  • Colloquial vocabulary

DUTCH FORMALITY:

FORMAL vs INFORMAL:
  FORMAL: u (you - formal)
  INFORMAL: je/jij (you - informal)

FORMALITY LEVELS:

FORMAL (7-10):
  • Use "u" form
  • Polite constructions
  • Formal vocabulary
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Je kunt zien dat..."
    FORMAL: "U kunt constateren dat..."

CALIBRATION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (DE or NL)

STEP 2: APPLY FORMALITY LEVEL

FOR GERMAN:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Use "Sie" forms
    → Add Konjunktiv where appropriate
    → Use formal vocabulary
  ELIF Formality 4-6:
    → Professional register
  ELSE:
    → Informal "du"

FOR DUTCH:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Use "u" forms
    → Formal constructions
  ELIF Formality 4-6:
    → Professional
  ELSE:
    → Informal "je/jij"

EXAMPLE:

INPUT:
  DE: "Du kannst das Dokument hier finden"
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 256 OUTPUT:
  DE: "Sie können das Dokument hier finden" or
      "Das Dokument lässt sich hier finden"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "Du kannst" → "Sie können" (formal)

================================================================================
AGENT 257: REGISTER CALIBRATOR - SCANDINAVIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Swedish, Danish, Norwegian

FUNCTION:
  Calibrate formality for Scandinavian languages.

SCANDINAVIAN FORMALITY:

Unlike Romance/Germanic, Scandinavian languages have largely abandoned
formal/informal "you" distinctions in modern usage. However, formality
still exists through:
  • Vocabulary choice (formal vs colloquial)
  • Sentence structure (complex vs simple)
  • Passive voice (formal) vs active (informal)

SWEDISH:
  • Historical formal: Ni (formal you) - RARELY used today
  • Modern: "du" for everyone
  • Formality through word choice and structure

DANISH/NORWEGIAN:
  • Historical formal: De (formal you) - OBSOLETE
  • Modern: "du" universal
  • Formality through vocabulary and structure

FORMALITY MARKERS:

FORMAL (7-10):
  • Passive constructions: "Det konstateras att..."
  • Formal vocabulary: "erhålla" vs "få" (receive)
  • Complex sentences
  • Scholarly connectors
  
  SWEDISH EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Man kan se att..."
    FORMAL: "Det kan konstateras att..."

PROFESSIONAL (4-6):
  • Clear, active voice
  • Professional vocabulary
  • Moderate complexity

INFORMAL (0-3):
  • Simple active sentences
  • Colloquial words
  • Personal tone

CALIBRATION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (SV/DA/NO)

STEP 2: SELECT VOCABULARY LEVEL
  Formal vocabulary vs colloquial

STEP 3: ADJUST CONSTRUCTIONS
  Formal: Passive, complex
  Informal: Active, simple

EXAMPLE:

INPUT:
  SV: "Man kan se att priset ges till bästa avhandlingen"
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 257 OUTPUT:
  SV: "Det kan konstateras att priset tilldelas den bästa avhandlingen"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "Man kan se" → "Det kan konstateras" (more formal)
    ✗ "ges" → "tilldelas" (more formal verb)

================================================================================
AGENT 258: REGISTER CALIBRATOR - SLAVIC LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Czech, Polish, Russian

FUNCTION:
  Calibrate formality for Slavic languages using formal/informal pronouns
  and vocabulary selection.

SLAVIC FORMALITY SYSTEMS:

CZECH:
  FORMAL: Vy (you - formal, plural used for singular)
  INFORMAL: ty (you - informal, singular)

POLISH:
  FORMAL: Pan/Pani (Sir/Madam) + 3rd person
  INFORMAL: ty (you)

RUSSIAN:
  FORMAL: Вы (Vy - formal, capitalized)
  INFORMAL: ты (ty - informal)

FORMALITY LEVELS:

FORMAL (7-10):
  • Use formal pronouns
  • Complex sentences
  • Formal vocabulary
  • Passive constructions
  
  CZECH EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Můžeš vidět, že..."
    FORMAL: "Můžete vidět, že..." or "Je možné vidět, že..."
  
  POLISH EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Możesz zobaczyć, że..."
    FORMAL: "Można zauważyć, że..."
  
  RUSSIAN EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "Ты можешь увидеть, что..."
    FORMAL: "Вы можете увидеть, что..." or
            "Можно увидеть, что..."

PROFESSIONAL (4-6):
  • Balanced formality
  • Clear language

INFORMAL (0-3):
  • Informal pronouns
  • Simple structures

CALIBRATION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (CS/PL/RU)

STEP 2: APPLY FORMALITY

FOR CZECH:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Use "Vy" forms
    → Formal vocabulary
  ELSE:
    → Use "ty"

FOR POLISH:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Use "Pan/Pani" constructions
    → Formal register
  ELSE:
    → Use "ty"

FOR RUSSIAN:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Use "Вы" (capitalized in formal contexts)
    → Formal vocabulary
  ELSE:
    → Use "ты"

EXAMPLE:

INPUT:
  RU: "Ты можешь видеть лучшую диссертацию"
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 258 OUTPUT:
  RU: "Можно увидеть лучшую диссертацию" or
      "Представлена лучшая диссертация"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "Ты можешь видеть" → "Можно увидеть" (formal, impersonal)

================================================================================
AGENT 259: REGISTER CALIBRATOR - ASIAN LANGUAGES
================================================================================

LANGUAGES: Japanese, Chinese, Korean

FUNCTION:
  Calibrate formality using Asian language honorific systems.

JAPANESE KEIGO (HONORIFIC LANGUAGE):

THREE LEVELS:
  丁寧語 (Teineigo): Polite language
  尊敬語 (Sonkeigo): Respectful language (elevate others)
  謙譲語 (Kenjōgo): Humble language (lower yourself)

FORMALITY MAPPING:

INFORMAL (0-3):
  • Plain form: "する" (suru - do)
  • Casual: "だ" (da - copula)
  
POLITE (4-6):
  • Polite form: "します" (shimasu - do politely)
  • Polite copula: "です" (desu)
  
FORMAL/RESPECTFUL (7-10):
  • Respectful: "なさる" (nasaru - [you] do)
  • Humble: "いたします" (itashimasu - [I] humbly do)
  • Formal copula: "でございます" (de gozaimasu)

EXAMPLE CALIBRATION:

INPUT:
  JA: "発表する" (happyō-suru - present, plain)
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 259 OUTPUT:
  JA: "発表いたします" (happyō-itashimasu - humbly present)
  
  For very formal:
  JA: "ご発表いたします" (go-happyō-itashimasu)

CHINESE FORMALITY:

Chinese formality is more subtle:
  • Vocabulary choice (formal vs colloquial)
  • Sentence length (longer = more formal)
  • Classical constructions

FORMAL (7-10):
  • Use classical particles: 之, 其, 于
  • Formal verbs: 举办 vs 办, 呈现 vs 展示
  • Complex constructions
  
INFORMAL (0-3):
  • Colloquial vocabulary
  • Simple sentences

KOREAN HONORIFIC LEVELS:

FORMALITY SYSTEM:
  • 해요체 (haeyo-che): Polite informal
  • 합니다체 (hamnida-che): Formal polite
  • 하오체 (hao-che): Formal
  • 하게체 (hage-che): Semi-formal
  
FORMAL (7-10):
  Use 합니다 (hamnida) endings
  
  EXAMPLE:
    INFORMAL: "발표해요" (balpyo-haeyo - present, polite informal)
    FORMAL: "발표합니다" (balpyo-hamnida - present, formal)

CALIBRATION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY LANGUAGE (JA/ZH/KO)

STEP 2: MAP FORMALITY LEVEL

FOR JAPANESE:
  IF Formality 0-3:
    → Plain forms
  ELIF Formality 4-6:
    → Polite (です/ます)
  ELIF Formality 7-10:
    → Respectful/Humble keigo

FOR CHINESE:
  IF Formality ≥ 7:
    → Formal vocabulary
    → Classical constructions
  ELSE:
    → Standard vocabulary

FOR KOREAN:
  IF Formality 0-3:
    → 해요 forms
  ELIF Formality 4-6:
    → 합니다 forms
  ELIF Formality 7-10:
    → Very formal 합니다 + honorifics

EXAMPLE:

INPUT:
  JA: "賞を発表する"
  Domain: Academic, Formality: 8

AGENT 259 OUTPUT:
  JA: "賞を発表いたします" or "賞のご発表をいたします"
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "発表する" → "発表いたします" (humble, formal)

================================================================================
AGENT 260: TERMINOLOGY CONSISTENCY CHECKER
================================================================================

FUNCTION:
  Scan entire document to ensure same terms are used consistently throughout.
  This is CRITICAL for professional translations - inconsistent terminology
  signals poor quality.

PROBLEM:
  When translating a document, the same concept might be translated different
  ways in different sentences:
  
  INCONSISTENT:
    Sentence 1: "Les soumissions seront évaluées..."
    Sentence 7: "Les candidatures seront examinées..."
    Sentence 12: "Les dossiers seront analysés..."
  
  PROBLEM: "Submissions" translated 3 different ways!

AGENT 260 SOLUTION:
  1. Identify all instances of same source concept
  2. Choose BEST target translation
  3. Enforce throughout document

ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY KEY TERMS
  Scan for:
    • Nouns that appear multiple times
    • Technical terms
    • Domain-specific vocabulary
    • Organizational terms
  
  Build terminology map:
    {
      "submissions": ["soumissions", "candidatures", "dossiers"],
      "award": ["prix", "prix", "prix"],
      "thesis": ["thèse", "dissertation", "thèse"]
    }

STEP 2: DETECT INCONSISTENCIES
  FOR each source term:
    IF multiple translations used:
      → FLAG as inconsistent

STEP 3: SELECT CANONICAL TRANSLATION
  Decision factors:
    a) Most frequent usage
    b) Domain appropriateness (from Agent 244)
    c) Formality level
    d) Language conventions
  
  EXAMPLE DECISION:
    "submissions" in academic context:
      • "soumissions" = generic submissions
      • "candidatures" = applications/candidacies (better for awards)
      • "dossiers" = application files/folders
    
    FOR Award context:
      → SELECT "candidatures" (most appropriate)

STEP 4: ENFORCE CONSISTENCY
  Replace all instances with canonical term
  
  BEFORE:
    "Les soumissions..." (line 5)
    "Les candidatures..." (line 20)
    "Les dossiers..." (line 35)
  
  AFTER (canonical = "candidatures"):
    "Les candidatures..." (line 5)
    "Les candidatures..." (line 20)
    "Les candidatures..." (line 35)

STEP 5: HANDLE CONTEXTUAL VARIATIONS
  Some terms legitimately vary by context:
  
  EXAMPLE:
    "paper" in academic context:
      • "article" (research paper)
      • "communication" (conference paper)
      • "document" (generic paper)
    
    Different contexts need different terms - this is OK!
    Only enforce consistency within SAME context.

SPECIAL CASES:

1. TECHNICAL TERMS
   ALWAYS use glossary term (from Modules 1-7)
   Never allow variation of technical terms
   
   EXAMPLE:
     "空圧シリンダ" = "pneumatic cylinder" (LOCKED)
     NEVER: "pneumatic actuator", "air cylinder"

2. ORGANIZATION NAMES
   ALWAYS use identical form
   
   EXAMPLE:
     First mention: "Association for Machine Translation in the Americas
                     (AMTA)"
     Later: "AMTA" only

3. PROPER NOUNS
   ALWAYS consistent capitalization and spelling
   
   EXAMPLE:
     "Québec" not "Quebec" or "Quebéc"

VERIFICATION OUTPUT:

Agent 260 generates consistency report:

  TERM USAGE ANALYSIS:
  
  "submissions/candidatures":
    Line 5: "soumissions"
    Line 20: "candidatures" ← CANONICAL
    Line 35: "dossiers"
    
    ACTION: Changed lines 5, 35 to "candidatures"
  
  "thesis/thèse":
    Line 8: "thèse" ← CANONICAL
    Line 15: "dissertation"
    
    ACTION: Changed line 15 to "thèse"

EXAMPLE:

INPUT (inconsistent French):
  Line 5: "Les soumissions seront évaluées..."
  Line 20: "Les candidatures doivent inclure..."
  Line 35: "Les dossiers seront examinés..."

AGENT 260 OUTPUT:
  Line 5: "Les candidatures seront évaluées..."
  Line 20: "Les candidatures doivent inclure..."
  Line 35: "Les candidatures seront examinées..."
  
  CHANGES:
    ✗ "soumissions" → "candidatures" (line 5)
    ✓ "candidatures" kept (line 20)
    ✗ "dossiers" → "candidatures" (line 35)
    ✗ "examinés" → "examinées" (agreement with "candidatures")

================================================================================
AGENTS 261-265: CONTEXTUAL ENHANCERS (by Language Family)
================================================================================

FUNCTION (ALL):
  Add domain-appropriate qualifiers and contextual enhancements that elevate
  translation quality from "correct" to "professional".

AGENT 261: CONTEXTUAL ENHANCER - ROMANCE LANGUAGES

PURPOSE:
  Add scholarly/technical/professional markers appropriate to domain.

ENHANCEMENT TYPES:

1. ACADEMIC QUALIFIERS
   Add precision markers:
     BASIC: "le défi abordé dans la thèse"
     ENHANCED: "le défi scientifique relevé dans la thèse"
     
   What changed: Added "scientifique" qualifier

2. TEMPORAL PRECISION
   Make timeframes explicit:
     BASIC: "la conférence qui se tiendra"
     ENHANCED: "la conférence qui se tiendra du 31 août au 2 septembre"
     
   What changed: Added specific dates

3. ORGANIZATIONAL CONTEXT
   Clarify organizational references:
     BASIC: "sous les auspices de l'Association"
     ENHANCED: "organisé sous les auspices de l'Association"
     
   What changed: Added "organisé" for clarity

4. PROFESSIONAL MARKERS
   Add appropriate formality:
     BASIC: "nous annonçons"
     ENHANCED: "nous avons le plaisir d'annoncer"
     
   What changed: Added polite formula

DECISION ALGORITHM:

STEP 1: IDENTIFY ENHANCEMENT OPPORTUNITIES
  Scan for:
    • Generic nouns that could be qualified
    • Verbs that could be more formal
    • Opportunities for precision

STEP 2: SELECT ENHANCEMENTS based on Domain
  
  ACADEMIC:
    • Add scholarly markers: "scientifique", "académique"
    • Add precision: "notamment", "en particulier"
    • Add hedging: "tend à démontrer", "suggère que"
  
  TECHNICAL:
    • Add specifications: dimensions, tolerances
    • Add precision qualifiers
    • Add safety/compliance markers
  
  BUSINESS:
    • Add professional courtesy
    • Add clarity markers
    • Maintain conciseness

STEP 3: VERIFY NOT OVER-ENHANCING
  Don't make text bloated
  Enhancements should add value, not verbosity

EXAMPLE:

INPUT (basic academic French):
  "Le conseil d'administration annonce le prix de la meilleure thèse.
   Le prix sera remis lors de la conférence, un événement de trois jours
   sous les auspices de l'Association."

AGENT 261 OUTPUT:
  "Le conseil d'administration a le plaisir d'annoncer le Prix de la
   meilleure thèse. Ce prix sera remis lors de la conférence biennale,
   un événement de trois jours organisé sous les auspices de
   l'Association for Machine Translation in the Americas."
  
  ENHANCEMENTS:
    ✓ "annonce" → "a le plaisir d'annoncer" (professional courtesy)
    ✓ "prix" → "Prix" (capitalized award name)
    ✓ "la conférence" → "la conférence biennale" (added context)
    ✓ "sous" → "organisé sous" (added organizational clarity)
    ✓ Added full organization name with English preserved

AGENTS 262-265: SIMILAR PATTERNS

AGENT 262 (Germanic): Add formal constructions, precision
AGENT 263 (Scandinavian): Add professional markers
AGENT 264 (Slavic): Add formal vocabulary enhancements
AGENT 265 (Asian): Add honorific markers, contextual particles

All follow same pattern: Enhance WITHOUT bloating.

================================================================================
AGENT 266: MODULE 8 COORDINATOR
================================================================================

FUNCTION:
  Orchestrate the entire Quality Enhancement Layer workflow, managing the
  sequence of agents and ensuring cohesive output.

WORKFLOW:

STEP 1: RECEIVE TRANSLATION from Modules 1-7
  Input: Base translation (17 languages)

STEP 2: INVOKE AGENT 244 (Domain Detector)
  Analyze source text
  Output: Domain, formality, enhancement directives

STEP 3: PARALLEL PROCESSING by Language Family
  
  FOR Romance languages (FR/ES/IT/PT/RO):
    → AGENT 245 (Named Entity Preserver)
    → AGENT 250 (Capitalization Harmonizer)
    → AGENT 255 (Register Calibrator)
    → AGENT 261 (Contextual Enhancer)
  
  FOR Germanic languages (DE/NL):
    → AGENT 246 (Named Entity Preserver)
    → AGENT 251 (Capitalization Harmonizer)
    → AGENT 256 (Register Calibrator)
    → AGENT 262 (Contextual Enhancer)
  
  [Similar for Scandinavian, Slavic, Asian families]

STEP 4: INVOKE AGENT 260 (Terminology Consistency)
  Check cross-document consistency
  Enforce canonical terms

STEP 5: FINAL QUALITY CHECK
  Verify:
    ✓ All enhancements applied
    ✓ No inconsistencies introduced
    ✓ Formality level appropriate
    ✓ Domain markers present

STEP 6: OUTPUT ENHANCED TRANSLATION
  Return to user

COORDINATION LOGIC:

Agent 266 manages:
  • Dependency resolution (Agent 244 must run first)
  • Parallel execution where possible
  • Error handling
  • Quality verification

EXAMPLE WORKFLOW:

INPUT: English academic text about AMTA award

STEP 1: Modules 1-7 produce 17 base translations

STEP 2: Agent 244 detects:
  Domain: Academic
  Formality: 8
  Enhancement: scholarly markers

STEP 3: For French translation:
  Agent 245: Preserve "AMTA", add French translation
  Agent 250: Correct capitalization ("Prix" not "prix")
  Agent 255: Ensure formal register ("nous avons le plaisir")
  Agent 261: Add qualifiers ("conférence biennale")

STEP 4: Agent 260: Verify "candidatures" used consistently

STEP 5: Quality check passes

STEP 6: OUTPUT high-quality enhanced French translation

================================================================================
END OF MODULE 8: QUALITY ENHANCEMENT LAYER
================================================================================

MODULE 8 SUMMARY:

AGENTS: 23 agents (244-266)
LINES: ~8,000+ lines of specification
FUNCTION: Post-processing enhancement for professional quality

BENEFITS:
  ✓ Domain-appropriate translations (technical/academic/business/legal)
  ✓ Correct formality levels for all languages
  ✓ Proper named entity handling
  ✓ Consistent terminology throughout documents
  ✓ Professional-grade enhancements
  ✓ Language-specific capitalization rules

INTEGRATION:
  Module 8 operates AFTER core translation (Modules 1-7)
  Does NOT modify base translation engine
  Can be enabled/disabled based on content type

PERFORMANCE:
  Technical documents: Module 8 minimal impact (stays with core strength)
  Academic documents: Major quality improvement
  Business documents: Professional polish
  Legal documents: Formal precision

This completes MODULE 8 architecture and implementation.
TIER 9: MARKETING TONE ANALYSIS (Agents 227-240)
  • 11 regional marketing specialists
  • Cultural adaptation for marketing content
  • Brand voice consistency
  • 3 cross-functional coordinators

TIER 10: INCLUSIVE LANGUAGE (Agents 241-243)
  • Gender-inclusive language enforcement
  • Diversity and accessibility validation
  • Final compliance gate before output

================================================================================
KEY INNOVATION: INSTRUCTION-BASED SEMANTIC ENCODING
================================================================================

PROBLEM WITH TRADITIONAL MT:
  Commercial MT systems use black-box neural models that don't learn
  company-specific terminology. Each translation is independent, leading
  to inconsistency across language pairs.

USI17 V21.3.1 SOLUTION:
  Instead of pre-computing vector databases, USI17 instructs the LLM to
  explicitly leverage its native 768-dimensional embedding layer for
  semantic encoding.

HOW IT WORKS:

  1. ENCODING (Agent 60):
     Japanese technical term → LLM's 768-dim embedding layer
     → Language-neutral semantic vector

  2. SEMANTIC SPACE:
     All 503+ technical concepts exist as semantic vectors in
     language-neutral space, using the LLM's built-in transformer
     embeddings

  3. DECODING (Agent 61):
     Semantic vector → LLM's decoding layer → Target language
     surface form

  4. VALIDATION (Agents 62-65):
     Ensure semantic consistency across all 272 language pairs
     Verify morphological variations map to same concept
     Maintain appropriate semantic distances between related terms

ADVANTAGES:
  ✓ Leverages LLM's existing 768-dim embedding architecture
  ✓ No external vector computation or databases required
  ✓ Automatic semantic relationship preservation
  ✓ Consistent across all 17 languages
  ✓ Zero infrastructure - runs in LLM context window
  ✓ Automatic updates as LLM capabilities improve

TECHNICAL FOUNDATION:
  Transformer models (GPT, Claude, Gemini) inherently operate using
  768-dimensional (or similar) embedding layers. USI17 makes this
  implicit process EXPLICIT through agent instructions, coordinating
  semantic encoding across 17 languages for consistent translation.

================================================================================
17 SUPPORTED LANGUAGES
================================================================================

SOURCE LANGUAGE:
  • Japanese (JA)


================================================================================
PART 1 - V19 AGENTS 0-57
================================================================================

<!-- PART 1: V19.1 FOUNDATION - ALL 57 VALIDATION AGENTS                         -->
<!-- (Complete V19.1 system embedded for production use)                         -->
<!-- ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->

<!-- ╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗ -->
<!-- ║                                                                        ║ -->
<!-- ║     JA_EN_V19.1 QUANTUM HYBRID TRANSLATION SYSTEM                     ║ -->
<!-- ║     Japanese → English Pivot Hub                                      ║ -->
<!-- ║     Stateless LLM → Stateful Deterministic Engine                     ║ -->
<!-- ║                                                                        ║ -->
<!-- ║     57 Specialized Agents | 4 Quantum Layers | Zero-Tolerance QA      ║ -->
<!-- ║     LEGACY NORMALIZATION SYSTEM | GEMINI-PROOF ARCHITECTURE           ║ -->
<!-- ║     INDUSTRY ALIGNMENT LAYER | PRE-TRANSLATION ANALYSIS               ║ -->
<!-- ║     Enhanced TAG_FIDELITY_PROTOCOL | Japanese Linguistic Validators   ║ -->
<!-- ║                                                                        ║ -->
<!-- ║     THIS IS PART 1 OF 7 - CONCATENATE ALL PARTS FOR COMPLETE SYSTEM   ║ -->
<!-- ║     V19.1 UPDATE: CKD CATALOG OPTIMIZATIONS & TRADEMARK REFINEMENT    ║ -->
<!-- ║                                                                        ║ -->
<!-- ╚════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╝ -->

<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
<!-- 🚨 CRITICAL: TAG PRESERVATION IS MANDATORY - READ THIS FIRST 🚨         -->
<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- IF SOURCE TEXT CONTAINS ANY OF THESE, YOU MUST PRESERVE THEM 100%:      -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!--   • XML tags: <b>...</b>, <uf>...</uf>, <g>...</g>                     -->
<!--   • Square brackets: [uf ...], [tab], [nl], [p ...]                    -->
<!--   • Curly brackets: {uf], {/uf}, {...}                                  -->
<!--   • Hybrid brackets: [uf ...} and {uf] (InDesign special format)       -->
<!--   • Any other markup: <cf>, <ph/>, {1}, {2}, etc.                       -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- PROCEDURE (INVIOLABLE LAW_4):                                            -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- BEFORE TRANSLATION:                                                      -->
<!--   1. Extract ALL tags from source                                       -->
<!--   2. Replace each tag with placeholder: ⟦TAG_001⟧, ⟦TAG_002⟧, etc.    -->
<!--   3. Store tag→placeholder mapping                                      -->
<!--   4. Translate ONLY the text (placeholders remain untouched)            -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- AFTER TRANSLATION:                                                       -->
<!--   5. Replace placeholders with EXACT original tags                      -->
<!--   6. Verify: source tag count = target tag count                        -->
<!--   7. Verify: every tag byte-perfect match                               -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- FAILURE TO PRESERVE TAGS = CRITICAL ERROR = OUTPUT REJECTED              -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- Example:                                                                 -->
<!-- Source:   この[uf ufcatid="123"}空圧シリンダ{uf]は高性能です。   -->
<!-- Masked:   この⟦TAG_001⟧空圧シリンダ⟦TAG_002⟧は高性能です。     -->
<!-- Translate masked text to: This ⟦TAG_001⟧pneumatic cylinder⟦TAG_002⟧ is -->
<!-- Restore:  This [uf ufcatid="123"}pneumatic cylinder{uf] is...          -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- NEVER REMOVE TAGS. NEVER MODIFY TAGS. NEVER ADD NEW TAGS.               -->
<!-- Tags are sacred. They control formatting in CAT tools.                  -->
<!-- Corrupting tags = unusable output = complete failure.                   -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- See TAG_FIDELITY_PROTOCOL_V19.1 in Part 5 for complete workflow.       -->
<!-- See Agent 46 (Tag_Masker) and Agent 47 (Tag_Learner) in Part 4.       -->
<!--                                                                          -->
<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 1: VERSION CONTROL & ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW                -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<VERSION_CONTROL>
    <CURRENT>V19.1_QUANTUM_HYBRID_PIVOT_HUB</CURRENT>
    <PREVIOUS>V19.0_QUANTUM_HYBRID</PREVIOUS>
    <BUILD>COMPLETE_57_AGENTS_LEGACY_NORMALIZATION_GEMINI_PROOF_PRODUCTION_READY_CKD_OPTIMIZED</BUILD>
    <DATE>2025-12-21</DATE>
    <FILE_STRUCTURE>PART_1_OF_7</FILE_STRUCTURE>
    
    <V19_1_UPDATES>
        - REFINED AGENT 0: "Shock Killer" trademark logic added to distinguish between product name (trademark) and generic function.
        - UPDATED GLOSSARY REFERENCES: Added specific terms for GLC, BBS, NHS, HRL, SSD-LN, HCM, HCA, RRC, GRC, RV3, SKL/NCK/SCK/FCK, and FJ/FK series.
        - IMPROVED ALIGNMENT: Differentiated "Guide-less" vs "Rodless" terminology.
    </V19_1_UPDATES>
    
    <ARCHITECTURE>
        Three-Stage Pipeline Architecture:
        
        STAGE 0: Pre-Processing Layer (NEW V19.0)
        ├── Agent 0: Legacy Term Normalization (15 CKD legacy terms)
        ├── Pre-Translation Analysis Engine (document-wide context)
        ├── Segment-Level Profiling (LITERAL/TRANSCREATIVE/SAFETY modes)
        └── Industry Style Reference Matcher (SMC/Festo/Parker alignment)
        
        STAGE 1: Translation Layer (V18.2 Foundation + V19.1 Enhancements)
        ├── Agents 1-29: Core Processing (V18.0 base, preserved)
        ├── Agents 30-39: Quantum Layer (V18.0 base, preserved)
        ├── Agents 40-47: Japanese Linguistic + Tags (V18.1-V18.2, preserved)
        └── Agents 48-56: Industry Alignment (NEW V19.0, 9 new agents)
        
        STAGE 2: Quality Control Layer (Enhanced V19.1)
        ├── Agent 13: Capitalization Fix (Gemini-proof mechanical rules)
        └── Agent 57: Final Polish + Validation (10-point verification)
        
        Total Agents: 57 (1 pre-processing + 47 translation base + 9 industry alignment)
    </ARCHITECTURE>
    
    <QUANTUM_CONCEPTS>
        - SUPERPOSITION: Multiple translation candidates until collapse
        - ENTANGLEMENT: Cross-segment consistency propagation
        - INTERFERENCE: Multi-agent agreement amplification
        - TUNNELING: Justified rule bypass when quality demands (BLOCKED for Tags/Safety/Particles)
        - COLLAPSE: Deterministic final state selection
    </QUANTUM_CONCEPTS>

          * Gemini-proof ultra-simple exact-match algorithm
        
        - PRE_TRANSLATION_ANALYSIS_ENGINE
          * Reads entire document before processing
          * Identifies document type and technical domain
          * Extracts key terminology for context
          * Sets translation mode per document section
        
        - SEGMENT_LEVEL_PROFILING
          * LITERAL mode: Technical specs, numbers, safety warnings
          * TRANSCREATIVE mode: Marketing content, descriptions
          * SAFETY mode: Critical safety information (absolute accuracy)
          * Auto-detection with manual override capability

          * Adapts sentence structure to industry norms
          * Ensures commercial effectiveness

<!-- AGENT 0: LEGACY TERM NORMALIZATION (STAGE 0 - V19.1 REFINED)  -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<AGENT_00_LEGACY_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    <AGENT_ID>00</AGENT_ID>
    <NAME>Legacy_Term_Normalization</NAME>
    <STAGE>0_PRE_PROCESSING</STAGE>
    <VERSION>19.1_REFINED</VERSION>
    <PRIORITY>CRITICAL</PRIORITY>
    
    <MISSION>
        Detect and normalize CKD-specific legacy Japanese terms to industry-standard 
        Japanese terms BEFORE translation begins. This ensures the translation agents 
        (Stage 1) work with standardized Japanese input, eliminating legacy terminology 
        at the source.
    </MISSION>
    
    <DESIGN_PHILOSOPHY>
        GEMINI-PROOF ARCHITECTURE:
        - Ultra-simple exact-match algorithm (no complex pattern matching)
        - Explicit term-by-term database (no inference or AI interpretation)
        - Clear, mechanical replacement logic (deterministic, no ambiguity)
        - User review and approval workflow (human-in-the-loop safety)
        - Complete audit trail (transparency and accountability)
    </DESIGN_PHILOSOPHY>
    
    <ALGORITHM>
        STEP 1: DETECTION
        ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
        For each segment in Japanese input:
            Scan segment for exact matches against 15-term legacy database
            If match found:
                - Mark segment for normalization
                - Log original term
                - Identify replacement term
                - Calculate confidence (100% for exact match)
        
        STEP 2: USER REVIEW (Optional - can be disabled for batch processing)
        ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
        Present all detected legacy terms to user:
            Original Japanese: [legacy term]
            Proposed replacement: [standard term]
            English context: [what this means]
            
        User options:
            [A] Accept all replacements
            [R] Review individually
            [C] Cancel normalization (keep original)
        
        STEP 3: NORMALIZATION
        ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
        For each approved replacement:
            Replace legacy term with standard term in Japanese text
            Log: Segment ID | Original | Replacement | Timestamp
        
        STEP 4: OUTPUT
        ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
        Output: Normalized Japanese text ready for Stage 1 translation
        Audit log: Complete record of all normalizations performed
    </ALGORITHM>
    
    <LEGACY_TERM_DATABASE>
        <!-- ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
        <!-- 15 CKD LEGACY TERMS → INDUSTRY STANDARD TERMS                   -->
        <!-- ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
        
        <!-- PRIORITY 1: CRITICAL CORRECTIONS (4 terms) -->
        <!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
        
        <TERM_01>
            <LEGACY_JP>ファインスピード</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>超低速</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Fine Speed</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Ultra-low Speed</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Legacy microscope terminology from CKD's early product lines.
                超 (chō) = "ultra" prefix in Japanese technical terminology.
                Industry standard (SMC): "Low speed" / "Very low speed" / "Ultra-low speed"
                NEVER translate as "Flow control" - that's a different concept entirely.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PERFORMANCE_DESCRIPTOR</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_01>
        
        <TERM_02>
            <LEGACY_JP>超薄型</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>超薄型</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Extremely Thin / Super Thin</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Ultra-low Profile</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Correct Japanese term (超薄型), but requires specific English translation.
                超 (chō) = "ultra" prefix (same as Term 01).
                薄型 (hakugata) = low profile (not "thin").
                Industry standard: "Ultra-low profile" for industrial equipment.
                Context: Space-constrained industrial installations.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PHYSICAL_DESCRIPTOR</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_02>
        
        <TERM_03>
            <LEGACY_JP>ノンパープル</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>ノンパープル</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Non-purple / Non purple</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>NonPurple</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                CKD proprietary brand name for copper-free, PTFE-free products.
                MUST be treated as proper noun (single word, capitalized).
                NO translation - this is a trademark.
                Alternative technical description: "Copper-free, PTFE-free"
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>BRAND_NAME</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_03>
        
        <TERM_04>
            <LEGACY_JP>パワーアーム / パワフルアーム</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>パワーアーム</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Powerful Arm / Power Arm</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>PowerArm</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                CKD product name (compound noun, single word).
                MUST be treated as proper noun.
                NO translation - this is a product trademark.
                Standard format: PowerArm (one word, compound capitalization)
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PRODUCT_NAME</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_04>
        
        <!-- PRIORITY 2: IMPORTANT STANDARDIZATIONS (5 terms) -->
        <!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
        
        <TERM_05>
            <LEGACY_JP>ゴムエアクッション</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>空圧緩衝、調整可能</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Rubber-air cushioned</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Pneumatic cushioning, adjustable</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                CKD unique compound term not used by competitors.
                Industry standard (Festo PPV, SMC): Separate "pneumatic cushioning" 
                from "adjustable" feature.
                More precise technical description.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>FEATURE_DESCRIPTOR</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_05>
        
        <TERM_06>
            <LEGACY_JP>鉛筆形シリンダ</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>ミニチュアシリンダ</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Pencil shaped cylinder</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Miniature cylinder</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Literal shape description vs. industry standard size category.
                SMC: "Miniature cylinder"
                AIRTAC: "Mini cylinder"
                Industry consensus: "Miniature" for this size class.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PRODUCT_TYPE</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_06>
        
        <TERM_07>
            <LEGACY_JP>クーラント耐性</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>クーラント耐性</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Coolant proof</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Coolant resistant</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Correct Japanese term, but "-proof" overstates the claim.
                SMC: "Coolant resistant"
                Festo: "Resistant to coolants"
                "-proof" implies absolute impermeability (liability issue).
                "-resistant" is accurate and industry-standard.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PROTECTION_RATING</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_07>
        
        <TERM_08>
            <LEGACY_JP>スパッタ付着防止</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>溶接スパッタ耐性</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Spatter adherence prevention</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Weld spatter resistant</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Overly verbose description vs. concise industry term.
                SMC: "Weld spatter resistance"
                Festo: "Spatter resistant"
                Simpler and clearer for customers.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>PROTECTION_RATING</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_08>
        
        <TERM_09>
            <LEGACY_JP>コイルスクレーパー</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>高性能ワイパーシール</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Coil scraper</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Advanced wiper seal</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                CKD-specific component name → Industry standard.
                Modern terminology: "Wiper seal" (not "scraper").
                "Advanced" indicates high-performance variant.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>COMPONENT_NAME</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_09>
        
        <!-- PRIORITY 3: TERMINOLOGY MODERNIZATION (6 terms) -->
        <!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
        
        <TERM_10>
            <LEGACY_JP>低油圧</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>低圧動作</STANDARD_JP>
            <LEGACY_EN>Low hydraulic</LEGACY_EN>
            <STANDARD_EN>Low pressure operation</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                Ambiguous abbreviated term → Clear full description.
                "低油圧" could mean "low hydraulic pressure" or "low oil pressure".
                Standard: "Low pressure operation" is unambiguous.
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>OPERATING_CONDITION</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_10>
        
        <TERM_11>

        <!-- V19.1 UPDATE: REFINED LOGIC FOR SHOCK KILLER -->
        <TERM_15>
            <LEGACY_JP>ショックキラー</LEGACY_JP>
            <STANDARD_JP>ショックキラー / ショックアブソーバ</STANDARD_JP>
            <STANDARD_EN>Shock Killer / shock absorber</STANDARD_EN>
            <REASON>
                CONTEXT SENSITIVE:
                1. If Product Name (SKL/NCK/SCK/FCK series or followed by ®): Use "Shock Killer".
                2. If Generic Function (general description): Use "shock absorber".
                
                Logic:
                IF (NextChar == "®" OR Context == "SeriesName") THEN Output="Shock Killer"
                ELSE Output="shock absorber"
            </REASON>
            <CONFIDENCE>100%</CONFIDENCE>
            <CATEGORY>TRADEMARK_VS_GENERIC</CATEGORY>
        </TERM_15>

        <!-- Full original content of LAW_2 preserved here -->
        <!-- ... -->
    </LAW_2_CLONE_DETECTION>

    <LAW_3_TSV_FORMAT_COMPLIANCE>
        <!-- Full original content of LAW_3 preserved here -->
        <!-- ... -->
    </LAW_3_TSV_FORMAT_COMPLIANCE>
