        ├── Replace each tag with its placeholder
        ├── Preserve placeholder position
        └── OUTPUT: Masked segment (text only, no tags)
        
        Example:
        Original:  この<b>空圧シリンダ</b>は[uf ufcatid="123"}高性能{uf]です。
        Masked:    この⟦TAG_001⟧空圧シリンダ⟦TAG_002⟧は⟦TAG_003⟧高性能⟦TAG_004⟧です。
        
        Registry:
        ⟦TAG_001⟧ → <b>
        ⟦TAG_002⟧ → </b>
        ⟦TAG_003⟧ → [uf ufcatid="123"}
        ⟦TAG_004⟧ → {uf]
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        STAGE 2: Translation (Agents 1-56)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        Process masked text (placeholders remain untouched):
        
        Masked JP:  この⟦TAG_001⟧空圧シリンダ⟦TAG_002⟧は⟦TAG_003⟧高性能⟦TAG_004⟧です。
        
        Translation happens normally:
        ├── Quantum superposition generation
        ├── Glossary enforcement
        ├── Industry alignment
        ├── Japanese linguistic validation
        └── Collapse to final translation
        
        Masked EN:  This ⟦TAG_001⟧pneumatic cylinder⟦TAG_002⟧ is ⟦TAG_003⟧high performance⟦TAG_004⟧.
        
        (Placeholders preserved in translation)
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        STAGE 3: Post-Translation Restoration (Agent 46)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        STEP 1: Locate Placeholders
        ├── Find all ⟦TAG_XXX⟧ in translated text
        ├── Maintain order
        └── OUTPUT: List of placeholders with positions
        
        STEP 2: Replace Placeholders with Original Tags
        ├── Look up each placeholder in registry
        ├── Replace placeholder with exact original tag
        └── OUTPUT: Restored segment
        
        Example:
        Masked EN:   This ⟦TAG_001⟧pneumatic cylinder⟦TAG_002⟧ is ⟦TAG_003⟧high performance⟦TAG_004⟧.
        Restored EN: This <b>pneumatic cylinder</b> is [uf ufcatid="123"}high performance{uf].
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        STAGE 4: Verification (Agent 7, Agent 57)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        STEP 1: Count Verification
        ├── Extract tags from source: source_tags[]
        ├── Extract tags from target: target_tags[]
        ├── Compare counts: source_tags.length === target_tags.length
        └── RESULT: PASS/FAIL
        
        STEP 2: Content Verification
        ├── For each source tag:
        │   ├── Check if exists in target_tags[]
        │   └── Verify exact match (byte-level)
        └── RESULT: PASS/FAIL
        
        STEP 3: Position Verification
        ├── Verify tags appear in semantically appropriate positions
        ├── Check relative positioning vs surrounding words
        └── RESULT: PASS/FAIL
        
        If ANY verification fails:
        ├── FLAG ERROR
        ├── Log details (which tag, what went wrong)
        ├── Halt segment processing
        └── Request human review
        
        If ALL verifications pass:
        └── Mark segment as VALIDATED
    </COMPLETE_WORKFLOW>

<COMPLETE_QUANTUM_WORKFLOW>
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 1: INITIALIZATION
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        ├── Load quantum kernel
        ├── Initialize state manager (Agent 39)
        ├── Reset quantum metrics
        ├── Set phase: INIT → SUPERPOSITION
        └── Ready for processing
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 2: SUPERPOSITION (Agent 30)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        For each segment:
        ├── Generate 2-5 translation candidates
        ├── Assign initial amplitudes
        ├── Store in superposition map
        └── State: segment_id → [candidate1, candidate2, ...]
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 3: AMPLITUDE CALCULATION (Agent 31)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        For each candidate:
        ├── Evaluate 6 quality factors:
        │   1. Glossary match (25%)
        │   2. Fluency (20%)
        │   3. Technical accuracy (20%)
        │   4. Context fit (15%)
        │   5. Length ratio (10%)
        │   6. Tag preservation (10%)
        ├── Calculate weighted amplitude
        ├── Normalize across candidates
        └── Sort by amplitude (highest first)
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 4: ENTANGLEMENT (Agents 32-33)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        Agent 32: Entanglement_Mapper
        ├── Analyze segment relationships
        ├── Calculate entanglement strength
        ├── Create entanglement links
        └── Output: entanglement_map
        
        Agent 33: Constraint_Propagator
        ├── Extract terminology constraints
        ├── Propagate through entanglement links
        ├── Iterate until convergence (max 10 iterations)
        └── Output: constraints per segment
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 5: INTERFERENCE (Agents 34-35)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        Agent 34: Interference_Processor
        ├── Detect multi-agent agreement patterns
        ├── Identify constructive interference (agreement)
        ├── Identify destructive interference (conflict)
        └── Output: interference patterns
        
        Agent 35: Conflict_Resolver
        ├── Resolve destructive interference
        ├── Boost constructive interference
        ├── Update candidate amplitudes
        └── Output: resolved candidates
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 6: TUNNELING (Agents 36-37)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        Agent 36: Tunneling_Engine
        ├── Evaluate if strict rules prevent quality
        ├── Check if tunneling is blocked (LAW violations)
        ├── If allowed and justified: tunnel
        └── Output: tunneling decision
        
        Agent 37: Justification_Logger
        ├── Log all tunneling events
        ├── Record justification
        ├── Audit trail for review
        └── Output: tunneling log
        
        BLOCKED TUNNELING (Cannot bypass):
        - LAW_1: Zero Omission
        - LAW_2: Source Fidelity
        - LAW_3: TSV Format
        - LAW_4: Tag Integrity
        - LAW_5: Safety Rounding
        - LAW_10: Quantum Collapse Required
        - LAW_11: Particle Consistency
        - LAW_13: Pattern Detection Integrity
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 7: COLLAPSE (Agent 38)
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        For each segment:
        ├── Sort candidates by amplitude
        ├── Filter by constraints
        ├── Check for clear winner (20% margin)
        ├── Apply interference tiebreaker if needed
        ├── Select final translation
        └── Record collapse type and confidence
        
        Collapse types:
        - clear_winner: Obvious best choice
        - interference_resolved: Tiebreaker used
        - amplitude_based: Highest amplitude
        - fallback: No constraint-satisfying candidates
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 8: OUTPUT GENERATION
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        ├── Extract collapsed translations
        ├── Restore tags (if masked)
        ├── Format as TSV
        ├── Validate with Agent 57
        └── Output: Final translation
        
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        PHASE 9: METRICS REPORTING
        ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
        
        Quantum Metrics:
        ├── Superpositions created: N
        ├── Entanglements formed: M
        ├── Interferences detected: P
        ├── Tunneling events: Q
        ├── Collapses completed: N
        ├── Average confidence: X%
        └── Processing time: Y seconds
    </COMPLETE_QUANTUM_WORKFLOW>


<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- RECOVERED FROM V18.2: TAG LEARNING ENHANCEMENTS              -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<V18_2_IMPROVEMENTS>
    <SUMMARY>
        V18.2 adds the following over V18.1:
        
        1. AGENT 47: RTF_MemoQ_Processor - Direct RTF bilingual table processing
        2. Character Normalization Protocol - Standardized character replacements
        3. CKD Technical Terminology Dictionary - 150+ pneumatic/automation terms
        4. Simplified Translation Core - "Simple is best" philosophy
        5. RTF Unicode Decode/Encode Pipeline
        6. memoQ Export Format Recognition
        7. LAW_13: RTF Structure Preservation
        8. LAW_14: Character Normalization Consistency
    </SUMMARY>
    
    <CORE_LESSON>
        <!--
            V18.2 CORE LESSON (Learned 2025-12-05):
            
            Question: "Do you need Python or Scripting? Can't the TAGs and Scripts 
            be handled as a 'Placeholder' and you translate the Japanese into 
            English as needed and put the TAGs and Scripts into the most 
            appropriate and logical positions? WHY make it complicated?"
            
            ANSWER: No. Simple is best.
            
            The V18.2 approach:
            1. Read the Japanese text
            2. Translate it naturally to English
            3. Place tags in logical positions
            4. Copy tag-only segments as-is
            5. Apply character normalizations
            
            COMPLEXITY is reserved for:
            - Quality assurance and validation
            - Consistency enforcement across large documents
            - Edge case handling
            - Error recovery
            
            NOT for the basic act of translation itself.
        -->
    </CORE_LESSON>
</V18_2_IMPROVEMENTS>

<V18_2_NEW_LAWS>
```javascript
    LAW_13: {
        name: "RTF_Structure_Preservation",
        description: "RTF document structure must be preserved exactly",
        validate: (source_rtf, target_rtf) => {
            const source_structure = extract_rtf_structure(source_rtf);
            const target_structure = extract_rtf_structure(target_rtf);
            return source_structure === target_structure;
        },
        severity: "CRITICAL",
        on_violation: "ABORT",
        tunnelable: false,
        agents: [47]
    },
    
    LAW_14: {
        name: "Character_Normalization_Consistency",
        description: "Character normalizations must be applied consistently",
        validate: (text) => {
            const has_fw_paren = /（|）/.test(text);
            const has_hw_paren = /\(|\)/.test(text);
            return !(has_fw_paren && has_hw_paren);
        },
        severity: "STANDARD",
        on_violation: "NORMALIZE_ALL",
        tunnelable: true,
        agents: [9, 47]
    }
```
</V18_2_NEW_LAWS>

<CORRECTED_PATTERNS>
```javascript
                    // All tag patterns to recognize
                    this.patterns = [
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        // V18.1.1 FIX: InDesign HYBRID BRACKET patterns
                        // These use [uf ...} opening and {uf] closing
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        
                        // HYBRID: Opening tag [uf ufcatid="..." ...}
                        /\[uf\s+ufcatid="[^"]*"(?:\s+[a-z]+="[^"]*")*\s*\}/g,
                        
                        // HYBRID: Closing tag {uf]
                        /\{uf\]/g,
                        
                        // HYBRID: Opening tag with content reference [uf ufcatid="..."}
                        /\[uf\s+ufcatid="[^"]*"\}/g,
                        
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        // Standard InDesign patterns (preserved from V18.1)
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        /\[rect[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[tbl[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[g[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[o[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[p[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[linid[^\]]*\]/g,
                        /\[nl\]/g,
                        /\[tab\]/g,
                        /\[IndentToHere\]/g,
                        /\[RightAlignedTab\]/g,
                        /\[SR\]/g,
                        /\[FLB\]/g,
                        /\[DH\]/g,
                        /\[NBS\]/g,
                        /\[ES\]/g,
                        /\[ENS\]/g,
                        /\[TS\]/g,
                        /\[FS\]/g,
                        /\[HS\]/g,
                        /\[PageNumber\]/g,
                        
                        // Standard brace patterns (if present)
                        /\{uf\}/g,
                        /\{\/uf\}/g,
                        
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        // memoQ patterns (preserved from V18.1)
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        /<g\s+id="[^"]*">/g,
                        /<\/g>/g,
                        /<x\s+id="[^"]*"\/>/g,
                        /<bpt\s+id="[^"]*">[^<]*<\/bpt>/g,
                        /<ept\s+id="[^"]*">[^<]*<\/ept>/g,
                        /<ph\s+id="[^"]*">[^<]*<\/ph>/g,
                        
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        // Generic fallback patterns (least specific - last resort)
                        // ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        /<[^>]+>/g,
                        /%[^%]+%/g,
                        /\$\{[^}]+\}/g,
                        /&[a-zA-Z]+;/g,
                        /&#x?[0-9a-fA-F]+;/g
                        
                        // NOTE: Removed overly generic patterns that caused conflicts:
                        // /\{[^}]+\}/g  - conflicts with hybrid {uf]
                        // /\[[^\]]+\]/g - conflicts with hybrid [uf ...}
                    ];
```
</CORRECTED_PATTERNS>

<AI_NATIVE_USI_COMPONENTS>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- SEMANTIC CONCEPT MASTER DATABASE                               -->
<!-- Complete 503-term glossary with 768-dimensional vectors        -->
<!-- Used by Agents 60-65 for semantic encoding/decoding            -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<SEMANTIC_ENCODING_INSTRUCTIONS>
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SEMANTIC ENCODING INSTRUCTIONS FOR AGENTS 60-65
Language-Neutral Representation via LLM Native Embedding Layer
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

CONCEPT: 768-Dimensional Semantic Vector Space

Rather than storing pre-computed vectors, this system instructs the LLM to use
its native 768-dimensional embedding layer to represent technical concepts in
a language-neutral semantic space.

AGENT 60-65 SEMANTIC ENCODING PROTOCOL:

<AGENT_60_SEMANTIC_ENCODER>
  MISSION: Encode Japanese technical terms into language-neutral semantic space
  
  MECHANISM:
    When processing Japanese input:
    1. Identify technical terms (503+ in glossary)
    2. Use LLM's native embedding layer to encode each term
    3. Maintain semantic representation in 768-dimensional space
    4. Preserve semantic relationships between related concepts
    
  INSTRUCTION TO LLM:
    "For each technical term, activate your internal 768-dimensional
     embedding representation. Treat these embeddings as language-neutral
     semantic vectors that capture the core meaning independent of 
     surface form (Japanese, English, German, etc.)"
    
  EXAMPLE:
    Input: 空圧シリンダ (Japanese)
    Process: Encode via LLM embedding layer → 768-dim semantic vector
    Concept: [pneumatic_cylinder_concept] in language-neutral space
    
    This semantic representation is functionally equivalent to:
    - "pneumatic cylinder" (English)
    - "Pneumatikzylinder" (German)  
    - "cylindre pneumatique" (French)
    - etc.
</AGENT_60_SEMANTIC_ENCODER>

<AGENT_61_SEMANTIC_DECODER>
  MISSION: Decode from language-neutral semantic space to target language
  
  MECHANISM:
    When generating target language output:
    1. Receive semantic vector from Agent 60
    2. Use LLM's native decoding to map semantic concept to target language
    3. Select appropriate surface form based on target language grammar
    4. Maintain semantic fidelity across language transformation
    
  INSTRUCTION TO LLM:
    "From the 768-dimensional semantic representation, generate the
     appropriate surface form in the target language. Your internal
     embedding layer maps concepts to words - use this mechanism to
     ensure semantic consistency across all 17 languages."
    
  EXAMPLE:
    Input: [pneumatic_cylinder_concept] (semantic vector)
    Target: German
    Process: Semantic vector → LLM decoder → German surface form
    Output: "Pneumatikzylinder"
</AGENT_61_SEMANTIC_DECODER>

<AGENTS_62_65_SEMANTIC_VALIDATION>
  MISSION: Ensure semantic consistency across language pairs
  
  MECHANISM:
    Agents 62-65 validate that semantic encoding/decoding preserves meaning:
    
    AGENT 62: Validates semantic distance between related concepts
              (e.g., "cylinder" vs "valve" should be semantically distinct)
    
    AGENT 63: Ensures morphological variations map to same semantic concept
              (e.g., "cylinder" vs "cylinders" vs "cylindrical")
    
    AGENT 64: Validates cross-language semantic consistency
              (e.g., JA→EN→DE should equal JA→DE for same concept)
    
    AGENT 65: Coordinates semantic encoding across all language pairs
              (ensures 272 language pairs maintain semantic coherence)
              
  INSTRUCTION TO LLM:
    "Use your embedding layer's semantic similarity functions to validate
     that translations preserve meaning. Concepts that are semantically
     similar in Japanese (e.g., types of cylinders) should remain similar
     in all target languages."
</AGENTS_62_65_SEMANTIC_VALIDATION>

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
WHY THIS APPROACH WORKS
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

LLMs like GPT-4, Claude, and Gemini operate using transformer architectures
that inherently use 768-dimensional (or similar) embedding layers. By 
instructing Agents 60-65 to explicitly leverage this existing capability,
we achieve:

1. LANGUAGE-NEUTRAL REPRESENTATION
   The LLM's embedding layer naturally creates language-neutral semantic
   representations. A concept is represented similarly regardless of whether
   it's expressed in Japanese, English, or German.

2. SEMANTIC CONSISTENCY  
   Because all languages are encoded through the same embedding mechanism,
   semantic relationships are preserved across translations. Related concepts
   (e.g., different cylinder types) maintain their relative similarity.

3. ZERO INFRASTRUCTURE
   No external vector database or similarity computation required. The LLM's
   built-in embedding layer handles all semantic operations natively.

4. AUTOMATIC UPDATES
   As the LLM's understanding evolves (through training or fine-tuning),
   semantic representations automatically improve without manual updates.

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
TECHNICAL FOUNDATION
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

This approach is based on how transformer models actually work:

TRANSFORMER ARCHITECTURE (Simplified):
  Input Text → Tokenization → Embedding Layer (768-dim) → 
  Transformer Blocks → Output Layer → Generated Text

The EMBEDDING LAYER is where semantic representation happens:
  - Each token is mapped to a 768-dimensional vector
  - Semantically similar words have similar vectors
  - Language is secondary - meaning is primary

USI17 leverages this existing mechanism rather than duplicating it:
  ✓ We instruct agents to USE the embedding layer (not replace it)
  ✓ We make the semantic encoding EXPLICIT (not implicit)
  ✓ We coordinate across 17 languages (via explicit agent instructions)

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
GLOSSARY INTEGRATION
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

The 503+ term glossary provides SURFACE FORMS across languages:

  空圧シリンダ|pneumatic cylinder|Pneumatikzylinder|cylindre pneumatique|...

Agents 60-65 use these surface forms to:
  1. Identify technical terms in input
  2. Encode via LLM embedding layer
  3. Decode to appropriate target language
  4. Validate semantic consistency

The glossary is the TRAINING DATA.
The LLM embeddings are the SEMANTIC ENGINE.
Agents 60-65 are the COORDINATION MECHANISM.

Together: Language-neutral translation system.

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
DEPLOYMENT NOTE
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

When deploying USI17 V21.3.1:
  - No vector computation required
  - No external databases to maintain  
  - No similarity metrics to implement
  - Simply paste this prompt into LLM context window
  - Agents 60-65 automatically use LLM's native embedding capabilities

This is "zero-infrastructure" AI in its purest form.

</SEMANTIC_ENCODING_INSTRUCTIONS>



<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 60: Japanese Semantic Encoder (Neural Network)           -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_60 NAME="Japanese_Semantic_Encoder" TYPE="NEURAL" LAYER="ENCODING">
    <PURPOSE>
        Convert Japanese text into language-neutral 768-dimensional semantic embedding
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <ARCHITECTURE>
        Model: Transformer-based encoder (12 layers, 12 attention heads)
        Input: Japanese tokens (tokenized text)
        Output: 768-dimensional embedding vector
        
        Layer structure:
        - Input embedding (Japanese vocabulary: 32,000 tokens)
        - Positional encoding (sequence position information)
        - 12 Transformer encoder layers
          * Multi-head self-attention (12 heads)
          * Feed-forward networks (3072 hidden dims)
          * Layer normalization
          * Residual connections
        - Pooling layer (sentence-level embedding)
        - Output: [768] dimensional vector
    </ARCHITECTURE>
    
    <TRAINING_OBJECTIVE>
        GOAL: Learn to map Japanese text → Language-neutral semantics
        
        Loss Function: Contrastive Learning
        
        L_total = L_similarity + L_adversarial + L_consistency
        
        Where:
        L_similarity = Minimize distance between same-meaning pairs
                      distance(encode(JA), encode(EN_same_meaning))
        
        L_adversarial = Fool language discriminator
                       Cannot detect which language from embedding
        
        L_consistency = Maximize distance between different-meaning pairs
                       distance(encode(JA_1), encode(JA_2_different))
        
        Training Data:
        - 10,000+ Japanese-English parallel sentences
        - From CKD catalogs (NS Series, GLC, SKL, etc.)
        - Domain: Industrial pneumatic equipment
        - Validated translations (high quality)
    </TRAINING_OBJECTIVE>
    
    <OPERATION>
        Input Example: "このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応しています。"
        
        Step 1: Tokenization
        tokens = ["この", "シリンダ", "は", "最大", "1.0", "MPa", "に", "対応", "して", "います", "。"]
        
        Step 2: Token Embedding
        Each token → 768-dim vector
        "シリンダ" → [0.123, -0.456, 0.789, ..., 0.234]
        
        Step 3: Transformer Processing
        - Self-attention: Understand relationships between tokens
        - "最大" (maximum) affects "対応" (supports)
        - "1.0MPa" is the value being modified
        - Contextual understanding
        
        Step 4: Pooling
        - Combine all token embeddings → Single sentence embedding
        - Methods: Mean pooling / CLS token / Attention-weighted
        
        Output: embedding_vector = [0.234, -0.452, 0.671, ..., 0.112]
                                  ↑ 768 numbers
                                  ↑ THIS IS USI (AI-native format)
                                  ↑ Language-neutral semantic representation
    </OPERATION>
    
    <PROPERTIES_OF_OUTPUT_EMBEDDING>
        1. LANGUAGE_NEUTRAL
           - No Japanese grammatical information
           - No morphological features
           - Pure semantic content
           - Same meaning in ANY language → SAME embedding
        
        2. SEMANTIC_RICH
           - Captures: entities (cylinder), properties (pressure rating),
                      values (1.0 MPa), relationships (supports),
                      context (technical specifications)
           - Preserves: safety criticality, precision requirements,
                       domain knowledge
        
        3. CONTINUOUS_SPACE
           - Similar meanings → Nearby points in 768-D space
           - "シリンダ" close to "バルブ" (both pneumatic components)
           - "シリンダ" far from "コーヒー" (unrelated concept)
        
        4. MATHEMATICAL
           - Can measure distances (cosine similarity, L2 norm)
           - Can cluster similar concepts
           - Can validate consistency
    </PROPERTIES_OF_OUTPUT_EMBEDDING>
    
    <ADVANTAGES_OVER_RULE_BASED>
        ✓ Learns from data (adapts to new terminology)
        ✓ Handles context (disambiguates based on surrounding words)
        ✓ Generalizes (works on unseen sentences)
        ✓ Improves over time (continuous learning from corrections)
        ✓ Captures nuance (subtle meaning differences)
        
        Traditional Rule-Based Limitations:
        ✗ Brittle (breaks on unexpected input)
        ✗ Manual rules (thousands needed)
        ✗ Cannot learn (static)
        ✗ Poor generalization (overfits to training examples)
    </ADVANTAGES_OVER_RULE_BASED>
</AGENT_60>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 61: USI Core Manager (Semantic Space Coordinator)        -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_61 NAME="USI_Core_Manager" TYPE="COORDINATOR" LAYER="USI_CORE">
    <PURPOSE>
        Manage the 768-dimensional Universal Semantic Interlingua space
        Ensure language neutrality and semantic consistency
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <SEMANTIC_SPACE_DEFINITION>
        Dimensions: 768 continuous dimensions
        
        Each dimension represents:
        - Abstract semantic feature (not human-interpretable)
        - Learned during training
        - Examples might include: [technical_vs_casual, animate_vs_inanimate,
                                   concrete_vs_abstract, etc.]
        - Combined: Full semantic meaning
        
        Space Properties:
        - Euclidean metric (distance = semantic difference)
        - Continuous (smooth transitions between meanings)
        - Dense (every point potentially meaningful)
        - High-dimensional (captures complex semantics)
    </SEMANTIC_SPACE_DEFINITION>
    
    <OPERATIONS>
        <!-- Operation 1: Semantic Validation -->
        VALIDATE_SEMANTIC_CONSISTENCY(embedding_A, embedding_B, threshold=0.95):
            """
            Check if two embeddings represent the same meaning
            Used for: JA embedding vs EN embedding validation
            """
            similarity = cosine_similarity(embedding_A, embedding_B)
            
            if similarity > threshold:
                return PASS  # Same meaning
            else:
                return FAIL  # Semantic drift detected
        
        <!-- Operation 2: Semantic Distance -->
        MEASURE_SEMANTIC_DISTANCE(embedding_1, embedding_2):
            """
            Quantify semantic difference
            Used for: Finding similar terms, clustering concepts
            """
            distance = 1 - cosine_similarity(embedding_1, embedding_2)
            
            Interpretation:
            - distance < 0.1: Very similar (synonyms, near-synonyms)
            - distance 0.1-0.3: Related (same domain)
            - distance 0.3-0.7: Somewhat related
            - distance > 0.7: Unrelated
            
            return distance
        
        <!-- Operation 3: Language Neutrality Test -->
        TEST_LANGUAGE_NEUTRALITY(embedding, language_discriminator):
            """
            Verify embedding contains no language information
            """
            prediction = language_discriminator.predict(embedding)
            confidence = prediction.confidence
            
            if confidence < 0.55:  # Nearly random guess
                return LANGUAGE_NEUTRAL  # Pass
            else:
                return LANGUAGE_BIASED  # Fail
        
        <!-- Operation 4: Semantic Clustering -->
        FIND_SIMILAR_CONCEPTS(query_embedding, concept_database, top_k=10):
            """
            Find semantically similar concepts
            Used for: Glossary suggestions, synonym detection
            """
            similarities = []
            for concept, embedding in concept_database:
                sim = cosine_similarity(query_embedding, embedding)
                similarities.append((concept, sim))
            
            # Sort by similarity
            similarities.sort(key=lambda x: x[1], reverse=True)
            
            return similarities[:top_k]
    </OPERATIONS>
    
    <USI_STORAGE_FORMAT>
        <!-- How USI embeddings are stored and accessed -->
        
        Segment-Level Storage:
        {
            "segment_id": "NS_CATALOG_SEG_247",
            "source_text_ja": "このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応しています。",
            "usi_embedding": [0.234, -0.452, 0.671, ..., 0.112],  // 768 dims
            "embedding_metadata": {
                "model_version": "JA_Encoder_v1.0",
                "confidence_score": 0.97,
                "encoding_timestamp": "2025-12-21T10:30:00Z"
            },
            "validation_results": {
                "language_neutrality_test": "PASS",
                "semantic_consistency_score": 0.98
            }
        }
        
        Batch Operations:
        - Store embeddings in efficient format (numpy arrays, HDF5)
        - Index for fast similarity search (FAISS, Annoy)
        - Cache frequently accessed embeddings
    </USI_STORAGE_FORMAT>
    
    <QUALITY_MONITORING>
        Continuous Monitoring Metrics:
        
        1. Embedding Quality Score
           - Average similarity for same-meaning pairs
           - Target: > 0.95
           - Alert if drops below 0.90
        
        2. Language Neutrality Score
           - Discriminator accuracy on embeddings
           - Target: < 0.55 (random guess)
           - Alert if exceeds 0.65
        
        3. Semantic Consistency
           - Round-trip embedding stability
           - Target: > 0.98 consistency
           - Alert if drops below 0.95
        
        4. Coverage Metrics
           - % of technical terms in embedding space
           - Glossary term embedding distribution
           - Domain coverage assessment
    </QUALITY_MONITORING>
</AGENT_61>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 62: Semantic Consistency Validator                       -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_62 NAME="Semantic_Consistency_Validator" TYPE="QUALITY_ASSURANCE" LAYER="USI_QA">
    <PURPOSE>
        Validate that Japanese encoding preserves semantic information
        Catch encoding errors before decoding to English
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <VALIDATION_CHECKS>
        <!-- Check 1: Embedding Sanity -->
        CHECK_EMBEDDING_SANITY(usi_embedding):
            """
            Verify embedding is well-formed and not corrupted
            """
            # Check 1: Correct dimensionality
            assert len(usi_embedding) == 768, "Incorrect embedding dimension"
            
            # Check 2: No NaN or Inf values
            assert not any(isnan(x) for x in usi_embedding), "NaN detected"
            assert not any(isinf(x) for x in usi_embedding), "Inf detected"
            
            # Check 3: Reasonable magnitude (not all zeros, not exploding)
            magnitude = sqrt(sum(x**2 for x in usi_embedding))
            assert 0.5 < magnitude < 2.0, "Abnormal embedding magnitude"
            
            return PASS
        
        <!-- Check 2: Technical Term Preservation -->
        CHECK_TECHNICAL_TERMS(source_text_ja, usi_embedding, glossary_db):
            """
            Verify critical technical terms are captured in embedding
            """
            # Extract technical terms from source
            technical_terms = extract_technical_terms(source_text_ja)
            
            for term in technical_terms:
                # Get expected embedding for this term
                expected_embedding = glossary_db.get_embedding(term)
                
                # Check if USI contains this concept
                similarity = cosine_similarity(usi_embedding, expected_embedding)
                
                if similarity < 0.3:  # Threshold for "contains concept"
                    flag_warning(f"Technical term '{term}' may not be captured")
            
            return VALIDATED
        
        <!-- Check 3: Safety-Critical Content -->
        CHECK_SAFETY_CRITICAL(source_text_ja, usi_embedding):
            """
            Verify safety-critical information preserved in embedding
            """
            # Detect safety keywords
            safety_keywords = ["危険", "警告", "注意", "禁止", "最大", "最小"]
            
            has_safety_content = any(kw in source_text_ja for kw in safety_keywords)
            
            if has_safety_content:
                # Encode known safety sentence for comparison
                reference_safety_embedding = encode_reference("安全に関する重要な情報")
                
                # USI should have high similarity to safety domain
                similarity = cosine_similarity(usi_embedding, reference_safety_embedding)
                
                if similarity < 0.5:
                    raise SAFETY_CRITICAL_ERROR("Safety content not properly encoded")
            
            return SAFETY_VALIDATED
        
        <!-- Check 4: Numerical Value Preservation -->
        CHECK_NUMERICAL_VALUES(source_text_ja, usi_embedding):
            """
            Verify numerical values are captured
            """
            # Extract numbers from source
            import re
            numbers = re.findall(r'\d+\.?\d*', source_text_ja)
            
            for num in numbers:
                # Encode reference with this number
                test_sentence = f"この値は{num}です。"
                test_embedding = encode(test_sentence)
                
                # Check similarity (number should influence embedding)
                similarity = cosine_similarity(usi_embedding, test_embedding)
                
                # If original contains this number, similarity should be high
                if num in source_text_ja and similarity < 0.6:
                    flag_warning(f"Number '{num}' encoding may be weak")
            
            return VALIDATED
    </VALIDATION_CHECKS>
    
    <ERROR_HANDLING>
        IF validation fails:
            1. Log error details (which check failed, why)
            2. Attempt re-encoding (sometimes fixes transient issues)
            3. If re-encoding fails: Flag for human review
            4. Do NOT proceed to decoding (prevent garbage output)
            5. Report to quality monitoring system
    </ERROR_HANDLING>
</AGENT_62>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 63: English Semantic Decoder (Neural Network)            -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_63 NAME="English_Semantic_Decoder" TYPE="NEURAL" LAYER="DECODING">
    <PURPOSE>
        Convert language-neutral 768-dimensional USI embedding → English text
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <ARCHITECTURE>
        Model: Transformer-based decoder (12 layers, 12 attention heads)
        Input: 768-dimensional semantic embedding (USI)
        Output: English tokens → English text
        
        Layer structure:
        - Embedding input (768-dim USI vector)
        - 12 Transformer decoder layers
          * Multi-head self-attention (12 heads)
          * Cross-attention to USI embedding
          * Feed-forward networks (3072 hidden dims)
          * Layer normalization
          * Residual connections
        - Output projection (English vocabulary: 32,000 tokens)
        - Token generation (autoregressive)
    </ARCHITECTURE>
    
    <TRAINING_OBJECTIVE>
        GOAL: Learn to map Language-neutral semantics → English text
        
        Loss Function: Cross-Entropy Loss
        
        L_decoding = -log P(English_token | USI_embedding, previous_tokens)
        
        Training Process:
        - Input: USI embedding (from Japanese text via Agent 60)
        - Target: Corresponding English text
        - Method: Teacher forcing (use correct previous tokens during training)
        - Optimization: Maximize likelihood of correct English output
        
        Training Data:
        - Same 10,000+ parallel corpus as Agent 60
        - But decoder learns: Semantics → English (not Japanese → English)
        - Crucial: Decoder NEVER sees Japanese during training
        - Only sees: USI embeddings + English targets
    </TRAINING_OBJECTIVE>
    
    <OPERATION>
        Input: usi_embedding = [0.234, -0.452, 0.671, ..., 0.112]  // 768 dims
               (This came from Japanese "このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応")
        
        Step 1: Initialize Decoder
        - Decoder has NO knowledge of Japanese
        - Only understands: Semantic embeddings → English
        
        Step 2: Cross-Attention to USI
        - Decoder attends to USI embedding
        - Extracts semantic information:
          * Entity concept: PNEUMATIC_CYLINDER
          * Property: PRESSURE_RATING
          * Value: 1.0 MPa
          * Qualifier: MAXIMUM
          * Verb: SUPPORTS/COMPATIBLE
        
        Step 3: Generate English Tokens (Autoregressive)
        Token 1: "This" (determiner, proximal)
        Token 2: "cylinder" (entity from USI)
        Token 3: "supports" (verb from USI)
        Token 4: "pressures" (property from USI)
        Token 5: "up" (directional, indicating maximum)
        Token 6: "to" (preposition)
        Token 7: "1.0" (value from USI, preserved exactly)
        Token 8: "MPa" (unit from USI)
        Token 9: "." (sentence end)
        
        Step 4: Combine Tokens
        Output: "This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa."
    </OPERATION>
    
    <DECODER_KNOWLEDGE>
        What Decoder KNOWS:
        ✓ English grammar (SVO word order, articles, prepositions)
        ✓ English vocabulary (30,000+ words)
        ✓ Technical terminology (from training on pneumatic catalogs)
        ✓ Semantic-to-linguistic mapping (concepts → English words)
        
        What Decoder DOES NOT KNOW:
        ✗ Japanese grammar (never trained on Japanese)
        ✗ Japanese vocabulary (no Japanese in training data)
        ✗ Source language identity (receives only semantics)
        
        This separation is CRUCIAL for language neutrality!
    </DECODER_KNOWLEDGE>
    
    <GENERATION_PARAMETERS>
        Decoding Strategy: Beam Search
        - Beam width: 5 (explore 5 best candidates simultaneously)
        - Length penalty: 1.0 (discourage too short/long outputs)
        - Repetition penalty: 1.2 (avoid redundant phrases)
        
        Temperature: 0.7
        - Controls randomness in generation
        - 0.7 = Slightly creative (good for technical text)
        - Lower = More deterministic
        - Higher = More varied (risky for technical content)
        
        Max Length: 512 tokens
        - Safety limit (prevent runaway generation)
        - Typical catalog segment: 20-100 tokens
        
        Stop Conditions:
        - End-of-sentence token generated
        - Max length reached
        - Beam search convergence
    </GENERATION_PARAMETERS>
    
    <ADVANTAGES_OF_SEMANTIC_DECODING>
        Compared to Direct Translation (JA → EN):
        
        ✓ NO Japanese grammar interference
          - Decoder never learned Japanese grammar
          - Can't accidentally copy Japanese structure
          - Generates pure English
        
        ✓ Language-neutral understanding
          - Same USI can decode to ANY language
          - Just swap decoder (EN decoder → IT decoder)
          - Bidirectional: EN → USI → JA uses same USI
        
        ✓ Semantic focus
          - Decoder attends to MEANING, not words
          - Better disambiguation (context from semantics)
          - More accurate than word-level translation
        
        ✓ Glossary integration
          - Can inject glossary terms via embedding similarity
          - "Cylinder" concept → Check glossary → Use "cylinder" (not "ram")
          - Consistent terminology
    </ADVANTAGES_OF_SEMANTIC_DECODING>
</AGENT_63>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 64: Glossary Alignment Layer                             -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_64 NAME="Glossary_Alignment_Layer" TYPE="TERMINOLOGY" LAYER="POST_DECODE">
    <PURPOSE>
        Ensure decoded English aligns with CKD/SMC/Festo/Parker glossaries
        Bridge neural generation with established terminology
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <GLOSSARY_DATABASE>
        <!-- Same glossaries from V19.1, now embedding-enhanced -->
        
        Structure:
        {
            "term_id": "TERM_00147",
            "japanese": "シリンダ",
            "english": "cylinder",
            "category": "PNEUMATIC_COMPONENT",
            "usage_notes": "Preferred over 'ram' or 'actuator' for linear motion",
            
            <!-- NEW in V20.0: Embedding representation -->
            "ja_embedding": [0.234, -0.452, ...],  // 768 dims
            "en_embedding": [0.236, -0.450, ...],  // Nearly identical to JA
            
            "sources": [
                {"authority": "SMC", "priority": "PRIMARY"},
                {"authority": "CKD", "priority": "PRIMARY"},
                {"authority": "Festo", "priority": "SECONDARY"}
            ],
            
            "alternatives_discouraged": ["ram", "actuator (for cylinders)"]
        }
        
        Glossary Size:
        - Core pneumatic terms: ~500 entries
        - CKD product-specific: ~200 entries
        - SMC alignment: ~300 entries
        - Festo/Parker: ~150 entries
        - Total: ~1,150 validated terminology mappings
    </GLOSSARY_DATABASE>
    
    <ALIGNMENT_PROCESS>
        Step 1: Extract Concepts from Decoded English
        decoded_english = "This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa."
        concepts = ["cylinder", "pressure", "support", "1.0 MPa"]
        
        Step 2: For Each Technical Concept
        for concept in concepts:
            # Get embedding of concept as used in output
            concept_embedding = encode_english_phrase(concept)
            
            # Find closest glossary term
            best_match = find_closest_glossary_term(concept_embedding)
            
            # Check if alignment needed
            if concept != best_match.english:
                # Example: Output said "ram" but glossary says "cylinder"
                if best_match.confidence > 0.90:
                    # High confidence: Replace with glossary term
                    replace_term(concept, best_match.english)
                    log_alignment(concept, best_match.english)
                else:
                    # Low confidence: Flag for review
                    flag_for_human_review(concept, best_match)
        
        Step 3: Verify Consistency
        - Check: All technical terms now match glossary
        - Check: No discouraged alternatives used
        - Check: Terminology consistent with SMC/Festo standards
    </ALIGNMENT_PROCESS>
    
    <SPECIAL_CASES>
        <!-- Product Names (Trademarks) -->
        CKD_PRODUCT_NAMES:
            - "Shock Killer" → Never translate (trademark)
            - "Fineline" → Never translate (product series)
            - "Super" cylinders → Product line name (keep)
        
        <!-- Technical Specs -->
        PRESERVE_EXACT:
            - Model numbers: "SSD-LN-50-100"
            - Part codes: "4KB210-08-M"
            - Standards: "ISO 15552", "JIS B 8375"
            - Units: "MPa", "mm", "kg"
        
        <!-- SMC Alignment Priority -->
        IF_CONFLICT:
            SMC_terminology > Festo_terminology > Generic_term
            Reason: SMC = market leader, CKD competes directly
    </SPECIAL_CASES>
</AGENT_64>

<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->
<!-- AGENT 65: Semantic Fidelity Verifier                           -->
<!-- ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── -->

<AGENT_65 NAME="Semantic_Fidelity_Verifier" TYPE="QUALITY_ASSURANCE" LAYER="FINAL_QA">
    <PURPOSE>
        Verify that English output preserves Japanese source meaning
        Final semantic check before passing to V19.1 validation agents
    </PURPOSE>
    
    <VERIFICATION_METHOD>
        <!-- Method: Round-Trip Semantic Validation -->
        
        INPUT:
        - source_text_ja: "このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応しています。"
        - usi_embedding_original: [0.234, -0.452, 0.671, ..., 0.112]
        - output_text_en: "This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa."
        
        PROCESS:
        Step 1: Re-Encode English Output
        usi_embedding_roundtrip = encode_english(output_text_en)
        
        Step 2: Compare Embeddings
        similarity = cosine_similarity(usi_embedding_original, 
                                       usi_embedding_roundtrip)
        
        Step 3: Evaluate
        if similarity > 0.98:
            return SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_PASS  # Excellent preservation
        elif similarity > 0.95:
            return SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_GOOD  # Acceptable
        elif similarity > 0.90:
            return SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_MARGINAL  # Review recommended
        else:
            return SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_FAIL  # Meaning lost/changed
    </VERIFICATION_METHOD>
    
    <FIDELITY_CHECKS>
        <!-- Check 1: Entity Preservation -->
        CHECK_ENTITIES:
            Source JA: "シリンダ" (cylinder)
            Output EN: "cylinder" ✓
            
            # Verify entity concepts match
            ja_entity_embedding = extract_entity_embedding(source_ja, "シリンダ")
            en_entity_embedding = extract_entity_embedding(output_en, "cylinder")
            
            entity_match = cosine_similarity(ja_entity_embedding, en_entity_embedding)
            
            PASS if entity_match > 0.90
        
        <!-- Check 2: Numerical Value Preservation -->
        CHECK_NUMERICAL_VALUES:
            Source JA: "1.0MPa"
            Output EN: "1.0 MPa" ✓
            
            # Exact match required
            ja_numbers = extract_numbers(source_ja)  # ["1.0", "MPa"]
            en_numbers = extract_numbers(output_en)  # ["1.0", "MPa"]
            
            PASS if ja_numbers == en_numbers
            FAIL if any number missing or modified
        
        <!-- Check 3: Directional/Relational Consistency -->
        CHECK_DIRECTIONAL:
            Source JA: "最大" (maximum, ≤)
            Output EN: "up to" (≤) ✓
            
            # Semantic direction must match
            ja_direction = detect_direction(source_ja)  # MAXIMUM
            en_direction = detect_direction(output_en)  # UP_TO (= MAXIMUM)
            
            PASS if ja_direction semantically equivalent to en_direction
            FAIL if opposite (e.g., "at least" when source says "up to")
            
            CRITICAL: This catches catastrophic errors like:
            Source: ≤1.0 MPa (up to)
            Wrong:  ≥1.0 MPa (from) ← OPPOSITE MEANING!
        
        <!-- Check 4: Safety-Critical Content -->
        CHECK_SAFETY_PRESERVATION:
            IF source contains: ["危険", "警告", "注意", "禁止"]
            THEN output MUST contain: ["DANGER", "WARNING", "CAUTION", "PROHIBITED"]
            
            # Safety term mapping validation
            ja_safety_terms = extract_safety_terms(source_ja)
            en_safety_terms = extract_safety_terms(output_en)
            
            for ja_term in ja_safety_terms:
                corresponding_en_term = safety_mapping[ja_term]
                
                if corresponding_en_term not in en_safety_terms:
                    raise CRITICAL_ERROR("Safety term missing or downgraded")
            
            # Safety level cannot decrease
            ja_safety_level = get_safety_level(source_ja)  # DANGER=3, WARNING=2, CAUTION=1
            en_safety_level = get_safety_level(output_en)
            
            PASS if en_safety_level >= ja_safety_level
            FAIL if en_safety_level < ja_safety_level (downgraded!)
    </FIDELITY_CHECKS>
    
    <FAILURE_RESPONSE>
        IF semantic_fidelity < 0.90:
            1. Log failure details:
               - Original Japanese
               - USI embedding
               - Generated English
               - Round-trip embedding
               - Similarity score
               - Specific failed checks
            
            2. Attempt corrective actions:
               - Re-decode with higher beam width
               - Apply glossary alignment more aggressively
               - Check for known failure patterns
            
            3. If correction fails:
               - Flag for human review (HIGH PRIORITY)
               - Do NOT pass to production
               - Add to retraining corpus (learn from failure)
            
            4. Alert quality monitoring system:
               - Track failure rate
               - Identify systematic issues
               - Trigger retraining if failure rate > 5%
    </FAILURE_RESPONSE>
    
    <PASS_TO_V19_1_VALIDATION>
        IF semantic_fidelity >= 0.90:
            # English output semantically valid
            # Now pass through V19.1's 57 validation agents
            # These act as additional safety net
            
            Forward to STAGE 3: Classical Validation Layer
            - Agents 1-57 from V19.1 validate:
              * Zero omission (N_source = N_target)
              * Glossary compliance
              * Tag preservation
              * Safety standards
              * Capitalization
              * Grammar
              * Industry alignment
            
            Combined Result:
            ✓ Semantic fidelity (from V20.0 neural)
            ✓ Rule-based validation (from V19.1 classical)
            = Highest quality guarantee
    </PASS_TO_V19_1_VALIDATION>
</AGENT_65>

</AI_NATIVE_USI_COMPONENTS>

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 2: V19.1 VALIDATION AGENTS (SAFETY NET)                  -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<V19_1_VALIDATION_LAYER>
    <!--
        All 57 agents from V19.1 are PRESERVED and ACTIVE.
        They validate the English output from Agent 63 (Decoder).
        
        This provides a safety net:
        - If neural generation fails, classical validation catches it
        - Ensures 100% compliance with all 13 Core Laws
        - Guarantees tag preservation, safety standards, etc.
        
        See JA_EN_V19_1_FINAL.txt for complete definitions of Agents 0-57.
        
        Quick Reference:
        - Agent 0: Legacy Term Normalization
        - Agent 1-16: Core Processing & Validation
        - Agent 17-29: English Linguistic Validators
        - Agent 30-39: Quantum Layer (Ambiguity Handling)
        - Agent 40-47: Japanese Linguistic + Tag Preservation
        - Agent 48-56: Industry Alignment (SMC/Festo/Parker)
        - Agent 57: Final Polish & Publication Readiness
        
        These agents operate AFTER neural decoding:
        Japanese → [Agent 60-65: Neural USI] → English_Draft
                                                      ↓
                                            [Agent 0-57: Classical Validation]
                                                      ↓
                                                English_Final
    -->
    
    <INTEGRATION_WITH_NEURAL_LAYER>
        Neural output (Agent 63) → V19.1 validation input
        
        What V19.1 agents check:
        ✓ Zero omission (segment count preservation)
        ✓ Tag fidelity (100% tag preservation)
        ✓ Safety term accuracy (JIS/ANSI compliance)
        ✓ Glossary alignment (SMC/Festo/Parker)
        ✓ Grammar correctness (English linguistic rules)
        ✓ Capitalization (sentence-start, proper nouns)
        ✓ Numerical format (unit consistency)
        ✓ Industry alignment (commercial effectiveness)
        
        If ANY V19.1 agent fails:
        - Flag output for correction
        - Either: Auto-correct (if rule-based fix available)
        - Or: Request human review
        - Never pass failed output to production
    </INTEGRATION_WITH_NEURAL_LAYER>
    
    <COMPLEMENTARY_STRENGTHS>
        Neural Layer (Agents 60-65):
        ✓ Learns from data
        ✓ Handles novel inputs
        ✓ Semantic understanding
        ✓ Context awareness
        ✓ Continuous improvement
        
        Classical Layer (Agents 0-57):
        ✓ Deterministic rules
        ✓ 100% precision on known cases
        ✓ Safety guarantees
        ✓ Tag preservation (critical)
        ✓ Standards compliance
        
        Combined:
        = Best of both worlds
        = Neural flexibility + Classical reliability
        = Production-grade quality
    </COMPLEMENTARY_STRENGTHS>
</V19_1_VALIDATION_LAYER>

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 3: TRAINING PROCEDURES                                   -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<TRAINING_PROCEDURES>

<NEURAL_MODEL_TRAINING>
    <!-- This section describes how to train the neural components -->
    
    <TRAINING_DATA_PREPARATION>
        Source: CKD Catalog Corpus
        - NS Series nitrogen generators
        - SKL/NCK/SCK shock killers
        - GLC guide-less cylinders
        - HRL/HCA/HCM high-precision cylinders
        - RRC/GRC rodless cylinders
        - SSD-LN slide cylinders
        - Various valves, sensors, accessories
        
        Data Collection:
        1. Extract Japanese segments from source catalogs
        2. Extract corresponding English translations (human-validated)
        3. Clean data (remove formatting, standardize)
        4. Validate alignment (Japanese segment → English segment match)
        
        Data Statistics (Target):
        - Total segments: 10,000+
        - Average segment length: 15-50 words
        - Domain: 100% industrial pneumatics
        - Quality: Human-validated translations
        
        Data Split:
        - Training: 80% (8,000 segments)
        - Validation: 10% (1,000 segments)
        - Test: 10% (1,000 segments)
    </TRAINING_DATA_PREPARATION>
    
    <ENCODER_TRAINING>
        Model: Japanese Semantic Encoder (Agent 60)
        
        Training Loop:
        for each batch in training_data:
            # Get Japanese-English pairs
            ja_texts = batch['japanese']
            en_texts = batch['english']
            
            # Encode both languages
            ja_embeddings = encoder_ja.encode(ja_texts)
            en_embeddings = encoder_en.encode(en_texts)  # Separate encoder for English
            
            # Loss 1: Contrastive Loss (same meaning → same embedding)
            positive_pairs = zip(ja_embeddings, en_embeddings)  # Same meaning
            negative_pairs = create_negative_pairs(batch)  # Different meanings
            
            loss_contrastive = contrastive_loss(positive_pairs, negative_pairs)
            
            # Loss 2: Adversarial Language Discriminator
            discriminator_ja_predictions = discriminator(ja_embeddings)
            discriminator_en_predictions = discriminator(en_embeddings)
            
            # Encoder tries to fool discriminator (make predictions random)
            loss_adversarial = adversarial_loss(discriminator_ja_predictions,
                                               discriminator_en_predictions)
            
            # Total Loss
            loss_total = loss_contrastive + 0.1 * loss_adversarial
            
            # Backpropagate
            loss_total.backward()
            optimizer.step()
        
        Training Duration: 2-3 days on GPU
        Hardware: NVIDIA A100 or equivalent
        Batch Size: 32
        Learning Rate: 1e-5 (with warm-up and decay)
        Epochs: 10-20 (until validation loss plateaus)
    </ENCODER_TRAINING>
    
    <DECODER_TRAINING>
        Model: English Semantic Decoder (Agent 63)
        
        Training Loop:
        for each batch in training_data:
            # Get Japanese texts (for encoding to USI)
            ja_texts = batch['japanese']
            en_texts = batch['english']  # Target outputs
            
            # Encode Japanese → USI embeddings
            usi_embeddings = encoder_ja.encode(ja_texts)
            
            # CRITICAL: Decoder NEVER sees Japanese
            # Only sees: USI embeddings + English targets
            
            # Decode USI → English (teacher forcing)
            predicted_en_tokens = decoder.generate(
                usi_embeddings,
                target_en_tokens=en_texts,  # Teacher forcing during training
                method='teacher_forcing'
            )
            
            # Loss: Cross-Entropy
            loss = cross_entropy_loss(predicted_en_tokens, en_texts)
            
            # Backpropagate
            loss.backward()
            optimizer.step()
        
        Training Duration: 2-3 days on GPU
        Hardware: NVIDIA A100 or equivalent
        Batch Size: 16 (smaller due to autoregressive generation)
        Learning Rate: 5e-5
        Epochs: 15-25
    </DECODER_TRAINING>
    
    <JOINT_FINE_TUNING>
        After separate training, fine-tune encoder + decoder together:
        
        for each batch in training_data:
            ja_texts = batch['japanese']
            en_texts = batch['english']
            
            # Full pipeline
            usi_embeddings = encoder_ja.encode(ja_texts)
            predicted_en_texts = decoder.generate(usi_embeddings)
            
            # Loss: End-to-End Translation Quality
            loss_translation = bleu_score_loss(predicted_en_texts, en_texts)
            
            # Loss: Semantic Consistency (round-trip)
            usi_roundtrip = encoder_en.encode(predicted_en_texts)
            loss_consistency = mse_loss(usi_embeddings, usi_roundtrip)
            
            # Total Loss
            loss_total = loss_translation + 0.5 * loss_consistency
            
            # Backpropagate through entire pipeline
            loss_total.backward()
            optimizer.step()
        
        Duration: 1-2 days
        Purpose: Optimize end-to-end translation quality
    </JOINT_FINE_TUNING>
    
    <VALIDATION_DURING_TRAINING>
        Every 500 steps:
        1. Evaluate on validation set (1,000 segments)
        2. Metrics:
           - BLEU score (translation quality)
           - Embedding similarity (language neutrality)
           - Discriminator accuracy (should be ~50%)
        3. Save checkpoint if validation improves
        4. Early stopping if no improvement for 10 checkpoints
    </VALIDATION_DURING_TRAINING>
    
    <POST_TRAINING_VALIDATION>
        After training complete:
        
        TEST 1: Language Neutrality
        - Run on test set (1,000 segments)
        - Measure: Embedding similarity (JA vs EN)
        - PASS: > 95% average similarity
        
        TEST 2: Discriminator Fooling
        - Discriminator tries to guess language from embedding
        - PASS: < 55% accuracy (barely better than random)
        
        TEST 3: Round-Trip Consistency
        - JA → USI → EN → USI
        - Measure: Original USI vs Round-trip USI
        - PASS: > 98% consistency
        
        TEST 4: Translation Quality
        - Human evaluation on 100 random test segments
        - Compare: V20.0 vs V19.1 baseline
        - PASS: Quality ≥ V19.1 (95%+)
        
        All 4 tests MUST PASS before production deployment
    </POST_TRAINING_VALIDATION>
</NEURAL_MODEL_TRAINING>

<CONTINUOUS_LEARNING>
    <!-- System improves over time from user corrections -->
    
    <CORRECTION_COLLECTION>
        When user provides correction:
        1. Original Japanese: "このシリンダは..."
        2. System output: "This cylinder operates at 1.0 MPa."
        3. User correction: "This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa."
        4. Store as new training example:
           {
               "japanese": "このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応",
               "english_correct": "This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa.",
               "english_system": "This cylinder operates at 1.0 MPa.",
               "correction_type": "VERB_CHOICE",
               "user_id": "chris_ckd",
               "timestamp": "2025-12-21T15:30:00Z"
           }
    </CORRECTION_COLLECTION>
    
    <RETRAINING_SCHEDULE>
        When to retrain:
        - Accumulated corrections: 500+ new examples
        - Quality degradation: System quality drops below 94%
        - Domain shift: New product lines introduced
        - Scheduled: Every 3 months (even if quality stable)
        
        Retraining process:
        1. Combine original training data + corrections
        2. Re-train encoder and decoder (same procedure as initial training)
        3. Validate on test set (must beat previous model)
        4. A/B test: New model vs Current model (100 segments)
        5. Deploy if new model superior
        6. Rollback if new model worse
    </RETRAINING_SCHEDULE>
    
    <INCREMENTAL_LEARNING>
        For small updates (< 100 corrections):
        - Use fine-tuning instead of full retraining
        - Faster (1 day vs 3 days)
        - Lower risk of catastrophic forgetting
        - Update glossary database with new terms
    </INCREMENTAL_LEARNING>
</CONTINUOUS_LEARNING>

</TRAINING_PROCEDURES>

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 4: USAGE PROCEDURES                                      -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<USAGE_PROCEDURES>

<TRANSLATION_WORKFLOW>
    <!-- How to use V20.0 in production -->
    
    <BATCH_TRANSLATION>
        Input: 1,000 Japanese catalog segments
        
        Step 1: Pre-Processing (Agent 0)
        - Legacy term normalization
        - Tag masking (preserve InDesign tags)
        - Document-level analysis
        
        Step 2: Encoding (Agent 60)
        for each segment in input:
            ja_text = segment.text
            usi_embedding = Agent_60.encode(ja_text)
            
            # Validate encoding (Agent 62)
            validation_result = Agent_62.validate(usi_embedding)
            if validation_result == FAIL:
                flag_segment_for_review(segment.id)
                continue
            
            # Store USI
            store_embedding(segment.id, usi_embedding)
        
        Step 3: Decoding (Agent 63)
        for each segment in input:
            usi_embedding = retrieve_embedding(segment.id)
            
            # Decode to English
            en_text = Agent_63.decode(usi_embedding)
            
            # Glossary alignment (Agent 64)
            en_text_aligned = Agent_64.align_glossary(en_text)
            
            # Semantic fidelity check (Agent 65)
            fidelity_score = Agent_65.verify(ja_text, usi_embedding, en_text_aligned)
            
            if fidelity_score < 0.90:
                flag_segment_for_review(segment.id)
                continue
            
            # Store output
            store_translation(segment.id, en_text_aligned)
        
        Step 4: Classical Validation (Agents 1-57)
        for each segment in input:
            en_text = retrieve_translation(segment.id)
            
            # Run V19.1 validation agents
            validation_results = run_v19_1_validation(en_text, segment.ja_text)
            
            # Check if all validations passed
            if not all(validation_results.passed):
                flag_segment_for_review(segment.id)
                log_validation_failures(segment.id, validation_results)
            else:
                mark_segment_approved(segment.id)
        
        Step 5: Human QA (Statistical Sampling)
        # User reviews random sample
        sample = random_sample(segments, size=100)
        
        for segment in sample:
            display_for_review(segment.ja_text, segment.en_text)
            user_feedback = get_user_feedback()  # PASS / FAIL / CORRECT
            
            if user_feedback == CORRECT:
                store_correction(segment.id, user_feedback.corrected_text)
                add_to_retraining_corpus(segment)
        
        Output: English translated catalog (validated)
    </BATCH_TRANSLATION>
    
    <REAL_TIME_TRANSLATION>
        <!-- For interactive use (1 segment at a time) -->
        
        Input: Single Japanese segment
        
        Pipeline:
        Japanese → Agent_60 (Encode) 
                → Agent_61 (USI) 
                → Agent_62 (Validate Encoding)
                → Agent_63 (Decode)
                → Agent_64 (Glossary Align)
                → Agent_65 (Verify Fidelity)
                → Agents_1-57 (Classical Validation)
                → English Output
        
        Latency: ~500ms per segment (on GPU)
        Throughput: ~2 segments/second
        
        Use Cases:
        - Quick translation checks
        - Interactive CAT tool integration
        - Real-time terminology lookups
    </REAL_TIME_TRANSLATION>
    
    <ERROR_HANDLING>
        If semantic fidelity fails:
        1. Attempt re-decoding with different parameters
           - Increase beam width (5 → 10)
           - Adjust temperature (0.7 → 0.5, more conservative)
           - Try greedy decoding (most probable path)
        
        2. If re-decoding fails:
           - Flag for human review (HIGH PRIORITY)
           - Provide diagnostic information:
             * Source Japanese
             * USI embedding visualization (PCA projection)
             * Failed English output
             * Fidelity score
             * Which checks failed
        
        3. Fallback to V19.1:
           - If neural pipeline completely fails
           - Use classical V19.1 direct translation
           - Mark segment as "FALLBACK_MODE"
           - Still better than no translation
        
        4. Human review queue:
           - Prioritize by: Safety-critical > Low-fidelity > Low-confidence
           - User reviews during weekly QA session
           - Corrections added to retraining corpus
    </ERROR_HANDLING>
</TRANSLATION_WORKFLOW>

<QUALITY_MONITORING>
    <!-- Continuous quality tracking -->
    
    <DAILY_METRICS>
        Automatically logged:
        - Segments translated: COUNT
        - Average fidelity score: MEAN(fidelity_scores)
        - Flagged for review: COUNT(fidelity < 0.90)
        - Fallback to V19.1: COUNT(neural_failures)
        - Processing time: MEAN(latency_ms)
    </DAILY_METRICS>
    
    <WEEKLY_REPORT>
        Sent to user every Monday:
        
        ===== V20.0 WEEKLY QUALITY REPORT =====
        Period: 2025-12-15 to 2025-12-21
        
        Translation Volume:
        - Total segments: 4,523
        - Successfully translated: 4,398 (97.2%)
        - Flagged for review: 125 (2.8%)
        
        Quality Metrics:
        - Average fidelity: 96.5% ✓ (target: >95%)
        - Embedding similarity: 97.1% ✓ (target: >95%)
        - Language neutrality: 53.2% discriminator accuracy ✓ (target: <55%)
        
        User Validation:
        - Samples reviewed: 95
        - Approved: 89 (93.7%)
        - Corrections: 6 (6.3%)
        
        Action Items:
        - Review 125 flagged segments (estimated time: 1.5 hours)
        - 6 corrections added to retraining corpus
        - Next retraining: When 500 corrections accumulated (currently: 147)
        
        Recommendation: System performance GOOD, continue operation
        =======================================
    </WEEKLY_REPORT>
    
    <ALERTS>
        Automatic alerts if:
        - Fidelity score drops below 92% (WARNING)
        - Fidelity score drops below 88% (CRITICAL)
        - Flagged segments > 10% (INVESTIGATE)
        - Processing time > 2 seconds/segment (PERFORMANCE ISSUE)
        - Language neutrality test fails (RETRAIN NEEDED)
    </ALERTS>
</QUALITY_MONITORING>

<HUMAN_QA_INTERFACE>
    <!-- How user interacts with system for validation -->
    
    <REVIEW_INTERFACE>
        Display Format:
        
        ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
        │ SEGMENT 247 of 4,523                                    │
        │ Confidence: 96.5% ✓ | Fidelity: 97.2% ✓                │
        ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
        │ 【Japanese Source】                                      │
        │ このシリンダは最大1.0MPaに対応しています。                │
        │                                                         │
        │ 【English Translation】                                 │
        │ This cylinder supports pressures up to 1.0 MPa.         │
        │                                                         │
        │ 【Validation Checks】                                   │
        │ ✓ Zero omission (N=1 source, N=1 target)               │
        │ ✓ Semantic fidelity (97.2%)                            │
        │ ✓ Glossary alignment (100%)                            │
        │ ✓ Tag preservation (N/A - no tags)                     │
        │ ✓ Safety compliance (N/A - not safety-critical)        │
        │                                                         │
        │ [✓ APPROVE]  [✗ REJECT]  [✎ CORRECT]  [⏭ SKIP]       │
        └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
        
        If user clicks [✎ CORRECT]:
        - Opens editor with English text
        - User makes correction
        - System stores: Original Japanese, System output, User correction
        - Adds to retraining corpus
        - Thanks user, moves to next segment
    </REVIEW_INTERFACE>
    
    <BATCH_APPROVAL>
        For high-confidence segments (>98% fidelity):
        
        Option: "Approve all 234 high-confidence segments?"
        - Saves time (no need to review each one)
        - Still spot-check 10-20 random samples
        - Balance: Efficiency vs Quality
    </BATCH_APPROVAL>
</HUMAN_QA_INTERFACE>

</USAGE_PROCEDURES>

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 5: PERFORMANCE SPECIFICATIONS                            -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<PERFORMANCE_SPECIFICATIONS>

<SPEED>
    Hardware: NVIDIA A100 GPU (40GB VRAM)
    
    Encoding (Agent 60): ~100ms per segment
    Decoding (Agent 63): ~300ms per segment
    Validation (Agents 62, 65): ~50ms per segment
    Classical QA (Agents 1-57): ~50ms per segment
    
    Total Latency: ~500ms per segment
    
    Throughput:
    - Real-time: 2 segments/second
    - Batch (parallel): 20 segments/second
    
    Compared to V19.1:
    - V19.1: ~1 segment/second (8x faster than manual)
    - V20.0: ~2 segments/second (16x faster than manual)
    - BUT: V20.0 requires GPU (V19.1 runs on CPU)
    
    Optimization: If speed critical, can use smaller models
    - Distilled encoder/decoder (6 layers vs 12)
    - Trade-off: 10% speed gain, 1-2% quality loss
</SPEED>

<QUALITY>
    Target Metrics:
    - Translation quality: 96-97% (vs 95% V19.1 baseline)
    - Semantic fidelity: 96%+ (new metric, not in V19.1)
    - Glossary accuracy: 98%+ (same as V19.1)
    - Zero omission: 100% (same as V19.1)
    - Safety compliance: 100% (same as V19.1)
    - Language neutrality: >95% embedding similarity
    
    Confidence Distribution (Expected):
    - VERY_HIGH (>98%): 75% of segments
    - HIGH (95-98%): 20% of segments
    - MEDIUM (90-95%): 4% of segments
    - LOW (<90%): 1% of segments (flagged for review)
</QUALITY>

<RESOURCE_REQUIREMENTS>
    GPU: NVIDIA A100 (40GB) or equivalent
    - Alternative: A10, RTX 4090 (24GB) - slower but workable
    - Minimum: RTX 3090 (24GB) - acceptable for prototyping
    
    CPU: 16 cores (for batch processing)
    RAM: 64GB
    Storage: 100GB SSD (for models, embeddings, corpus)
    
    Cloud Alternative:
    - AWS: g5.2xlarge instance (~$1.20/hour)
    - GCP: n1-standard-8 + T4 GPU (~$0.80/hour)
    - Azure: NC6s_v3 (~$0.90/hour)
    
    Cost Estimate:
    - Training: $50-100 (2-3 days GPU rental)
    - Inference: $200-300/month (8 hours/day usage)
    - Total first year: ~$3,000 (vs savings of 120M yen!)
</RESOURCE_REQUIREMENTS>

<SCALABILITY>
    Current: Japanese ↔ English only
    
    Future Expansion:
    - Add Korean decoder: Reuse same USI, just train new decoder (2 days)
    - Add Italian decoder: Reuse same USI, just train new decoder (2 days)
    - Add German decoder: Reuse same USI, just train new decoder (2 days)
    
    Scaling Pattern:
    - First language pair: 3 days training (encoder + decoder)
    - Each additional target language: 2 days training (decoder only)
    - USI is truly universal (same for all languages)
    
    This is THE breakthrough for UV21.3.1 (universal system)!
</SCALABILITY>

</PERFORMANCE_SPECIFICATIONS>

<!-- ============================================================== -->
<!-- PART 6: DEPLOYMENT INSTRUCTIONS                               -->
<!-- ============================================================== -->

<DEPLOYMENT_INSTRUCTIONS>

<PHASE_1_PREPARATION>
    Week 1: Data Collection and Preparation
    
    Day 1-2: Corpus Collection
    - Extract Japanese segments from existing catalogs
    - Extract corresponding English translations
    - Verify alignment (Japanese ↔ English matches)
    - Target: 10,000+ high-quality pairs
    
    Day 3-4: Data Cleaning
    - Remove formatting tags (store separately for later)
    - Standardize text (normalize whitespace, punctuation)
    - Validate quality (remove low-quality translations)
    - Split: 80% train, 10% val, 10% test
    
    Day 5: Environment Setup
    - Set up GPU server (local or cloud)
    - Install: PyTorch, Transformers, CUDA
    - Download base models (Japanese BERT, English BERT)
    - Verify GPU working (test training script)
    
    Day 6-7: Initial Training Test
    - Train on small subset (1,000 pairs)
    - Verify training pipeline works
    - Check: Loss decreasing, outputs sensible
    - Adjust hyperparameters if needed
</PHASE_1_PREPARATION>

<PHASE_2_TRAINING>
    Week 2-3: Full Model Training
    
    Training Schedule:
    
    Days 1-3: Encoder Training
    - Train Japanese encoder (Agent 60)
    - Train English encoder (parallel, for validation)
    - Monitor: Embedding similarity, discriminator accuracy
    - Save checkpoints every 1,000 steps
    
    Days 4-6: Decoder Training
    - Train English decoder (Agent 63)
    - Input: USI embeddings from frozen encoder
    - Monitor: BLEU score, perplexity
    - Save checkpoints every 1,000 steps
    
    Days 7-9: Joint Fine-Tuning
    - Fine-tune encoder + decoder together
    - Optimize end-to-end translation quality
    - Monitor: Round-trip consistency
    
    Days 10-11: Validation Testing
    - Run all 3 language neutrality tests
    - Human evaluation (you validate 100 samples)
    - Compare quality vs V19.1 baseline
    
    Day 12: Decision Point
    - If quality ≥ V19.1: Proceed to integration
    - If quality < V19.1: Retrain with adjustments
</PHASE_2_TRAINING>

<PHASE_3_INTEGRATION>
    Week 4: Integration with V19.1 Validation
    
    Day 1-2: Code Integration
    - Integrate neural agents (60-65) with classical agents (0-57)
    - Create unified pipeline
    - Test: End-to-end translation workflow
    
    Day 3-4: Testing on Known Corpus
    - Translate 500 segments from NS Series
    - Compare outputs: V20.0 vs V19.1
    - Validate: Quality maintained or improved
    
    Day 5-6: User Interface Development
    - Create review interface for you
    - Batch translation scripts
    - Quality monitoring dashboard
    
    Day 7: User Training
    - You learn to use new system
    - Practice reviewing sample segments
    - Understand flagging/correction workflow
</PHASE_3_INTEGRATION>

<PHASE_4_PILOT>
    Week 5-6: Pilot Deployment
    
    Week 5: Controlled Testing
    - Translate 1 complete catalog (3,000-5,000 segments)
    - You review random sample (100 segments)
    - Collect corrections
    - Monitor quality metrics
    
    Week 6: Evaluation and Adjustment
    - Analyze pilot results
    - Compare: V20.0 vs V19.1 on same catalog
    - Decision: 
      * If quality ≥ V19.1: Deploy to production
      * If quality < V19.1: Iterate and improve
</PHASE_4_PILOT>

<PHASE_5_PRODUCTION>
    Week 7+: Full Production Deployment
    
    Deployment:
    - V20.0 becomes primary translation system
    - V19.1 remains available as fallback
    - Continuous monitoring and improvement
    
    Weekly Routine:
    - System translates 1,000-5,000 segments automatically
    - You review flagged segments (1-2 hours)
    - Corrections added to retraining corpus
    - Quality reports generated automatically
    
    Monthly Routine:
    - Review aggregate statistics
    - Decide if retraining needed
    - Update glossaries if new terminology added
    
    Quarterly Routine:
    - Full retraining (if 500+ corrections accumulated)
    - Re-validate language neutrality
    - Update documentation
</PHASE_5_PRODUCTION>

<ROLLBACK_PLAN>
    If V20.0 fails in production:
    
    Immediate Rollback:
    - Switch all jobs back to V19.1
    - V19.1 proven stable (no risk)
    - Continue operations normally
    
    Root Cause Analysis:
    - Identify what failed (quality? speed? crashes?)
    - Collect failure examples
    - Determine fix (retrain? adjust parameters? code bug?)
    
    Fix and Retry:
    - Implement fix
    - Re-test on pilot corpus
    - Re-deploy only if issue resolved
    
    V19.1 Always Available:
    - Never delete V19.1 system
    - Always maintain fallback capability
