              - "k cylindru" (to the cylinder)
          </DATIVE>
          
          <ACCUSATIVE>
            Uses:
              - Direct object
              - After motion prepositions: na, do, za, před, pod
              - After certain verbs requiring accusative
            
            Triggers:
              - Object of transitive verb
              - "vidím cylindr" (I see cylinder-ACC)
          </ACCUSATIVE>
          
          <VOCATIVE>
            Uses:
              - Direct address
              (Rare in technical documentation)
          </VOCATIVE>
          
          <LOCATIVE>
            Uses:
              - Location ("in, on, about")
              - After prepositions: v, na, o, po, při
            
            Triggers:
              - "v cylindru" (in the cylinder)
              - "o válci" (about the valve)
          </LOCATIVE>
          
          <INSTRUMENTAL>
            Uses:
              - Means/instrument ("with, by")
              - After certain prepositions: s, nad, pod, před, za
            
            Triggers:
              - "s cylindrem" (with the cylinder)
              - "řízen počítačem" (controlled by computer)
          </INSTRUMENTAL>
        
        DETERMINE required_case based on triggers
        STORE with term
      END FOR
    </STEP_1_DETERMINE_REQUIRED_CASE>
    
    <STEP_2_DETERMINE_NUMBER>
      ANALYZE for singular vs plural:
        - Verb agreement
        - Quantity expressions
        - Context clues
      
      SET required_number
    </STEP_2_DETERMINE_NUMBER>
    
    <STEP_3_RETRIEVE_DECLENSION>
      FOR EACH term:
        
        LOAD from glossary:
          IF required_number = singular:
            CASE_FORMS = entry.case_declensions
          ELSE:
            CASE_FORMS = entry.plural_declensions
          END IF
        
        SELECT appropriate form:
          IF required_case = nominative:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.nominative
          ELSE IF required_case = genitive:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.genitive
          ELSE IF required_case = dative:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.dative
          ELSE IF required_case = accusative:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.accusative
          ELSE IF required_case = vocative:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.vocative
          ELSE IF required_case = locative:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.locative
          ELSE IF required_case = instrumental:
            term_form = CASE_FORMS.instrumental
          END IF
        
        IF term_form exists in glossary:
          confidence = 1.0
        ELSE:
          ATTEMPT rule-based construction
          confidence = 0.85
          FLAG: "Declension constructed"
        END IF
        
        STORE declined_form
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_RETRIEVE_DECLENSION>
    
    <STEP_4_ADJECTIVE_AGREEMENT>
      FOR EACH term WITH adjective:
        
        ADJECTIVE must agree in:
          - Gender
          - Number
          - Case
        
        <ADJECTIVE_DECLENSION_PATTERNS>
          Hard adjectives (e.g., "nový" - new):
            Masculine inanimate nominative singular: -ý
            Masculine animate nominative singular: -ý
            Feminine nominative singular: -á
            Neuter nominative singular: -é
            
            [Each gender has 7 cases × 2 numbers = 14 forms]
          
          Soft adjectives (e.g., "moderní" - modern):
            Similar pattern but with different endings
        </ADJECTIVE_DECLENSION_PATTERNS>
        
        APPLY appropriate adjective form:
          MATCH: gender + number + case
          
          EXAMPLE:
            Noun: "cylindr" (masculine inanimate)
            Adjective: "pneumatický"
            
            Nominative singular: "pneumatický cylindr"
            Genitive singular: "pneumatického cylindru"
            Locative singular: "pneumatickém cylindru"
            Instrumental singular: "pneumatickým cylindrem"
        
        COMBINE: declined_adjective + declined_noun
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_ADJECTIVE_AGREEMENT>
    
    <STEP_5_PREPOSITION_CASE_AGREEMENT>
      FOR EACH term WITH preposition:
        
        VERIFY preposition governs correct case:
          
          Prepositions governing GENITIVE:
            bez, do, od, z, u, kolem, vedle, místo, během
          
          Prepositions governing DATIVE:
            k, proti, díky, kvůli, naproti
          
          Prepositions governing ACCUSATIVE:
            (with motion) na, do, za, před, pod, mezi, nad
          
          Prepositions governing LOCATIVE:
            v, na, o, po, při
          
          Prepositions governing INSTRUMENTAL:
            s, nad, pod, před, za, mezi
          
          Note: Some prepositions take different cases for different meanings:
            na + accusative = motion "onto"
            na + locative = location "on"
        
        VERIFY term is in case required by preposition
        CORRECT if mismatch
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_PREPOSITION_CASE_AGREEMENT>
    
    <STEP_6_VALIDATION>
      VERIFY complete agreement:
        - Case matches context
        - Number matches
        - Gender consistent
        - Adjective agrees
        - Preposition governs correct case
      
      CALCULATE confidence
      
      IF validation_errors:
        ATTEMPT correction
        LOG errors
      END IF
    </STEP_6_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_7_OUTPUT>
      PACKAGE declined_czech_terms{
        terms: declined_forms[],
        cases_applied: case_list[],
        confidence_scores: scores[]
      }
      
      RETURN to AGENT_93 (Czech Compound Handler)
    </STEP_7_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF case_determination_ambiguous:
      USE nominative (default/safest)
      REDUCE confidence by 0.15
      FLAG for review
    END IF
    
    IF declension_missing_from_glossary:
      APPLY standard declension rules
      REDUCE confidence by 0.15
    END IF
    
    IF preposition_case_conflict:
      PRIORITIZE preposition requirement
      LOG conflict
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <10ms per term (complex due to 7 cases)
    Accuracy: >95% with glossary data, >88% with constructed forms
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_92_CZECH_CASE_HANDLER>

================================================================================
AGENT 93: CZECH COMPOUND HANDLER
================================================================================

<AGENT_93_CZECH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Czech multi-word technical phrases</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_COMPOUND_STRUCTURE>
      Czech technical terms typically multi-word (like Romance languages)
      NOT single compounds (unlike German)
      
      Common patterns:
        Adjective + Noun: "pneumatický válec"
        Noun + Genitive: "válec vzduchu" (valve of air)
    </STEP_1_COMPOUND_STRUCTURE>
    
    <STEP_2_MAINTAIN_SEPARATION>
      DO NOT create single-word compounds
      KEEP multi-word structure
      APPLY proper case endings to all components
    </STEP_2_MAINTAIN_SEPARATION>
    
    <STEP_3_OUTPUT>
      RETURN structured_phrases[] to AGENT_94
    </STEP_3_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_93_CZECH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

================================================================================
AGENT 94: CZECH FORMAT VALIDATOR
================================================================================

<AGENT_94_CZECH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Czech orthography and diacritics</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_DIACRITIC_VALIDATION>
      CRITICAL: Verify ALL diacritics present and correct
      
      Czech diacritics:
        Acute: á, é, í, ó, ú, ý
        Háček: č, ď, ě, ň, ř, š, ť, ž
        Ring: ů
      
      CHECK each character
      VERIFY against dictionary
      CORRECT any errors
      
      IF diacritics missing or wrong:
        CRITICAL ERROR - meaning changes
        FORCE correction
        FLAG for verification
      END IF
    </STEP_1_DIACRITIC_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_2_CAPITALIZATION>
      VERIFY:
        - Sentence-initial capitals
        - Proper nouns capitalized
        - Common nouns lowercase
    </STEP_2_CAPITALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_3_OUTPUT>
      RETURN validated_czech[] to AGENT_95
    </STEP_3_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_94_CZECH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

================================================================================
AGENT 95: CZECH QUALITY CHECKER
================================================================================

<AGENT_95_CZECH_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final quality verification for Czech translations</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_COMPREHENSIVE_CHECK>
      VERIFY:
        - All 7 cases applied correctly
        - Gender agreement throughout
        - Diacritics perfect
        - Adjective declension correct
        - LOCKED terms enforced
      
      CALCULATE quality_score
    </STEP_1_COMPREHENSIVE_CHECK>
    
    <STEP_2_LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
      VERIFY 100% compliance for locked terms
      FORCE correction if needed
    </STEP_2_LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_3_OUTPUT>
      RETURN final_czech_terms[] to USI Manager
    </STEP_3_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_95_CZECH_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
AGENTS 96-100: POLISH GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_96_POLISH_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Polish terms to glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <POLISH_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <DIACRITICS>
        Polish diacritics (meaning-critical):
          ą (a with ogonek - nasal)
          ć (c with acute)
          ę (e with ogonek - nasal)
          ł (l with stroke)
          ń (n with acute)
          ó (o with acute)
          ś (s with acute)
          ź (z with acute)
          ż (z with dot)
        
        PRESERVE exactly - changes meaning
      </DIACRITICS>
      
      <CASE_SYSTEM>
        Polish has 7 grammatical cases (like Czech):
          Nominative, Genitive, Dative, Accusative, Instrumental, Locative, Vocative
        
        MUST normalize to nominative for lookup
      </CASE_SYSTEM>
      
      <GENDER_SYSTEM>
        3 genders: masculine, feminine, neuter
        Masculine subdivided: personal vs non-personal (affects declension)
      </GENDER_SYSTEM>
    </POLISH_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <LOOKUP_ALGORITHM>
      [Similar structure to Czech - AGENT_91]
      
      NORMALIZE to nominative case
      SEARCH exact match
      SEARCH case variants
      SEARCH diacritic variants (emergency only)
      
      RETURN results to AGENT_97
    </LOOKUP_ALGORITHM>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <2ms per term
    Accuracy: >97% with diacritics
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_96_POLISH_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

<AGENT_97_POLISH_CASE_GENDER_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply Polish case and gender agreement</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <CASE_DETERMINATION>
      [Similar to Czech - 7 cases with similar usage]
      
      DETERMINE required case from context:
        - Nominative: subject
        - Genitive: possession, after negation, with numbers
        - Dative: indirect object
        - Accusative: direct object
        - Instrumental: means/instrument
        - Locative: location
        - Vocative: address (rare in technical)
    </CASE_DETERMINATION>
    
    <APPLY_DECLENSION>
      RETRIEVE case forms from glossary
      SELECT appropriate form
      APPLY to term
    </APPLY_DECLENSION>
    
    <ADJECTIVE_AGREEMENT>
      Polish adjectives agree in:
        - Gender
        - Number
        - Case
      
      APPLY proper adjective declension
    </ADJECTIVE_AGREEMENT>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN declined_polish[] to AGENT_98
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_97_POLISH_CASE_GENDER_HANDLER>

<AGENT_98_POLISH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Polish multi-word phrases</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    MAINTAIN multi-word structure
    APPLY case endings to components
    PRESERVE proper word order
    
    RETURN to AGENT_99
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_98_POLISH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_99_POLISH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Polish orthography</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY all Polish diacritics present:
      ą, ć, ę, ł, ń, ó, ś, ź, ż
    
    CHECK capitalization
    VERIFY spelling
    
    RETURN to AGENT_100
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_99_POLISH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

<AGENT_100_POLISH_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Polish quality check</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - 7 cases correct
      - Diacritics perfect
      - Gender/number agreement
      - LOCKED terms enforced
    
    RETURN final_polish_terms[]
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_100_POLISH_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
AGENTS 101-105: TURKISH GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_101_TURKISH_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Turkish terms to glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <TURKISH_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <ALPHABET>
        Turkish uses Latin alphabet with modifications:
          Special letters: ç, ğ, ı (dotless i), İ (capital dotted I), ö, ş, ü
        
        CRITICAL: "i" and "ı" are DIFFERENT letters
          i → İ (dotted)
          ı → I (dotless)
        
        This affects capitalization and searching
      </ALPHABET>
      
      <VOWEL_HARMONY>
        Turkish uses vowel harmony:
          Suffixes change vowels to match root word
          
          Front vowels: e, i, ö, ü
          Back vowels: a, ı, o, u
        
        IMPORTANT for suffix handling
      </VOWEL_HARMONY>
      
      <AGGLUTINATION>
        Turkish is agglutinative:
          Many suffixes attached to root
          Example: "ev" (house) → "evlerimizden" (from our houses)
        
        MUST strip suffixes to find root for glossary lookup
      </AGGLUTINATION>
      
      <NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER>
        Turkish has NO grammatical gender (simplifies agreement)
        
        But has:
          - 6 cases (nominative, accusative, dative, locative, ablative, genitive)
          - Plural marking
          - Possessive suffixes
      </NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER>
    </TURKISH_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH potential_term:
        
        <STRIP_SUFFIXES>
          IDENTIFY and remove Turkish suffixes:
            
            Plural: -ler, -lar (vowel harmony)
            
            Case suffixes:
              Accusative: -(y)ı, -(y)i, -(y)u, -(y)ü
              Dative: -(y)a, -(y)e
              Locative: -de, -da, -te, -ta
              Ablative: -den, -dan, -ten, -tan
              Genitive: -(n)in, -(n)ın, -(n)un, -(n)ün
            
            Possessive suffixes:
              1st person: -im, -ım, -um, -üm
              2nd person: -in, -ın, -un, -ün
              3rd person: -(s)i, -(s)ı, -(s)u, -(s)ü
          
          EXAMPLES:
            "silindirlerde" → "silindir" (cylinder-PLUR-LOC → cylinder)
            "valfin" → "valf" (valve-GEN → valve)
          
          GENERATE root_form for lookup
        </STRIP_SUFFIXES>
        
        <HANDLE_I_DOTTING>
          CRITICAL: Handle i/ı distinction properly
          
          When converting case:
            lowercase i → uppercase İ (dotted)
            lowercase ı → uppercase I (dotless)
            uppercase İ → lowercase i (dotted)
            uppercase I → lowercase ı (dotless)
          
          SEARCH must respect this distinction
        </HANDLE_I_DOTTING>
      END FOR
    </TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      FOR EACH root_form:
        
        <EXACT_MATCH>
          SEARCH glossary WHERE turkish = root_form
          (CASE-SENSITIVE including i/ı distinction)
          
          IF exact_match:
            RETRIEVE entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              turkish: root_form,
              case_forms: {
                nominative: form,
                accusative: form,
                dative: form,
                locative: form,
                ablative: form,
                genitive: form
              },
              plural_forms: {same 6 cases for plural},
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            STORE result
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_MATCH>
        
        <CASE_INSENSITIVE_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            SEARCH with Turkish case-folding rules:
              (Respecting i/İ and ı/I distinctions)
            
            IF match_found:
              confidence = 0.98
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </CASE_INSENSITIVE_MATCH>
        
        <SUFFIX_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no match:
            TRY alternative suffix stripping
            (Vowel harmony might produce variants)
            
            IF match_found:
              confidence = 0.94
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </SUFFIX_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            note: "Route to TIER 3"
          }
          STORE result
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH locked_term:
        SET mandatory enforcement
      END FOR
    </LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN results[] to AGENT_102 (Turkish Case Handler)
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF suffix_stripping_ambiguous:
      TRY all plausible roots
      SELECT highest confidence match
    END IF
    
    IF i_ı_confusion_in_source:
      LOG warning
      TRY both variants
      FLAG for verification
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <2ms per term
    Accuracy: >96% with proper suffix handling
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_101_TURKISH_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

<AGENT_102_TURKISH_CASE_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply Turkish case suffixes</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <DETERMINE_REQUIRED_CASE>
      ANALYZE context for case requirement:
        
        Nominative: subject, dictionary form (no suffix)
        Accusative: direct object
        Dative: indirect object, direction
        Locative: location "at, in, on"
        Ablative: source "from"
        Genitive: possession "of"
      
      DETERMINE which case needed
    </DETERMINE_REQUIRED_CASE>
    
    <APPLY_CASE_SUFFIX>
      RETRIEVE case form from glossary
      OR CONSTRUCT using rules:
        
        <VOWEL_HARMONY_RULES>
          IF root has back vowels (a, ı, o, u):
            USE back vowel variant
          ELSE IF root has front vowels (e, i, ö, ü):
            USE front vowel variant
          END IF
          
          EXAMPLES:
            "silindir" (front vowels) + locative = "silindirde"
            "valf" (front vowel) + genitive = "valfin"
        </VOWEL_HARMONY_RULES>
        
        <CONSONANT_HARMONY>
          IF root ends in voiceless consonant (p, ç, t, k):
            USE voiceless variant of suffix
          ELSE:
            USE voiced variant
          END IF
          
          EXAMPLES:
            "valf" (ends in f, voiceless) + locative = "valfte" (NOT "valfde")
        </CONSONANT_HARMONY>
      
      APPLY suffix with proper harmony
    </APPLY_CASE_SUFFIX>
    
    <HANDLE_PLURAL>
      IF plural needed:
        ADD plural suffix first: -ler or -lar (vowel harmony)
        THEN add case suffix
        
        EXAMPLE:
          "silindir" (cylinder)
          + plural: "silindirler"
          + locative: "silindirlerde" (in the cylinders)
    </HANDLE_PLURAL>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN declined_turkish[] to AGENT_103
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <5ms per term
    Accuracy: >95% with vowel harmony rules
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_102_TURKISH_CASE_HANDLER>

<AGENT_103_TURKISH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Turkish multi-word and compound terms</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <COMPOUND_STRUCTURE>
      Turkish can form compounds OR use multi-word phrases
      
      FOLLOW glossary specification:
        IF glossary shows single word: use single word
        IF glossary shows multi-word: keep separated
    </COMPOUND_STRUCTURE>
    
    <MAINTAIN_STRUCTURE>
      PRESERVE glossary word structure
      APPLY case suffixes appropriately
    </MAINTAIN_STRUCTURE>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN to AGENT_104
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_103_TURKISH_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_104_TURKISH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Turkish orthography</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <VERIFY_SPECIAL_LETTERS>
      CHECK all Turkish special letters correct:
        ç, ğ, ı, İ, ö, ş, ü
      
      VERIFY i/ı distinction (critical)
      VERIFY İ/I distinction (critical)
    </VERIFY_SPECIAL_LETTERS>
    
    <VERIFY_VOWEL_HARMONY>
      CHECK suffixes follow vowel harmony
      CORRECT violations
    </VERIFY_VOWEL_HARMONY>
    
    <CAPITALIZATION>
      VERIFY proper capitalization
      RESPECT i→İ and ı→I rules
    </CAPITALIZATION>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN validated_turkish[] to AGENT_105
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_104_TURKISH_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

<AGENT_105_TURKISH_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Turkish quality verification</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <COMPREHENSIVE_CHECK>
      VERIFY:
        - Suffix stripping correct
        - Case application proper
        - Vowel harmony respected
        - i/ı distinction maintained
        - LOCKED terms enforced
      
      CALCULATE quality_score
    </COMPREHENSIVE_CHECK>
    
    <LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
      VERIFY 100% compliance
      FORCE corrections
    </LOCKED_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <OUTPUT>
      RETURN final_turkish_terms[] to USI Manager
    </OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <15ms full validation per term
    Quality threshold: ≥90%
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_105_TURKISH_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
END OF TIER 2 PART 2
Agents 86-105: Portuguese, Czech, Polish, Turkish Glossary Systems
Lines: ~15,000
================================================================================
================================================================================
USI17_V21.3.1 EXECUTABLE PROMPT - TIER 2 PART 3: GLOSSARY SYSTEM
VIETNAMESE, THAI, INDONESIAN, KOREAN (AGENTS 106-125)
================================================================================

================================================================================
AGENTS 106-110: VIETNAMESE GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_106_VIETNAMESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Vietnamese terms to glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_VIETNAMESE_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <TONAL_SYSTEM>
        Vietnamese is a tonal language with 6 tones (Northern dialect):
          1. Level (unmarked): ma (ghost)
          2. Falling (grave): mà (but)
          3. Rising (acute): má (mother)
          4. Question (hook above): mả (tomb)
          5. Tumbling (tilde): mã (horse)
          6. Heavy (dot below): mạ (rice seedling)
        
        CRITICAL: Tone marks change meaning completely
        MUST preserve all diacritics exactly
        
        Diacritics used:
          Vowels: a, ă, â, e, ê, i, o, ô, ơ, u, ư, y
          Tone marks: ` (grave), ´ (acute), ̉ (hook), ~ (tilde), ̣ (dot below)
          Combined: à, á, ả, ã, ạ, etc.
      </TONAL_SYSTEM>
      
      <NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_OR_CASE>
        Vietnamese has:
          - NO grammatical gender
          - NO case declension
          - NO verb conjugation (for tense/person)
        
        BUT has:
          - Classifiers (required with numbers)
          - Measure words
          - Tone-based meaning
      </NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_OR_CASE>
      
      <MULTI_SYLLABIC_COMPOUNDS>
        Technical terms often multi-syllabic:
          "xy-lanh khí nén" (pneumatic cylinder)
          Each syllable carries tone
      </MULTI_SYLLABIC_COMPOUNDS>
      
      <WRITING_SYSTEM>
        Uses Latin alphabet (Romanized - Quốc ngữ)
        Spaces between syllables (not words in linguistic sense)
      </WRITING_SYSTEM>
    </STEP_1_VIETNAMESE_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
      RECEIVE: Vietnamese source text
      
      EXTRACT potential glossary terms:
        IDENTIFY technical terminology:
          - Multi-syllabic compounds
          - Terms with hyphens (xy-lanh, van-khí)
          - Specification-related terms
        
        PRESERVE all tones exactly
        STORE in candidate_terms[]
    </STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH term IN candidate_terms[]:
        
        <TONE_PRESERVATION>
          CRITICAL: Keep all tone marks
          STORE: term_original (with tones)
          
          CREATE normalized_variant:
            - Remove tone marks (for emergency fuzzy match only)
            - USE ONLY as last resort
        </TONE_PRESERVATION>
        
        <SPACING_NORMALIZATION>
          Vietnamese syllables separated by spaces:
            "xy lanh" vs "xy-lanh" (both valid)
          
          NORMALIZE spacing variations:
            - With hyphens: preferred for compounds
            - With spaces: also acceptable
          
          SEARCH both variants
        </SPACING_NORMALIZATION>
        
        <CASE_NORMALIZATION>
          Vietnamese doesn't use capitalization for grammar
          Only for:
            - Sentence beginnings
            - Proper names
          
          CREATE lowercase variant for matching
        </CASE_NORMALIZATION>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      LOAD glossary (503 terms with Vietnamese translations)
      
      FOR EACH normalized_term:
        
        <EXACT_TONE_MATCH>
          SEARCH WHERE vietnamese = term_original (exact with tones)
          
          IF exact_match_found:
            RETRIEVE complete_entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              vietnamese: matched_term,
              syllable_count: count,
              classifier: appropriate_classifier,
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              domain: category,
              tones_verified: true,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            CREATE result{
              match_type: "exact_with_tones",
              confidence: 1.0,
              entry: complete_entry
            }
            
            STORE in results[]
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_TONE_MATCH>
        
        <SPACING_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            TRY spacing/hyphenation variants:
              "xy-lanh" ↔ "xy lanh" ↔ "xylanh"
            
            IF variant_found:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "spacing_variant",
                confidence: 0.99,
                entry: variant_entry,
                note: "Spacing normalized"
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </SPACING_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <CASE_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no match yet:
            TRY case-insensitive match
            
            IF found:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "case_variant",
                confidence: 0.98,
                entry: entry
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </CASE_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <TONELESS_MATCH_EMERGENCY>
          IF still no match AND source_may_have_missing_tones:
            WARNING: This is emergency fallback only
            
            SEARCH with tone-insensitive comparison
            
            IF found:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "toneless_approximate",
                confidence: 0.60,
                warning: "TONE MARKS MISSING - verify accuracy",
                entry: entry,
                note: "Source text may have encoding issues"
              }
              
              FLAG for mandatory human verification
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </TONELESS_MATCH_EMERGENCY>
        
        <COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
          IF no match and term is multi-syllabic:
            SPLIT into syllables
            SEARCH for components
            
            IF all_components_found:
              CONSTRUCT composite translation
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "compound_constructed",
                confidence: 0.85,
                entry: composite_entry
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            entry: null,
            note: "Route to TIER 3 semantic translation"
          }
          STORE in results[]
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_5_TONE_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH result WHERE match_found:
        
        VERIFY tone marks are valid Vietnamese tones:
          CHECK: Each syllable has valid tone pattern
          VERIFY: Tone marks properly positioned
          
          IF tone_marks_invalid:
            REDUCE confidence by 0.20
            FLAG: "Invalid tone pattern detected"
          END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_TONE_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_CLASSIFIER_IDENTIFICATION>
      FOR EACH matched_term:
        
        Vietnamese uses classifiers with numbers:
          "một cái xy-lanh" (one [classifier] cylinder)
        
        IDENTIFY appropriate classifier from glossary:
          cái: general objects, machines
          chiếc: vehicles, machines
          con: animals, some objects
          quả: round objects
          
        STORE classifier for use in translation
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_CLASSIFIER_IDENTIFICATION>
    
    <STEP_7_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH result:
        VERIFY technical domain match
        CHECK semantic appropriateness
        
        ADJUST confidence based on context
      END FOR
    </STEP_7_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_8_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH result WHERE entry.locked = true:
        
        SET enforcement{
          status: "LOCKED",
          override_allowed: false,
          tone_preservation_mandatory: true,
          confidence: 1.0
        }
        
        IF tones_missing_in_locked_term:
          CRITICAL_ERROR: "LOCKED term requires exact tones"
          FORCE glossary version
        END IF
        
        LOG: "LOCKED Vietnamese term identified"
      END FOR
    </STEP_8_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_9_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
      FOR EACH term:
        CREATE package{
          original_term: source,
          matched_entry: glossary_entry,
          tones_verified: boolean,
          classifier: appropriate_classifier,
          confidence: score,
          warnings: warnings[]
        }
        
        STORE in packaged_results[]
      END FOR
      
      RETURN to AGENT_107 (Vietnamese Format Validator)
    </STEP_9_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF database_unavailable:
      TRY backup
      IF backup_fails:
        ROUTE all to TIER 3
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF tone_marks_corrupted_in_source:
      LOG critical_warning
      ATTEMPT repair using context
      FLAG for human verification
      REDUCE confidence significantly
    END IF
    
    IF tone_normalization_fails:
      USE original as-is
      FLAG for review
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <1ms per term
    Accuracy: >99% with proper tones, >60% without tones
    Critical: Tone accuracy essential for meaning
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_106_VIETNAMESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENT 107: VIETNAMESE FORMAT VALIDATOR
================================================================================

<AGENT_107_VIETNAMESE_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Vietnamese tone marks and orthography</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_TONE_MARK_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH term:
        
        <VERIFY_TONE_MARKS_PRESENT>
          Vietnamese syllables require tone marks
          
          SCAN each syllable:
            CHECK for tone mark (one of 6 tones)
            
            IF no_tone_mark AND syllable_not_particle:
              WARNING: "Missing tone mark"
              CHECK if level tone (unmarked) is correct
              OR if tone mark was lost
            END IF
        </VERIFY_TONE_MARKS_PRESENT>
        
        <VERIFY_TONE_MARK_POSITION>
          Tone marks go on vowels:
            - Single vowel: mark goes on that vowel
            - Diphthong: specific rules for which vowel gets mark
            
          RULES for diphthong tone placement:
            oa, oe, uy: mark on second vowel
            ia, ua, ưa: mark on second vowel  
            Other combinations: mark on first vowel
          
          VERIFY tone mark on correct vowel
          CORRECT if misplaced
        </VERIFY_TONE_MARK_POSITION>
        
        <VERIFY_DIACRITIC_COMBINATIONS>
          Vietnamese combines:
            - Base vowel modification (ă, â, ê, ô, ơ, ư)
            - Tone mark (`, ´, ̉, ~, ̣)
          
          EXAMPLES:
            ă + tone grave = ằ
            â + tone acute = ấ
            ơ + tone hook = ở
          
          VERIFY: Both diacritics present where needed
          CHECK: Proper Unicode encoding (combined characters)
        </VERIFY_DIACRITIC_COMBINATIONS>
      END FOR
    </STEP_1_TONE_MARK_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_2_SYLLABLE_STRUCTURE_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH syllable:
        
        VERIFY valid Vietnamese syllable structure:
          (Consonant) + Vowel + (Final consonant) + Tone
          
          Valid initial consonants:
            b, c, ch, d, đ, g, gh, gi, h, k, kh, l, m, n, ng, ngh, nh, p, ph, qu, r, s, t, th, tr, v, x
          
          Valid vowels (with modifications):
            a, ă, â, e, ê, i, o, ô, ơ, u, ư, y
          
          Valid final consonants:
            c, ch, m, n, ng, nh, p, t
          
          CHECK structure validity
          FLAG if invalid combination
      END FOR
    </STEP_2_SYLLABLE_STRUCTURE_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_3_CAPITALIZATION_CHECK>
      Vietnamese uses standard capitalization:
        - Sentence-initial words
        - Proper names
        - NOT for common nouns
      
      VERIFY capitalization appropriate
      CORRECT if needed
    </STEP_3_CAPITALIZATION_CHECK>
    
    <STEP_4_SPACING_VALIDATION>
      VERIFY proper spacing:
        - Syllables within compound may use hyphens or spaces
        - Words separated by spaces
        - No extra spaces
      
      NORMALIZE spacing
    </STEP_4_SPACING_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_5_ENCODING_VALIDATION>
      VERIFY proper Unicode encoding:
        - Precomposed characters preferred: ă not a+̆
        - Consistent encoding throughout
        
      NORMALIZE to standard encoding
    </STEP_5_ENCODING_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_OUTPUT>
      CREATE validated_output{
        validated_terms: terms[],
        tone_errors_corrected: count,
        warnings: warnings[]
      }
      
      RETURN to AGENT_108 (Vietnamese Quality Checker)
    </STEP_6_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF tone_mark_missing_cannot_determine:
      FLAG for human review
      MARK confidence low
    END IF
    
    IF invalid_syllable_structure:
      CHECK if transliteration error
      ATTEMPT correction
      IF cannot_correct:
        FLAG for review
      END IF
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <5ms per term
    Accuracy: >99% tone mark validation
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_107_VIETNAMESE_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

================================================================================
AGENTS 108-110: VIETNAMESE REMAINING AGENTS
================================================================================

<AGENT_108_VIETNAMESE_CLASSIFIER_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply appropriate Vietnamese classifiers</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    FOR terms used with numbers:
      SELECT appropriate classifier from glossary
      INSERT between number and noun
      
      EXAMPLE: "ba cái xy-lanh" (three [classifier] cylinders)
    
    RETURN to AGENT_109
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_108_VIETNAMESE_CLASSIFIER_HANDLER>

<AGENT_109_VIETNAMESE_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Vietnamese multi-syllabic compounds</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    MAINTAIN multi-syllabic structure
    PRESERVE tone marks on all syllables
    APPLY proper spacing/hyphenation
    
    RETURN to AGENT_110
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_109_VIETNAMESE_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_110_VIETNAMESE_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Vietnamese quality verification</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - All tone marks present and correct
      - Syllable structure valid
      - Classifiers appropriate
      - Encoding proper
      - LOCKED terms enforced with exact tones
    
    CALCULATE quality_score
    
    IF tones_incorrect OR missing:
      CRITICAL failure - tones change meaning
      REDUCE score significantly
    END IF
    
    RETURN final_vietnamese_terms[] to USI Manager
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Quality threshold: ≥95% (tones are critical)
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_110_VIETNAMESE_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
AGENTS 111-115: THAI GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_111_THAI_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Thai terms to glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_THAI_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <WRITING_SYSTEM>
        Thai uses its own script (Brahmic script)
        NOT Latin alphabet
        
        Alphabet: 44 consonants, 15 vowel symbols, 4 tone marks
        
        Direction: Left-to-right
        
        NO spaces between words (continuous writing)
        Spaces indicate sentence/phrase boundaries
      </WRITING_SYSTEM>
      
      <TONAL_SYSTEM>
        5 tones in Thai:
          1. Mid (no mark)
          2. Low (่)
          3. Falling (้)
          4. High (๊)
          5. Rising (๋)
        
        Tone determined by:
          - Consonant class (low, mid, high)
          - Tone mark (if present)
          - Vowel length
          - Final consonant
        
        CRITICAL: Tones change meaning
      </TONAL_SYSTEM>
      
      <VOWEL_POSITIONING>
        Thai vowels written:
          - Above consonant: เ ไ ใ
          - Below consonant: ุ ู
          - After consonant: ะ า
          - Around consonant: เ-อ, แ-ะ
        
        Reading order ≠ writing order in some cases
      </VOWEL_POSITIONING>
      
      <NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
        Thai has:
          - NO grammatical gender
          - NO case declension
          - NO plural marking (context-based)
        
        BUT has:
          - Classifiers (required with numbers)
          - Particles for politeness
          - Word order importance
      </NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
      
      <COMPOUND_WORDS>
        Technical terms often compounds written continuously:
          กระบอกลมนิวเมติก (pneumatic cylinder)
          No spaces within compound
      </COMPOUND_WORDS>
    </STEP_1_THAI_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
      RECEIVE: Thai source text
      
      <WORD_SEGMENTATION>
        CRITICAL: Thai has no spaces between words
        
        MUST perform word segmentation:
          USE Thai word segmentation algorithm
          IDENTIFY word boundaries
          EXTRACT potential technical terms
        
        METHODS:
          - Dictionary-based segmentation
          - Longest matching
          - Statistical models
        
        STORE segmented_terms[]
      </WORD_SEGMENTATION>
      
      <IDENTIFY_TECHNICAL_TERMS>
        SCAN for:
          - Compound technical words
          - Foreign loanwords (may be in Latin script)
          - Specification-related terms
        
        STORE in candidate_terms[]
      </IDENTIFY_TECHNICAL_TERMS>
    </STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH term IN candidate_terms[]:
        
        <TONE_MARK_PRESERVATION>
          PRESERVE all tone marks (่ ้ ๊ ๋)
          CRITICAL for meaning
          
          STORE: term_original (with tones)
        </TONE_MARK_PRESERVATION>
        
        <VOWEL_NORMALIZATION>
          VERIFY vowel marks properly positioned
          NORMALIZE any encoding variants
        </VOWEL_NORMALIZATION>
        
        <FINAL_CONSONANT_CHECK>
          Some consonants change pronunciation in final position
          PRESERVE exact spelling
        </FINAL_CONSONANT_CHECK>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      LOAD glossary (503 terms with Thai translations)
      
      FOR EACH normalized_term:
        
        <EXACT_MATCH>
          SEARCH WHERE thai = term_original (exact)
          
          IF exact_match_found:
            RETRIEVE complete_entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              thai: matched_term,
              thai_romanization: pronunciation_guide,
              classifier: appropriate_classifier,
              tone_pattern: tone_info,
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            CREATE result{
              match_type: "exact",
              confidence: 1.0,
              entry: complete_entry
            }
            
            STORE in results[]
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_MATCH>
        
        <TONE_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            TRY tone-insensitive comparison
            (Emergency fallback - tones are critical)
            
            IF variant_found:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "tone_approximate",
                confidence: 0.65,
                warning: "TONE MARKS DIFFER - verify meaning",
                entry: variant_entry
              }
              
              FLAG for mandatory human verification
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </TONE_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
          IF no match and term is compound:
            ATTEMPT decomposition:
              SPLIT into component morphemes
              SEARCH for components
            
            IF all_components_found:
              CONSTRUCT composite translation
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "compound_constructed",
                confidence: 0.82,
                entry: composite_entry
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
        
        <LOANWORD_MATCH>
          IF term appears to be loanword:
            CHECK for transliteration variants
            SEARCH alternative spellings
            
            IF found:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "loanword_variant",
                confidence: 0.88,
                entry: entry
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </LOANWORD_MATCH>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            note: "Route to TIER 3"
          }
          STORE in results[]
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_5_CLASSIFIER_IDENTIFICATION>
      FOR EACH matched_term:
        
        Thai uses classifiers with numbers:
          "สามอัน" (three [classifier])
        
        Common classifiers:
          อัน: general objects, small items
          เครื่อง: machines, devices
          ตัว: animals, furniture, some objects
          อย่าง: kinds, types
        
        RETRIEVE classifier from glossary
        STORE for use in translation
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_CLASSIFIER_IDENTIFICATION>
    
    <STEP_6_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH locked_term:
        SET mandatory_enforcement
        VERIFY exact Thai script match
        confidence = 1.0
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_7_OUTPUT>
      RETURN results[] to AGENT_112 (Thai Format Validator)
    </STEP_7_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF word_segmentation_fails:
      TRY alternative segmentation
      USE multiple candidate segmentations
      SELECT best match
    END IF
    
    IF tone_marks_missing:
      LOG critical_warning
      REDUCE confidence significantly
      FLAG for verification
    END IF
    
    IF encoding_corrupted:
      ATTEMPT repair
      IF cannot_repair:
        FLAG for human review
      END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <3ms per term (including segmentation)
    Accuracy: >96% with proper word segmentation
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_111_THAI_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENTS 112-115: THAI REMAINING AGENTS
================================================================================

<AGENT_112_THAI_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Thai script and tone marks</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Thai script proper (not corrupted)
      - Tone marks present where required
      - Vowel positioning correct
      - No mixing of scripts (Thai/Latin) inappropriately
      - Proper Unicode encoding
    
    CORRECT any errors found
    
    RETURN to AGENT_113
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_112_THAI_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

<AGENT_113_THAI_CLASSIFIER_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply Thai classifiers appropriately</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    FOR terms with numbers:
      INSERT appropriate classifier from glossary
      
      STRUCTURE: Number + Classifier + Noun
      EXAMPLE: ๓ เครื่อง กระบอกลม (three [classifier] cylinders)
    
    RETURN to AGENT_114
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_113_THAI_CLASSIFIER_HANDLER>

<AGENT_114_THAI_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Thai compound words</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    MAINTAIN continuous writing (no spaces within compound)
    PRESERVE tone marks on all syllables
    ENSURE proper component ordering
    
    RETURN to AGENT_115
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_114_THAI_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_115_THAI_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Thai quality verification</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Script integrity
      - Tone marks correct
      - Word segmentation proper
      - Classifiers appropriate
      - LOCKED terms exact match
    
    CALCULATE quality_score
    
    RETURN final_thai_terms[] to USI Manager
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_115_THAI_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
AGENTS 116-120: INDONESIAN GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_116_INDONESIAN_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Indonesian (Bahasa Indonesia) terms to glossary</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_INDONESIAN_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <WRITING_SYSTEM>
        Uses Latin alphabet
        Standard 26 letters (no additional letters)
        Phonetic spelling (generally regular)
      </WRITING_SYSTEM>
      
      <NO_TONES>
        Indonesian is NOT tonal (unlike Vietnamese/Thai)
        Pronunciation stress-based but not meaning-critical
      </NO_TONES>
      
      <AFFIXATION>
        Indonesian uses extensive affixes:
          Prefixes: me-, ber-, di-, ter-, pe-, per-, se-
          Suffixes: -kan, -i, -an
          Circumfixes: ke-...-an, pe-...-an, per-...-an
        
        MUST strip affixes to find root for lookup
      </AFFIXATION>
      
      <NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
        Indonesian has:
          - NO grammatical gender
          - NO case declension
          - NO verb conjugation for tense
        
        BUT has:
          - Reduplication for plurality/intensity
          - Affixes for voice/aspect
          - Word order significance
      </NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
      
      <LOANWORDS>
        Many technical terms borrowed from:
          - Dutch (historical)
          - English (modern)
          - Arabic (some terms)
        
        May have Indonesian spelling adaptations
      </LOANWORDS>
    </STEP_1_INDONESIAN_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
      RECEIVE: Indonesian source text
      
      EXTRACT potential glossary terms:
        - Technical terminology
        - Compound phrases
        - Specification terms
      
      STORE in candidate_terms[]
    </STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH term IN candidate_terms[]:
        
        <AFFIX_STRIPPING>
          IDENTIFY and remove Indonesian affixes:
            
            PREFIXES:
              me- (verb forming, active voice)
              ber- (verb forming, intransitive)
              di- (passive voice)
              ter- (accidental/superlative)
              pe- (agent noun)
              per- (noun forming)
              se- (one/same)
            
            SUFFIXES:
              -kan (causative/benefactive)
              -i (locative/applicative)
              -an (noun forming)
            
            CIRCUMFIXES:
              ke-...-an (abstract noun)
              pe-...-an (noun, action/result)
              per-...-an (noun, action/place)
          
          EXAMPLES of stripping:
            "silinder" → root (no affixes)
            "menyilinder" → "silinder" (remove me-)
            "disilinder" → "silinder" (remove di-)
            "kesilinder-an" → "silinder" (remove ke-...-an)
          
          GENERATE root_form for lookup
        </AFFIX_STRIPPING>
        
        <REDUPLICATION_HANDLING>
          Indonesian uses reduplication:
            Full: "buku-buku" (books - plural)
            Partial: "lelaki" (man)
          
          IF term is reduplicated:
            EXTRACT base form
            SEARCH for base
          END IF
        </REDUPLICATION_HANDLING>
        
        <CASE_NORMALIZATION>
          Indonesian doesn't use capitalization grammatically
          CREATE lowercase variant for matching
        </CASE_NORMALIZATION>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      FOR EACH root_form:
        
        <EXACT_MATCH>
          SEARCH glossary WHERE indonesian = root_form
          
          IF exact_match:
            RETRIEVE complete_entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              indonesian: root_form,
              affixed_forms: {common_derivations},
              classifier: classifier_if_applicable,
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            STORE result
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_MATCH>
        
        <CASE_INSENSITIVE_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            SEARCH case-insensitive
            
            IF found:
              confidence = 0.99
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </CASE_INSENSITIVE_MATCH>
        
        <SPELLING_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no match yet:
            CHECK spelling variants:
              - Old vs new spelling (pre/post-1972 reform)
              - Dutch-influenced vs modern
              
              EXAMPLES:
                "sistim" vs "sistem" (system)
                "tehnik" vs "teknik" (technique)
            
            IF variant_found:
              confidence = 0.95
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </SPELLING_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <LOANWORD_MATCH>
          IF term appears to be loanword:
            CHECK for:
              - English original with Indonesian spelling
              - Dutch loanword variants
            
            EXAMPLES:
              "silinder" ← cylinder
              "pneumatik" ← pneumatic
              "valv" ← valve (Dutch: klep OR valv)
            
            IF found:
              confidence = 0.92
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </LOANWORD_MATCH>
        
        <COMPOUND_PHRASE_MATCH>
          IF term is multi-word:
            SEARCH for full phrase
            IF phrase_found:
              confidence = 1.0
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
            
            DECOMPOSE and search components
            IF all_found:
              CONSTRUCT composite
              confidence = 0.85
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </COMPOUND_PHRASE_MATCH>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            note: "Route to TIER 3"
          }
          STORE result
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_5_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH match:
        VERIFY technical domain appropriateness
        CHECK semantic coherence
        
        ADJUST confidence
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH locked_term:
        SET mandatory_enforcement
        confidence = 1.0
        override_allowed = false
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_7_OUTPUT>
      RETURN results[] to AGENT_117 (Indonesian Format Validator)
    </STEP_7_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF affix_stripping_ambiguous:
      TRY all plausible roots
      SELECT highest confidence match
    END IF
    
    IF reduplication_irregular:
      SEARCH both full and partial forms
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <1.5ms per term
    Accuracy: >97% with proper affix handling
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_116_INDONESIAN_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENTS 117-120: INDONESIAN REMAINING AGENTS
================================================================================

<AGENT_117_INDONESIAN_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Indonesian spelling and formatting</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Modern spelling (post-1972 EYD system)
      - No archaic Dutch spellings
      - Proper capitalization (sentence-initial, proper nouns only)
      - Consistent spelling throughout
    
    CORRECT any errors
    
    RETURN to AGENT_118
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_117_INDONESIAN_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

<AGENT_118_INDONESIAN_AFFIX_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply Indonesian affixes appropriately</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    IF context requires affixed form:
      RETRIEVE appropriate affix from glossary
      APPLY to root according to phonological rules
      
      EXAMPLE:
        Root: "silinder"
        Passive: "disilinder"
        Nominalization: "pesilinder-an"
    
    RETURN to AGENT_119
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_118_INDONESIAN_AFFIX_HANDLER>

<AGENT_119_INDONESIAN_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Indonesian multi-word terms</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    Indonesian compounds typically separate words
    
    STRUCTURE: Noun + Modifier
      "silinder pneumatik" (pneumatic cylinder)
    
    MAINTAIN separation
    PRESERVE word order
    
    RETURN to AGENT_120
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_119_INDONESIAN_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_120_INDONESIAN_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Indonesian quality verification</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Root form correct
      - Affixes appropriate
      - Spelling modern/standard
      - LOCKED terms enforced
    
    CALCULATE quality_score
    
    RETURN final_indonesian_terms[] to USI Manager
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_120_INDONESIAN_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
AGENTS 121-125: KOREAN GLOSSARY SYSTEM
================================================================================

<AGENT_121_KOREAN_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Korean (Hangul) terms to glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_KOREAN_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <WRITING_SYSTEM>
        Korean uses Hangul (한글) - phonetic alphabet
        
        Syllable blocks composed of:
          - Initial consonant (초성)
          - Medial vowel (중성)
          - Optional final consonant (종성)
        
        Each syllable forms a block
        Example: 공 = ㄱ (g) + ㅗ (o) + ㅇ (ng)
      </WRITING_SYSTEM>
      
      <HANJA_USAGE>
        Technical terms may use:
          - Pure Hangul (native Korean)
          - Sino-Korean (한자/Hanja origin)
          - Loanwords (외래어) from English
        
        Same term may be written:
          - In Hangul only: 공압
          - With Hanja: 空壓 (rare in modern usage)
          - Mixed: usually Hangul in modern text
      </HANJA_USAGE>
      
      <PARTICLES>
        Korean uses grammatical particles (조사):
          Subject: 이/가, 은/는
          Object: 을/를
          Possessive: 의
          Direction: 에, 로/으로
          Topic: 은/는
        
        Particle choice depends on final consonant:
          이/가: after consonant / after vowel
          을/를: after consonant / after vowel
        
        MUST separate particles from root for lookup
      </PARTICLES>
      
      <NO_SPACES_WITHIN_COMPOUNDS>
        Korean technical compounds often written together:
          공압실린더 (pneumatic cylinder - no spaces)
        
        BUT may be separated in some contexts:
          공압 실린더 (with space)
      </NO_SPACES_WITHIN_COMPOUNDS>
      
      <HONORIFIC_SYSTEM>
        Korean has elaborate honorific system
        (Less relevant for technical documentation)
      </HONORIFIC_SYSTEM>
    </STEP_1_KOREAN_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
      RECEIVE: Korean source text
      
      EXTRACT potential glossary terms:
        - Technical Hangul compounds
        - Sino-Korean technical terms
        - Loanword technical terms
      
      STORE in candidate_terms[]
    </STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH term IN candidate_terms[]:
        
        <PARTICLE_STRIPPING>
          IDENTIFY and remove grammatical particles:
            
            Subject particles: 이, 가
            Object particles: 을, 를
            Topic particles: 은, 는
            Possessive: 의
            Locative: 에, 에서
            Direction: 로, 으로
            Instrumental: 로, 으로
            Comitative: 와, 과
            
          DETERMINE particle selection rule:
            After consonant-final syllable: 이, 을, 은, 과, 으로
            After vowel-final syllable: 가, 를, 는, 와, 로
          
          STRIP particle to get base noun
          STORE particle_info for reconstruction
          
          EXAMPLES:
            "실린더가" → "실린더" (subject particle removed)
            "밸브를" → "밸브" (object particle removed)
            "공압의" → "공압" (possessive particle removed)
        </PARTICLE_STRIPPING>
        
        <SPACING_NORMALIZATION>
          Korean compounds may be:
            - Written together: 공압실린더
            - Written separately: 공압 실린더
          
          CREATE variants:
            - No spaces
            - With spaces
          
          SEARCH both forms
        </SPACING_NORMALIZATION>
        
        <LOANWORD_NORMALIZATION>
          Korean loanwords written in Hangul phonetically:
            "실린더" (silindeo) ← cylinder
            "밸브" (baelbeu) ← valve
          
          PRESERVE Hangul spelling
          NOTE romanization for reference
        </LOANWORD_NORMALIZATION>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      FOR EACH normalized_term:
        
        <EXACT_HANGUL_MATCH>
          SEARCH glossary WHERE korean = term (exact Hangul)
          
          IF exact_match:
            RETRIEVE complete_entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              korean_hangul: matched_term,
              korean_hanja: hanja_if_applicable,
              romanization: pronunciation_guide,
              particles: {particle_attachment_rules},
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            STORE result
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_HANGUL_MATCH>
        
        <SPACING_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            TRY spacing variants:
              "공압실린더" ↔ "공압 실린더"
            
            IF variant_found:
              confidence = 0.99
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </SPACING_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <HANJA_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF term could be Sino-Korean:
            CHECK for Hanja equivalents
            
            EXAMPLE:
              공압 (空壓) - pneumatic (air pressure)
              실린더 - cylinder (loanword, no Hanja)
            
            IF hanja_variant_found:
              confidence = 0.97
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </HANJA_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <LOANWORD_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF term is loanword:
            CHECK for:
              - Alternative Hangul spellings
              - Older vs newer romanization
            
            EXAMPLES:
              "밸브" vs "밸브" (minor variant)
              "실린더" vs "실린다" (pronunciation variant)
            
            IF variant_found:
              confidence = 0.93
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </LOANWORD_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
          IF no match and appears compound:
            SPLIT into morphemes
            SEARCH components
            
            IF all_components_found:
              CONSTRUCT composite translation
              confidence = 0.85
              STORE result
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            note: "Route to TIER 3"
          }
          STORE result
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_5_PARTICLE_IDENTIFICATION>
      FOR EACH matched_term:
        
        DETERMINE which particle to use in context:
          
          ANALYZE grammatical role:
            IF subject: use 이/가 or 은/는
            IF object: use 을/를
            IF possessive: use 의
            etc.
          
          SELECT particle variant based on final sound:
            EXTRACT final syllable
            CHECK if consonant-final or vowel-final
            
            EXAMPLES:
              "실린더" (ends in ㄹ consonant) + subject = "실린더가"
              "공압" (ends in ㅂ consonant) + object = "공압을"
              "밸브" (ends in ㅡ vowel) + object = "밸브를"
          
          STORE particle_selection
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_PARTICLE_IDENTIFICATION>
    
    <STEP_6_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH match:
        VERIFY technical appropriateness
        CHECK semantic coherence
        
        ADJUST confidence
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_7_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH locked_term:
        SET mandatory_enforcement
        VERIFY exact Hangul match
        confidence = 1.0
        override_allowed = false
      END FOR
    </STEP_7_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_8_OUTPUT>
      RETURN results[] to AGENT_122 (Korean Particle Handler)
    </STEP_8_OUTPUT>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF particle_stripping_ambiguous:
      TRY both interpretations
      SELECT higher confidence match
    END IF
    
    IF spacing_ambiguous:
      SEARCH all variants
      PREFER glossary-specified spacing
    END IF
    
    IF Hangul_encoding_corrupted:
      LOG critical_error
      ATTEMPT repair
      FLAG for verification
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <2ms per term
    Accuracy: >97% with proper particle handling
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_121_KOREAN_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENTS 122-125: KOREAN REMAINING AGENTS
================================================================================

<AGENT_122_KOREAN_PARTICLE_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Apply Korean grammatical particles correctly</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    FOR EACH term requiring particle:
      
      DETERMINE grammatical role from context
      
      SELECT appropriate particle:
        Subject: 이/가 (consonant/vowel)
        Topic: 은/는 (consonant/vowel)
        Object: 을/를 (consonant/vowel)
        Possessive: 의
        Locative: 에, 에서
        Direction: 로/으로 (vowel/consonant)
      
      CHECK final sound of term:
        IF ends_in_consonant:
          USE consonant variant (이, 을, 은, etc.)
        ELSE:
          USE vowel variant (가, 를, 는, etc.)
        END IF
      
      ATTACH particle to term
      
      EXAMPLE:
        "실린더" + subject = "실린더가"
        "공압" + object = "공압을"
    
    RETURN to AGENT_123
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_122_KOREAN_PARTICLE_HANDLER>

<AGENT_123_KOREAN_COMPOUND_HANDLER>
  <MISSION>Handle Korean compound formation</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    Korean compounds may be:
      - Written together (common)
      - Written separately (less common)
    
    FOLLOW glossary specification:
      IF glossary shows no space: write together
      IF glossary shows space: keep separated
    
    DEFAULT: Write technical compounds together
      "공압실린더" (pneumatic cylinder)
    
    MAINTAIN proper syllable block structure
    
    RETURN to AGENT_124
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_123_KOREAN_COMPOUND_HANDLER>

<AGENT_124_KOREAN_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Korean Hangul and formatting</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Proper Hangul syllable blocks (초성+중성+종성)
      - No corrupted characters
      - Particles attached correctly
      - Spacing appropriate
      - No improper Hanja mixing (unless specified)
      - Proper Unicode encoding (modern Hangul block)
    
    CHECK syllable structure validity:
      Each block must have valid:
        - Initial consonant (including ㅇ for vowel-initial)
        - Medial vowel
        - Optional final consonant
    
    CORRECT any errors
    
    RETURN to AGENT_125
  </ALGORITHM>
</AGENT_124_KOREAN_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>

<AGENT_125_KOREAN_QUALITY_CHECKER>
  <MISSION>Final Korean quality verification</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    VERIFY:
      - Hangul integrity
      - Particles correct and properly attached
      - Spacing follows glossary standard
      - Compound structure proper
      - LOCKED terms exact Hangul match
    
    CALCULATE quality_score
    
    IF particle_errors:
      REDUCE score
      FLAG for correction
    END IF
    
    IF Hangul_structure_invalid:
      CRITICAL error
      REJECT translation
    END IF
    
    RETURN final_korean_terms[] to USI Manager
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Quality threshold: ≥92%
    Critical: Hangul structure and particle accuracy
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_125_KOREAN_QUALITY_CHECKER>

================================================================================
END OF TIER 2 PART 3
Agents 106-125: Vietnamese, Thai, Indonesian, Korean Glossary Systems
Lines: ~13,000
================================================================================
================================================================================
USI17_V21.3.1 EXECUTABLE PROMPT - TIER 2 PART 4: FINAL GLOSSARY SYSTEMS
CHINESE (SIMPLIFIED/TRADITIONAL), ENGLISH/JAPANESE EXTENSIONS + DATABASE
AGENTS 126-145 + COMPLETE GLOSSARY DATABASE (503 TERMS × 17 LANGUAGES)
================================================================================

================================================================================
AGENTS 126-130: CHINESE GLOSSARY SYSTEM (SIMPLIFIED & TRADITIONAL)
================================================================================

<AGENT_126_CHINESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Chinese terms (both Simplified and Traditional) to glossary</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_CHINESE_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
      <TWO_WRITING_SYSTEMS>
        Simplified Chinese (简体中文): Used in mainland China, Singapore
        Traditional Chinese (繁體中文): Used in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau
        
        SAME language, DIFFERENT characters:
          Simplified: 气压缸
          Traditional: 氣壓缸
          (Both mean "pneumatic cylinder")
        
        MUST support BOTH variants in glossary
      </TWO_WRITING_SYSTEMS>
      
      <NO_SPACES>
        Chinese written continuously without spaces
        Word boundaries determined by meaning, not spacing
        
        MUST perform word segmentation
      </NO_SPACES>
      
      <CHARACTERS_VS_WORDS>
        Each character is meaningful
        Words composed of 1-4+ characters
        Technical terms often 2-4 character compounds
      </CHARACTERS_VS_WORDS>
      
      <NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
        Chinese has:
          - NO grammatical gender
          - NO case declension
          - NO verb conjugation (tense by context/particles)
        
        BUT has:
          - Measure words/classifiers (量词)
          - Particles for aspect/mood
          - Complex character composition
      </NO_GRAMMATICAL_GENDER_CASE>
      
      <PRONUNCIATION_SYSTEMS>
        Pinyin (romanization): used for input/learning
        NOT used in final written text
        Characters are the standard written form
      </PRONUNCIATION_SYSTEMS>
    </STEP_1_CHINESE_SPECIFIC_FEATURES>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
      RECEIVE: Chinese source text
      
      <WORD_SEGMENTATION>
        CRITICAL: Chinese has no spaces between words
        
        PERFORM word segmentation:
          USE Chinese word segmentation algorithm
          IDENTIFY word boundaries
          EXTRACT potential technical terms
        
        METHODS:
          - Dictionary-based longest matching
          - Statistical segmentation models
          - Technical term recognition patterns
        
        STORE segmented_words[]
      </WORD_SEGMENTATION>
      
      <IDENTIFY_TECHNICAL_TERMS>
        SCAN for technical terminology patterns:
          - 2-4 character technical compounds
          - Domain-specific characters (气/氣, 压/壓, 缸, 阀/閥)
          - Specification-related terms
          - Measurement units
        
        STORE in candidate_terms[]
      </IDENTIFY_TECHNICAL_TERMS>
    </STEP_2_TERM_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_3_SIMPLIFIED_TRADITIONAL_HANDLING>
      FOR EACH term IN candidate_terms[]:
        
        <DETECT_VARIANT>
          DETERMINE if term is Simplified or Traditional:
            
            CHECK for variant-specific characters:
              Simplified-only: 气, 压, 阀, 门, etc.
              Traditional-only: 氣, 壓, 閥, 門, etc.
            
            IDENTIFY source_variant (CN or TW)
        </DETECT_VARIANT>
        
        <NORMALIZE_FOR_LOOKUP>
          GLOSSARY stores BOTH variants for each term
          
          SEARCH using detected variant
          ALSO search opposite variant (for robustness)
          
          EXAMPLE:
            Source has: 气压缸 (Simplified)
            Search: "气压缸" (primary)
            Also try: 氣壓缸 (Traditional variant)
        </NORMALIZE_FOR_LOOKUP>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_SIMPLIFIED_TRADITIONAL_HANDLING>
    
    <STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      FOR EACH term:
        
        <EXACT_MATCH_PRIMARY_VARIANT>
          IF source_variant = Simplified:
            SEARCH glossary WHERE chinese_cn = term
          ELSE IF source_variant = Traditional:
            SEARCH glossary WHERE chinese_tw = term
          END IF
          
          IF exact_match_found:
            RETRIEVE complete_entry{
              semantic_id: id,
              chinese_simplified: CN_form,
              chinese_traditional: TW_form,
              pinyin: romanization,
              measure_word: classifier,
              stroke_count: character_complexity,
              translations: {all_17_languages},
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            CREATE result{
              match_type: "exact",
              variant: source_variant,
              confidence: 1.0,
              entry: complete_entry
            }
            
            STORE in results[]
            CONTINUE
          END IF
        </EXACT_MATCH_PRIMARY_VARIANT>
        
        <CROSS_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no exact match in primary variant:
            SEARCH opposite variant:
              
              IF source was Simplified:
                SEARCH Traditional variant
              ELSE:
                SEARCH Simplified variant
              END IF
            
            IF found_in_opposite_variant:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "cross_variant",
                source_variant: detected_variant,
                matched_variant: opposite_variant,
                confidence: 0.98,
                entry: complete_entry,
                note: "Matched opposite Chinese variant"
              }
              
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </CROSS_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <PARTIAL_CHARACTER_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            CHECK for partial matches:
              - Same root characters with different measure words
              - Character order variants
              - Simplified/Traditional character mixing
            
            IF partial_match_found AND high_confidence:
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "partial",
                confidence: 0.85,
                entry: entry,
                note: "Partial character match"
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </PARTIAL_CHARACTER_MATCH>
        
        <COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
          IF term is multi-character compound:
            SPLIT into component characters
            SEARCH for component meanings
            
            IF all_components_found:
              CONSTRUCT composite meaning
              CREATE result{
                match_type: "compound_constructed",
                confidence: 0.80,
                entry: composite_entry,
                components: component_matches[]
              }
              STORE in results[]
              CONTINUE
            END IF
        </COMPOUND_DECOMPOSITION>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          CREATE result{
            match_type: "not_found",
            confidence: 0.0,
            entry: null,
            note: "Route to TIER 3 semantic translation"
          }
          STORE in results[]
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_5_VARIANT_SELECTION>
      FOR EACH matched_term:
        
        DETERMINE which variant to use in output:
          
          IF target_locale = mainland_china OR singapore:
            USE chinese_simplified from glossary
          ELSE IF target_locale = taiwan OR hong_kong OR macau:
            USE chinese_traditional from glossary
          ELSE:
            DEFAULT to Simplified (more common)
          END IF
        
        SELECT appropriate_variant
        STORE for output
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_VARIANT_SELECTION>
    
    <STEP_6_MEASURE_WORD_IDENTIFICATION>
      FOR EACH matched_term:
        
        Chinese uses measure words (classifiers) with numbers:
          "一个气压缸" (one [classifier] pneumatic cylinder)
        
        Common measure words:
          个/個 (ge): general classifier, most common
          台/臺 (tai): machines, equipment
          只/隻 (zhi): animals, some objects
          张/張 (zhang): flat objects
          条/條 (tiao): long objects
          根 (gen): stick-like objects
        
        RETRIEVE appropriate measure word from glossary
        STORE both Simplified and Traditional forms
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_MEASURE_WORD_IDENTIFICATION>
    
    <STEP_7_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH result:
        VERIFY technical domain appropriateness
        CHECK character composition makes sense
        VALIDATE semantic coherence
        
        ADJUST confidence based on validation
      END FOR
    </STEP_7_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_8_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH result WHERE entry.locked = true:
        
        SET enforcement{
          status: "LOCKED",
          override_allowed: false,
          variant_enforcement: "both_locked",
          confidence: 1.0
        }
        
        ENFORCE exact character match:
          Simplified form must match exactly
          Traditional form must match exactly
          NO character substitutions allowed
        
        LOG: "LOCKED Chinese term identified"
      END FOR
    </STEP_8_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_9_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
      FOR EACH term:
        CREATE package{
          original_term: source,
          matched_entry: glossary_entry,
          variant_used: CN_or_TW,
          simplified_form: CN_characters,
          traditional_form: TW_characters,
          pinyin: romanization,
          measure_word: classifier,
          confidence: score,
          warnings: warnings[]
        }
        
        STORE in packaged_results[]
      END FOR
      
      RETURN to AGENT_127 (Chinese Format Validator)
    </STEP_9_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF word_segmentation_fails:
      TRY alternative segmentation algorithms
      USE character-by-character matching as fallback
      REDUCE confidence
    END IF
    
    IF variant_detection_ambiguous:
      SEARCH both variants
      SELECT higher confidence match
    END IF
    
    IF character_encoding_corrupted:
      LOG critical_error
      ATTEMPT Unicode normalization repair
      FLAG for human verification
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <3ms per term (including segmentation)
    Accuracy: >96% with proper segmentation
    Variant handling: >99% accuracy
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_126_CHINESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENTS 127-130: CHINESE REMAINING AGENTS
================================================================================

<AGENT_127_CHINESE_FORMAT_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate Chinese character integrity and variant consistency</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_CHARACTER_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH term:
        
        VERIFY character integrity:
          - All characters valid Chinese (not corrupted)
          - No mixed character sets (no Japanese kanji intrusion)
          - Proper Unicode encoding
          - No character decomposition errors
        
        CHECK variant consistency:
          IF output_variant = Simplified:
            VERIFY all characters are Simplified forms
            CHECK for Traditional character intrusion
          ELSE IF output_variant = Traditional:
