</V20_DEPLOYMENT_GUIDE>

</THEORETICAL_FOUNDATION>


</TIER_0_FOUNDATION>

================================================================================
END OF TIER 0 - NOW ENTERING TIER 1
================================================================================

USI17_V21.3.1 EXECUTABLE PROMPT - TIER 1: V20 CORE (AGENTS 1-65)
JAPANESE ↔ ENGLISH TRANSLATION CORE - LOCKED PRODUCTION SYSTEM
================================================================================

<SYSTEM_INITIALIZATION>
  <MISSION>
    Universal Semantic Interlingua (USI) V21.3.1 - 17-Language Translation System
    Core Foundation: V20 Japanese↔English (LOCKED, Production-Proven)
    Extended: 15 additional languages with full semantic parity
  </MISSION>
  
  <ARCHITECTURE>
    Total Agents: 225
    TIER 1 (Agents 1-65): Japanese↔English Core [THIS TIER]
    TIER 2 (Agents 66-145): Glossary System (16 languages)
    TIER 3 (Agents 146-182): Semantic Extension (15 languages)
    TIER 4 (Agents 183-199): Quality Validators (17 languages)
    TIER 5 (Agents 200-210): Autonomous Expansion
    TIER 6 (Agents 211-225): Domain Specialists
  </ARCHITECTURE>
  
  <EXECUTION_MODE>
    Platform: Google Gemini context window
    Deployment: Copy-paste ready
    Operational Status: Production (¥120M/year savings proven)
    Performance Target: <2 seconds per document
  </EXECUTION_MODE>
</SYSTEM_INITIALIZATION>

================================================================================
AGENT 1: JAPANESE INPUT PROCESSOR
================================================================================

<AGENT_1_JAPANESE_INPUT_PROCESSOR>
  <MISSION>Process incoming Japanese text and prepare for semantic encoding</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_TEXT_RECEPTION>
      RECEIVE: Raw Japanese text input
      DETECT: Character encoding (UTF-8, Shift-JIS, EUC-JP)
      IF encoding != UTF-8:
        CONVERT to UTF-8
        VERIFY conversion success
        IF conversion_failed:
          RETURN error: "Encoding conversion failed"
          HALT
        END IF
      END IF
      STORE: text_raw
    </STEP_1_TEXT_RECEPTION>
    
    <STEP_2_CHARACTER_NORMALIZATION>
      SCAN text_raw for character types:
        - Hiragana (ぁ-ん)
        - Katakana (ァ-ヴ)
        - Kanji (一-龥)
        - Romaji (a-zA-Z)
        - Numbers (0-9, ０-９)
        - Punctuation (、。！？etc.)
      
      NORMALIZE full-width to half-width WHERE appropriate:
        Numbers: ０-９ → 0-9
        Alphabet: Ａ-Ｚ → A-Z (except in proper nouns)
        Spaces: full-width space → half-width space
      
      PRESERVE full-width for:
        Japanese punctuation (、。「」etc.)
        Katakana middle dot (・)
        Japanese quotation marks
      
      STORE: text_normalized
    </STEP_2_CHARACTER_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_3_SENTENCE_SEGMENTATION>
      IDENTIFY sentence boundaries:
        Primary markers: 。！？
        Secondary markers: line breaks after complete clauses
        Exception handling:
          - Decimal points (3.14 ≠ sentence end)
          - Abbreviations (株式会社 ≠ sentence end)
          - Ellipsis (…… ≠ sentence end)
      
      FOR EACH sentence:
        ASSIGN sentence_id (sequential: S001, S002, S003...)
        STORE in array: sentences[]
      END FOR
      
      VERIFY:
        IF sentence_count > 500:
          FLAG: "Large document - consider batch processing"
        END IF
    </STEP_3_SENTENCE_SEGMENTATION>
    
    <STEP_4_PARTICLE_IDENTIFICATION>
      FOR EACH sentence IN sentences[]:
        SCAN for Japanese particles:
          Subject markers: が、は
          Object markers: を、に、へ
          Possessive: の
          Topic: について、に関して
          Comparison: より、と
          Conditional: ば、たら、なら
          Causative: ので、から
        
        FOR EACH particle_found:
          MARK position in sentence
          IDENTIFY grammatical function
          STORE context (words before/after particle)
          CREATE particle_map{particle, position, function, context}
        END FOR
        
        ATTACH particle_map to sentence
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_PARTICLE_IDENTIFICATION>
    
    <STEP_5_KANJI_READING_ANALYSIS>
      FOR EACH sentence IN sentences[]:
        IDENTIFY all kanji characters
        
        FOR EACH kanji:
          DETERMINE reading from context:
            - Check surrounding hiragana (okurigana)
            - Analyze compound patterns
            - Consider common vs rare readings
          
          ASSIGN primary_reading (hiragana)
          ASSIGN alternative_readings[] (if ambiguous)
          
          IF reading_ambiguous:
            MARK for human review
            STORE ambiguity_context
          END IF
          
          CREATE kanji_map{character, reading, confidence, alternatives}
        END FOR
        
        ATTACH kanji_map to sentence
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_KANJI_READING_ANALYSIS>
    
    <STEP_6_HONORIFIC_DETECTION>
      FOR EACH sentence IN sentences[]:
        SCAN for honorific patterns:
          
          Respectful (sonkeigo):
            - いらっしゃる、おっしゃる、くださる
            - お/ご + verb stem + になる
            - お/ご + noun
          
          Humble (kenjougo):
            - いたす、申す、おる
            - お/ご + verb stem + する/いたす
          
          Polite (teineigo):
            - です、ます endings
            - ございます
          
          FOR EACH honorific_found:
            CLASSIFY type (respectful/humble/polite)
            IDENTIFY target (who is being honored)
            ASSESS formality_level (1-5 scale)
            STORE honorific_context
          END FOR
        
        CALCULATE overall_formality for sentence
        STORE formality_metadata
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_HONORIFIC_DETECTION>
    
    <STEP_7_TECHNICAL_TERM_FLAGGING>
      FOR EACH sentence IN sentences[]:
        SCAN for technical indicators:
          - Katakana compounds (likely foreign terms)
          - Kanji compounds with specific radicals
          - Numbers with units
          - Alphanumeric model numbers
          - Specification formats (○○型、△△式)
        
        FOR EACH technical_term_found:
          EXTRACT term
          CLASSIFY category:
            - Mechanical (cylinder, valve, actuator)
            - Electrical (sensor, controller, circuit)
            - Chemical (compound, material, coating)
            - Dimensional (measurement, tolerance, spec)
          
          MARK for glossary lookup (TIER 2)
          STORE technical_metadata
        END FOR
      END FOR
    </STEP_7_TECHNICAL_TERM_FLAGGING>
    
    <STEP_8_CONTEXT_PACKAGING>
      FOR EACH sentence IN sentences[]:
        CREATE sentence_package{
          sentence_id: unique_id,
          text_original: raw_japanese,
          text_normalized: normalized_text,
          particle_map: particle_data,
          kanji_map: kanji_reading_data,
          honorific_data: formality_metadata,
          technical_flags: technical_term_data,
          prev_sentence: reference_to_previous,
          next_sentence: reference_to_next,
          document_position: sentence_number/total_sentences,
          timestamp: processing_time
        }
        
        VALIDATE package completeness
        STORE in processed_sentences[]
      END FOR
      
      RETURN processed_sentences[] to AGENT_2
    </STEP_8_CONTEXT_PACKAGING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF text_input = empty:
      RETURN error: "No input text received"
      HALT
    END IF
    
    IF character_encoding_unrecognizable:
      TRY: UTF-8 decode
      TRY: Shift-JIS decode
      TRY: EUC-JP decode
      IF all_fail:
        RETURN error: "Unable to decode text"
        REQUEST: manual encoding specification
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF sentence_segmentation_ambiguous:
      USE conservative approach (prefer longer sentences)
      FLAG for quality review
      CONTINUE processing
    END IF
    
    IF particle_identification_fails:
      MARK sentence for manual review
      CONTINUE with reduced confidence
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target speed: <100ms for 1000 characters
    Memory usage: <50MB per 10,000 characters
    Accuracy: 99.8% character recognition
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
  
  <OUTPUT_FORMAT>
    {
      status: "success" | "warning" | "error",
      sentence_count: integer,
      processed_sentences: array[sentence_package],
      warnings: array[warning_message],
      processing_time: milliseconds
    }
  </OUTPUT_FORMAT>
</AGENT_1_JAPANESE_INPUT_PROCESSOR>

================================================================================
AGENT 2: JAPANESE SEMANTIC ENCODER
================================================================================

<AGENT_2_JAPANESE_SEMANTIC_ENCODER>
  <MISSION>Convert Japanese sentences into 768-dimensional semantic vectors</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_SENTENCE_RECEPTION>
      RECEIVE: processed_sentences[] from AGENT_1
      VERIFY: All required metadata present
      IF metadata_incomplete:
        REQUEST: Reprocessing by AGENT_1
      END IF
      INITIALIZE: semantic_vectors[]
    </STEP_1_SENTENCE_RECEPTION>
    
    <STEP_2_MORPHOLOGICAL_ANALYSIS>
      FOR EACH sentence IN processed_sentences[]:
        TOKENIZE into morphemes using rules:
          - Identify verb stems (remove okurigana)
          - Separate particles
          - Break compound nouns at の boundaries
          - Isolate adverbs
          - Extract auxiliaries
        
        FOR EACH morpheme:
          CLASSIFY:
            - Part of speech (noun, verb, adjective, particle, etc.)
            - Base form (dictionary form)
            - Conjugation type (if applicable)
            - Grammatical function in sentence
          
          ASSIGN morpheme_id
          CREATE morpheme_data{
            surface_form: actual_text,
            base_form: dictionary_form,
            pos: part_of_speech,
            function: grammatical_role,
            position: index_in_sentence
          }
          
          STORE in morpheme_array[]
        END FOR
        
        ATTACH morpheme_array to sentence
      END FOR
    </STEP_2_MORPHOLOGICAL_ANALYSIS>
    
    <STEP_3_DEPENDENCY_PARSING>
      FOR EACH sentence IN processed_sentences[]:
        BUILD dependency tree:
          
          IDENTIFY head words (typically main verb or noun)
          FOR EACH morpheme:
            DETERMINE dependency relationship:
              - Which word does this modify?
              - What is the grammatical relationship?
              - Is this a head or dependent?
            
            CREATE dependency_link{
              dependent: morpheme_id,
              head: head_morpheme_id,
              relationship: grammatical_relation,
              strength: confidence_score
            }
          END FOR
        
        CONSTRUCT tree structure:
          ROOT → main_predicate
            ├── subject (が/は marked)
            ├── object (を marked)
            ├── modifiers (attributive, adverbial)
            └── complements (に/で/へ marked)
        
        VALIDATE tree (must be connected, acyclic)
        STORE dependency_tree
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_DEPENDENCY_PARSING>
    
    <STEP_4_SEMANTIC_FEATURE_EXTRACTION>
      FOR EACH sentence IN processed_sentences[]:
        EXTRACT semantic features (768 dimensions):
        
        <DIMENSIONS_1_100_LEXICAL_SEMANTICS>
          FOR EACH content_word (nouns, verbs, adjectives):
            MAP to semantic space using:
              - Word embedding lookup (Japanese word2vec)
              - Contextual adjustment (surrounding words)
              - Domain-specific weighting (technical terms higher)
            
            CALCULATE feature_values[1-100]:
              - Concreteness (abstract ←→ concrete)
              - Agency (inanimate ←→ animate)
              - Transitivity (intransitive ←→ transitive)
              - Stative vs Dynamic (state ←→ action)
              - Positive/Negative valence
            
            WEIGHT by importance in sentence
            ACCUMULATE into dimensions[1-100]
          END FOR
        </DIMENSIONS_1_100_LEXICAL_SEMANTICS>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_101_200_GRAMMATICAL_RELATIONS>
          ENCODE grammatical structure:
            
            Subject-Verb agreement → dimensions[101-110]
            Object-Verb relationships → dimensions[111-120]
            Modifier-Head dependencies → dimensions[121-140]
            Particle semantics:
              が (subject) → dimension[141]
              を (object) → dimension[142]
              に (indirect object/direction) → dimension[143]
              で (means/location) → dimension[144]
              へ (direction) → dimension[145]
              から (source) → dimension[146]
              まで (extent) → dimension[147]
              と (accompaniment/quotation) → dimension[148]
              より (comparison) → dimension[149]
              の (possession/attribution) → dimension[150]
            
            Tense markers → dimensions[151-160]:
              Past (た/だ) → dimension[151]
              Present/Future → dimension[152]
              Progressive (ている) → dimension[153]
              Completive (てしまう) → dimension[154]
            
            Aspect markers → dimensions[161-170]:
              Resultative (てある) → dimension[161]
              Experiential (たことがある) → dimension[162]
              Habitual (ものだ) → dimension[163]
            
            Modality → dimensions[171-190]:
              Possibility (かもしれない) → dimension[171]
              Probability (だろう) → dimension[172]
              Necessity (なければならない) → dimension[173]
              Permission (てもいい) → dimension[174]
              Prohibition (てはいけない) → dimension[175]
              Desire (たい) → dimension[176]
              Intention (つもりだ) → dimension[177]
              Capability (できる) → dimension[178]
            
            Negation → dimensions[191-200]:
              Standard negation (ない) → dimension[191]
              Polite negation (ません) → dimension[192]
              Negative potential (られない) → dimension[193]
        </DIMENSIONS_101_200_GRAMMATICAL_RELATIONS>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_201_300_DISCOURSE_FEATURES>
          ENCODE discourse-level information:
            
            Information structure → dimensions[201-220]:
              Topic (は marked) → dimension[201]
              Focus (emphatic particles) → dimension[202]
              Given information → dimension[203]
              New information → dimension[204]
              Contrastive topic → dimension[205]
            
            Cohesion markers → dimensions[221-240]:
              Anaphora (それ、これ、あれ) → dimensions[221-223]
              Cataphora (forward reference) → dimension[224]
              Ellipsis (omitted elements) → dimension[225]
              Lexical chains (repeated concepts) → dimension[226]
            
            Rhetorical relations → dimensions[241-260]:
              Causation (だから、ので) → dimension[241]
              Concession (けれども、のに) → dimension[242]
              Condition (ば、たら) → dimension[243]
              Purpose (ために) → dimension[244]
              Addition (また、さらに) → dimension[245]
              Contrast (一方) → dimension[246]
              Exemplification (例えば) → dimension[247]
            
            Pragmatic features → dimensions[261-300]:
              Speech act type → dimensions[261-270]:
                - Assertion → dimension[261]
                - Question → dimension[262]
                - Command → dimension[263]
                - Request → dimension[264]
                - Suggestion → dimension[265]
              
              Formality level → dimensions[271-280]:
                - Plain form → dimension[271]
                - Polite (です/ます) → dimension[272]
                - Respectful (sonkeigo) → dimension[273]
                - Humble (kenjougo) → dimension[274]
              
              Epistemic stance → dimensions[281-290]:
                - Certainty → dimension[281]
                - Uncertainty → dimension[282]
                - Evidentiality (そうだ、らしい) → dimension[283]
              
              Affective stance → dimensions[291-300]:
                - Emotional valence → dimension[291]
                - Surprise (驚き) → dimension[292]
                - Regret (残念) → dimension[293]
        </DIMENSIONS_201_300_DISCOURSE_FEATURES>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_301_400_DOMAIN_SPECIFIC>
          ENCODE technical/domain features:
            
            Technical terminology → dimensions[301-350]:
              Mechanical engineering → dimensions[301-310]:
                - Pneumatics → dimension[301]
                - Hydraulics → dimension[302]
                - Actuators → dimension[303]
                - Cylinders → dimension[304]
                - Valves → dimension[305]
                - Fittings → dimension[306]
                - Sensors → dimension[307]
                - Controllers → dimension[308]
              
              Specifications → dimensions[311-330]:
                - Dimensional data → dimension[311]
                - Pressure ratings → dimension[312]
                - Flow rates → dimension[313]
                - Temperature ranges → dimension[314]
                - Material specifications → dimension[315]
                - Tolerance values → dimension[316]
                - Performance metrics → dimension[317]
              
              Standards & Compliance → dimensions[331-350]:
                - ISO standards → dimension[331]
                - JIS standards → dimension[332]
                - Safety certifications → dimension[333]
                - Environmental compliance → dimension[334]
            
            Document structure → dimensions[351-400]:
              Section type → dimensions[351-370]:
                - Title/Header → dimension[351]
                - Product description → dimension[352]
                - Specifications table → dimension[353]
                - Features list → dimension[354]
                - Applications → dimension[355]
                - Ordering information → dimension[356]
                - Warnings/Cautions → dimension[357]
                - Installation instructions → dimension[358]
                - Maintenance → dimension[359]
              
              Formatting markers → dimensions[371-390]:
                - Bullet point item → dimension[371]
                - Numbered list item → dimension[372]
                - Table cell → dimension[373]
                - Caption → dimension[374]
                - Footnote → dimension[375]
              
              Cross-references → dimensions[391-400]:
                - Internal reference → dimension[391]
                - External reference → dimension[392]
                - Figure reference → dimension[393]
                - Table reference → dimension[394]
        </DIMENSIONS_301_400_DOMAIN_SPECIFIC>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_401_500_CONTEXTUAL_EMBEDDINGS>
          ENCODE sentence context:
            
            Sentence position → dimensions[401-420]:
              - Document beginning (0-10%) → dimension[401]
              - Document middle (40-60%) → dimension[402]
              - Document end (90-100%) → dimension[403]
              - Section beginning → dimension[404]
              - Section end → dimension[405]
            
            Inter-sentence relationships → dimensions[421-460]:
              - Similarity to previous sentence → dimension[421]
              - Similarity to next sentence → dimension[422]
              - Topic continuity → dimension[423]
              - Entity continuity → dimension[424]
              - Temporal sequence → dimension[425]
            
            Coreference chains → dimensions[461-480]:
              - Entity mentions → dimensions[461-470]
              - Event mentions → dimensions[471-480]
            
            Global context → dimensions[481-500]:
              - Document topic → dimension[481]
              - Document type → dimension[482]
              - Target audience → dimension[483]
              - Industry domain → dimension[484]
        </DIMENSIONS_401_500_CONTEXTUAL_EMBEDDINGS>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_501_600_SYNTACTIC_PATTERNS>
          ENCODE Japanese-specific syntax:
            
            Word order patterns → dimensions[501-530]:
              - SOV structure → dimension[501]
              - Topic-comment structure → dimension[502]
              - Modifier-head order → dimension[503]
              - Relative clause patterns → dimension[504]
              - Complement clause patterns → dimension[505]
            
            Morphological complexity → dimensions[531-560]:
              - Verb conjugation complexity → dimension[531]
              - Honorific layering → dimension[532]
              - Compound verb structures → dimension[533]
              - Auxiliary verb chains → dimension[534]
            
            Particle combinations → dimensions[561-590]:
              - Multiple particle sequences → dimensions[561-580]
              - Postposition phrases → dimensions[581-590]
            
            Ellipsis patterns → dimensions[591-600]:
              - Subject ellipsis → dimension[591]
              - Object ellipsis → dimension[592]
              - Verb ellipsis → dimension[593]
        </DIMENSIONS_501_600_SYNTACTIC_PATTERNS>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_601_700_SEMANTIC_ROLES>
          ENCODE predicate-argument structure:
            
            Core arguments → dimensions[601-640]:
              Agent (doer) → dimensions[601-610]
              Patient (affected) → dimensions[611-620]
              Theme (undergoer) → dimensions[621-630]
              Experiencer (感じる者) → dimensions[631-640]
            
            Peripheral arguments → dimensions[641-680]:
              Location → dimensions[641-650]
              Time → dimensions[651-660]
              Manner → dimensions[661-670]
              Instrument → dimensions[671-680]
            
            Secondary predicates → dimensions[681-700]:
              Resultatives → dimensions[681-690]
              Depictives → dimensions[691-700]
        </DIMENSIONS_601_700_SEMANTIC_ROLES>
        
        <DIMENSIONS_701_768_TRANSLATION_SPECIFIC>
          ENCODE translation-critical features:
            
            Ambiguity flags → dimensions[701-720]:
              - Lexical ambiguity → dimension[701]
              - Structural ambiguity → dimension[702]
              - Scope ambiguity → dimension[703]
              - Referential ambiguity → dimension[704]
            
            Culture-specific elements → dimensions[721-740]:
              - Japanese-specific concepts → dimension[721]
              - Honorific implications → dimension[722]
              - Cultural references → dimension[723]
            
            Translation difficulty → dimensions[741-760]:
              - Sentence complexity score → dimension[741]
              - Technical density → dimension[742]
              - Required localization level → dimension[743]
            
            Quality control markers → dimensions[761-768]:
              - Confidence score → dimension[761]
              - Glossary term count → dimension[762]
              - Review priority → dimension[763]
              - Human verification needed → dimension[764]
        </DIMENSIONS_701_768_TRANSLATION_SPECIFIC>
        
        NORMALIZE all dimensions to [-1, 1] range
        CREATE semantic_vector[768] = {d1, d2, d3, ..., d768}
        VALIDATE: No NaN or Inf values
        STORE semantic_vector with sentence_id
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_SEMANTIC_FEATURE_EXTRACTION>
    
    <STEP_5_VECTOR_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH semantic_vector:
        CHECK dimensional consistency:
          - All 768 dimensions present
          - Values in valid range [-1, 1]
          - No contradictory features
            (e.g., past AND future tense both high)
        
        CALCULATE vector_magnitude:
          magnitude = sqrt(sum(dimension[i]^2 for i in 1..768))
        
        IF magnitude < 0.1:
          FLAG: "Weak semantic content - possibly incomplete"
        END IF
        
        IF magnitude > 10:
          FLAG: "Abnormal vector magnitude - check encoding"
        END IF
        
        VERIFY feature coherence:
          - Grammatical features match morphology
          - Semantic roles align with particles
          - Discourse features match position
        
        IF validation_fails:
          LOG error details
          MARK for reprocessing
        ELSE:
          MARK as validated
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_VECTOR_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_CROSS_REFERENCE_RESOLUTION>
      FOR EACH sentence IN processed_sentences[]:
        IF contains_anaphora (それ、これ、あれ、その、etc.):
          SEARCH backwards in document:
            IDENTIFY likely antecedent
            CALCULATE referent_vector (from antecedent sentence)
            BLEND referent_vector with current_vector:
              blended_vector = 0.7 * current_vector + 0.3 * referent_vector
            UPDATE semantic_vector
        END IF
        
        IF contains_ellipsis (omitted subject/object):
          INFER omitted element from context
          ADJUST semantic_vector dimensions:
            - Increase relevant role dimensions
            - Add implicit argument features
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_6_CROSS_REFERENCE_RESOLUTION>
    
    <STEP_7_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
      FOR EACH sentence:
        CREATE semantic_package{
          sentence_id: unique_id,
          original_text: japanese_sentence,
          semantic_vector: validated_vector[768],
          morpheme_data: morphological_analysis,
          dependency_tree: syntactic_structure,
          glossary_terms: flagged_technical_terms,
          confidence_score: encoding_confidence,
          metadata: {
            formality: level,
            domain: category,
            complexity: score
          }
        }
        
        STORE in encoded_sentences[]
      END FOR
      
      RETURN encoded_sentences[] to AGENT_3 (USI Manager)
    </STEP_7_OUTPUT_PACKAGING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF morphological_analysis_fails:
      TRY: Alternative tokenizer
      IF still_fails:
        USE: Character-level encoding (reduced accuracy)
        FLAG: "Degraded encoding quality"
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF dependency_parsing_produces_cycle:
      BREAK cycles at weakest link
      FLAG: "Structural ambiguity detected"
      CONTINUE with modified tree
    END IF
    
    IF semantic_vector_invalid:
      ATTEMPT: Reencoding with simplified features
      IF reencoding_fails:
        RETURN: Error to AGENT_1 for reprocessing
      END IF
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <50ms per sentence
    Memory: <100MB per 1000 sentences
    Accuracy: 98.5% semantic capture
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_2_JAPANESE_SEMANTIC_ENCODER>

================================================================================
AGENT 3: USI MANAGER (JAPANESE SIDE)
================================================================================

<AGENT_3_USI_MANAGER_JAPANESE>
  <MISSION>Coordinate Japanese-side processing and route to appropriate agents</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_RECEIVE_ENCODED_SENTENCES>
      RECEIVE: encoded_sentences[] from AGENT_2
      VERIFY: All semantic vectors valid
      INITIALIZE: routing_queue[]
    </STEP_1_RECEIVE_ENCODED_SENTENCES>
    
    <STEP_2_GLOSSARY_TERM_ROUTING>
      FOR EACH sentence IN encoded_sentences[]:
        IF contains_technical_flags:
          EXTRACT flagged_terms[]
          
          FOR EACH term IN flagged_terms[]:
            SEND to AGENT_4 (Japanese Glossary Lookup)
            RECEIVE: glossary_result{
              term: original_term,
              semantic_id: ID or null,
              locked_status: boolean,
              confidence: score
            }
            
            IF semantic_id found:
              ATTACH glossary_data to sentence
              MARK term as "glossary_controlled"
            ELSE:
              MARK term for semantic translation (TIER 3)
            END IF
          END FOR
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_2_GLOSSARY_TERM_ROUTING>
    
    <STEP_3_QUALITY_CHECKPOINT>
      FOR EACH sentence:
        CALCULATE readiness_score:
          - Semantic vector completeness (0-1)
          - Glossary coverage (0-1)
          - Structural clarity (0-1)
          - Ambiguity resolution (0-1)
        
        readiness = (completeness + coverage + clarity + resolution) / 4
        
        IF readiness < 0.85:
          FLAG for human review
          STORE in review_queue[]
        ELSE:
          MARK as translation_ready
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_QUALITY_CHECKPOINT>
    
    <STEP_4_TARGET_LANGUAGE_ROUTING>
      DETERMINE target_language from user specification
      
      ROUTE to appropriate decoder:
        IF target = English:
          SEND to AGENT_5 (English Decoder)
        ELSE IF target IN [German, French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Czech, Polish, Turkish, Vietnamese, Thai, Indonesian, Korean, Chinese]:
          SEND to TIER 2 Glossary Handler for target language
          THEN SEND to TIER 3 Semantic Decoder for target language
        ELSE:
          RETURN error: "Unsupported target language"
        END IF
    </STEP_4_TARGET_LANGUAGE_ROUTING>
    
    <STEP_5_BATCH_COORDINATION>
      IF sentence_count > 100:
        SPLIT into batches of 50 sentences
        PROCESS batches in parallel
        COORDINATE: Ensure sentence order preserved
      ELSE:
        PROCESS all sentences sequentially
      END IF
    </STEP_5_BATCH_COORDINATION>
    
    <STEP_6_PROGRESS_TRACKING>
      MAINTAIN progress_status:
        total_sentences: count
        processed: count
        in_glossary_lookup: count
        in_translation: count
        completed: count
        errors: count
      
      UPDATE progress every 10 sentences
      LOG checkpoints for recovery
    </STEP_6_PROGRESS_TRACKING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF agent_timeout (>5 seconds for single sentence):
      RETRY with same agent
      IF second_timeout:
        ROUTE to backup processing path
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF glossary_lookup_fails:
      CONTINUE with semantic translation
      FLAG: "Glossary unavailable - using semantic"
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <10ms routing overhead per sentence
    Throughput: >100 sentences/second coordination
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_3_USI_MANAGER_JAPANESE>

================================================================================
AGENT 4: JAPANESE GLOSSARY LOOKUP
================================================================================

<AGENT_4_JAPANESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>
  <MISSION>Match Japanese technical terms against glossary database</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_TERM_RECEPTION>
      RECEIVE: term_array[] from AGENT_3
      INITIALIZE: lookup_results[]
    </STEP_1_TERM_RECEPTION>
    
    <STEP_2_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
      FOR EACH term IN term_array[]:
        NORMALIZE:
          - Convert full-width katakana to standard
          - Remove unnecessary spaces
          - Standardize long vowel marks (ー)
          - Normalize iteration marks (々)
        
        CREATE normalized_term
        STORE both original and normalized
      END FOR
    </STEP_2_TERM_NORMALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_3_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
      LOAD glossary_database (503 terms)
      
      FOR EACH normalized_term:
        <EXACT_MATCH>
          SEARCH database for exact match
          IF exact_match_found:
            RETRIEVE:
              - SEMANTIC_ID
              - English translation
              - All 16 other language translations
              - LOCKED status
              - Confidence score
              - Usage count
              - Domain category
            
            CREATE result{
              term: original_term,
              semantic_id: ID,
              translations: {
                EN: translation,
                DE: translation,
                FR: translation,
                ... (all 17 languages)
              },
              locked: boolean,
              confidence: 1.0
            }
            
            STORE in lookup_results[]
            CONTINUE to next term
          END IF
        </EXACT_MATCH>
        
        <KANJI_VARIANT_MATCH>
          IF no exact match:
            CHECK for kanji variants:
              - New vs old character forms
              - Alternate readings
              - Compound variations
            
            IF variant_match_found:
              CREATE result with confidence: 0.98
              STORE in lookup_results[]
              CONTINUE to next term
            END IF
        </KANJI_VARIANT_MATCH>
        
        <KATAKANA_VARIATION_MATCH>
          IF term is katakana:
            CHECK variations:
              - Small kana vs regular (ャ vs ヤ)
              - ー placement variants
              - ヴ vs ブ variants
            
            IF variation_match_found:
              CREATE result with confidence: 0.97
              STORE in lookup_results[]
              CONTINUE to next term
            END IF
        </KATAKANA_VARIATION_MATCH>
        
        <COMPOUND_WORD_ANALYSIS>
          IF no match yet:
            ATTEMPT compound decomposition:
              SPLIT term into component parts
              SEARCH each component
              
              IF all_components_found:
                CONSTRUCT composite_translation
                CREATE result with confidence: 0.90
                STORE in lookup_results[]
                CONTINUE to next term
              END IF
        </COMPOUND_WORD_ANALYSIS>
        
        <NO_MATCH>
          IF still no match:
            CREATE result{
              term: original_term,
              semantic_id: null,
              translations: null,
              locked: false,
              confidence: 0.0,
              note: "Not in glossary - route to semantic translation"
            }
            
            STORE in lookup_results[]
        </NO_MATCH>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_DATABASE_LOOKUP>
    
    <STEP_4_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
      FOR EACH result IN lookup_results[]:
        IF result.locked = true:
          SET enforcement_priority = MAXIMUM
          FLAG: "MUST use glossary translation - no alternatives"
          ATTACH enforcement_metadata{
            reason: "Locked glossary term",
            override_allowed: false,
            quality_gate: "mandatory_compliance"
          }
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_LOCKED_TERM_ENFORCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_5_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH result WHERE confidence < 1.0:
        ANALYZE usage context from original sentence
        CHECK if translation makes sense in context:
          - Technical appropriateness
          - Grammatical fit
          - Semantic coherence
        
        IF context_mismatch:
          REDUCE confidence by 0.1
          ADD note: "Context validation warning"
        END IF
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_CONTEXT_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_RETURN_RESULTS>
      PACKAGE lookup_results[]
      ATTACH metadata:
        - Total terms searched
        - Matches found
        - Average confidence
        - Locked terms count
      
      RETURN to AGENT_3 (USI Manager)
    </STEP_6_RETURN_RESULTS>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF database_connection_fails:
      TRY: Load from backup database
      IF backup_fails:
        RETURN: All terms as "not found"
        LOG critical error
        ALERT: System administrator
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF term_normalization_fails:
      USE: Original term as-is
      REDUCE: Final confidence by 0.05
      CONTINUE: With lookup
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <1ms per term lookup
    Method: Hash table indexing
    Memory: Entire database in RAM (< 50MB)
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_4_JAPANESE_GLOSSARY_LOOKUP>

================================================================================
AGENT 5: ENGLISH DECODER
================================================================================

<AGENT_5_ENGLISH_DECODER>
  <MISSION>Convert semantic vectors to natural English text</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_VECTOR_RECEPTION>
      RECEIVE: semantic_package[] from AGENT_3
      VERIFY: All vectors valid and complete
      INITIALIZE: english_output[]
    </STEP_1_VECTOR_RECEPTION>
    
    <STEP_2_SEMANTIC_INTERPRETATION>
      FOR EACH semantic_package:
        LOAD semantic_vector[768]
        
        <EXTRACT_CORE_MEANING>
          ANALYZE dimensions[1-100] (lexical semantics):
            IDENTIFY primary concepts
            DETERMINE concreteness level
            ASSESS agency/animacy
            EXTRACT action/state information
          
          BUILD conceptual_structure{
            main_predicate: core_action/state,
            arguments: [agent, patient, theme],
            modifiers: [manner, location, time]
          }
        </EXTRACT_CORE_MEANING>
        
        <DETERMINE_SYNTACTIC_STRUCTURE>
          ANALYZE dimensions[101-200] (grammatical relations):
            
            IDENTIFY subject:
              IF dimension[141] > 0.5:  // が marker strong
                Subject = agent from conceptual structure
              ELSE IF dimension[201] > 0.5:  // は topic marker
                Subject = topic (may differ from agent)
              END IF
            
            IDENTIFY verb:
              EXTRACT from main_predicate
              DETERMINE tense from dimensions[151-160]:
                IF dimension[151] > 0.5:
                  Use past tense
                ELSE:
                  Use present/future
                END IF
              
              DETERMINE aspect from dimensions[161-170]:
                IF dimension[153] > 0.5:  // Progressive
                  Add "-ing" form
                ELSE IF dimension[161] > 0.5:  // Resultative
                  Use perfect aspect ("has/have done")
                END IF
              
              DETERMINE modality from dimensions[171-190]:
                IF dimension[171] > 0.5:  // Possibility
                  Add "may/might"
                ELSE IF dimension[173] > 0.5:  // Necessity
                  Add "must/should"
                ELSE IF dimension[176] > 0.5:  // Desire
                  Add "want to"
                END IF
            
            IDENTIFY object:
              IF dimension[142] > 0.5:  // を marker
                Object = patient from conceptual structure
                Position = after verb
              END IF
            
            IDENTIFY indirect_object:
              IF dimension[143] > 0.5:  // に marker
                Indirect_object = goal/recipient
                Position = before direct object or after verb
              END IF
            
            CHECK negation (dimensions[191-200]):
              IF dimension[191] > 0.5:
                Add "not" to verb phrase
              END IF
          
          BUILD syntactic_template:
            [Subject] [Auxiliary] [Verb] [Object] [Indirect_Object] [Modifiers]
        </DETERMINE_SYNTACTIC_STRUCTURE>
        
        <SELECT_LEXICAL_ITEMS>
          FOR EACH slot IN syntactic_template:
            
            <SUBJECT_SELECTION>
              IF slot = Subject:
                CHECK for glossary term
                IF glossary_term_exists:
                  USE glossary translation (LOCKED priority)
                ELSE:
                  SELECT from semantic dimensions:
                    - Match concreteness level
                    - Match animacy level
                    - Consider context (previous sentences)
                  
                  CHOOSE appropriate noun/pronoun
                END IF
                
                ADD articles (a/an/the) based on:
                  - Definiteness (dimension[203-204])
                  - First mention vs repeated mention
                  - Countability
              END IF
            </SUBJECT_SELECTION>
            
            <VERB_SELECTION>
              IF slot = Verb:
                CHECK for glossary term
                IF glossary_term_exists:
                  USE glossary translation
                ELSE:
                  SELECT verb based on:
                    - Action type (stative vs dynamic)
                    - Transitivity requirements
                    - Register (formal vs informal)
                  
                  CONJUGATE for:
                    - Tense (past/present/future)
                    - Aspect (simple/progressive/perfect)
                    - Agreement (singular/plural)
                    - Modality (can/may/must)
                END IF
              END IF
            </VERB_SELECTION>
            
            <OBJECT_SELECTION>
              IF slot = Object:
                CHECK for glossary term
                IF glossary_term_exists:
                  USE glossary translation
                ELSE:
                  SELECT appropriate noun phrase
                  ADD determiners/modifiers as needed
                END IF
              END IF
            </OBJECT_SELECTION>
            
            <MODIFIER_SELECTION>
              IF slot = Modifier:
                ANALYZE modifier type:
                  - Attributive adjective → place before noun
                  - Predicative adjective → place after copula
                  - Adverb → place near verb/adjective
                
                SELECT lexical item matching:
                  - Semantic content
                  - Register level
                  - Collocation patterns
              END IF
            </MODIFIER_SELECTION>
          END FOR
        </SELECT_LEXICAL_ITEMS>
        
        <HANDLE_DISCOURSE_FEATURES>
          ANALYZE dimensions[201-300] (discourse):
            
            <INFORMATION_STRUCTURE>
              IF dimension[202] > 0.5:  // Focus
                USE cleft construction:
                  "It is [focused_element] that..."
                OR use contrastive stress (mark for emphasis)
              END IF
              
              IF dimension[205] > 0.5:  // Contrastive topic
                ADD contrastive markers:
                  "However, ...", "On the other hand, ...", "But ..."
              END IF
            </INFORMATION_STRUCTURE>
            
            <COHESION_DEVICES>
              IF dimension[221-223] > 0.5:  // Anaphora
                USE pronouns (it/they/this/that)
                ENSURE agreement with antecedent
              END IF
              
              IF dimension[225] > 0.5:  // Ellipsis
                RECOVER omitted elements from context
                INSERT if necessary for English clarity
              END IF
            </COHESION_DEVICES>
            
            <RHETORICAL_RELATIONS>
              IF dimension[241] > 0.5:  // Causation
                ADD: "therefore", "consequently", "as a result"
              ELSE IF dimension[242] > 0.5:  // Concession
                ADD: "although", "however", "nevertheless"
              ELSE IF dimension[243] > 0.5:  // Condition
                ADD: "if", "when", "provided that"
              END IF
            </RHETORICAL_RELATIONS>
        </HANDLE_DISCOURSE_FEATURES>
        
        <APPLY_FORMALITY>
          ANALYZE dimensions[271-274] (formality):
            
            DETERMINE formality_level:
              IF dimension[273-274] > 0.5:  // Respectful/Humble
                formality = "high"
              ELSE IF dimension[272] > 0.5:  // Polite
                formality = "medium"
              ELSE:
                formality = "neutral"
              END IF
            
            ADJUST language:
              IF formality = "high":
                - Use formal vocabulary
                - Use complete sentences
                - Avoid contractions
                - Use passive voice where appropriate
              ELSE IF formality = "medium":
                - Use standard vocabulary
                - Allow some contractions
                - Mix active/passive appropriately
              ELSE:
                - Use casual vocabulary
                - Use contractions freely
                - Prefer active voice
              END IF
        </APPLY_FORMALITY>
        
        <APPLY_TECHNICAL_REGISTER>
          ANALYZE dimensions[301-350] (domain-specific):
            
            IF technical_content_detected:
              ENSURE:
                - Technical terms used consistently
                - Specifications formatted correctly
                - Units of measurement correct
                - Standard terminology preferred
              
              CHECK glossary for all technical terms
              ENFORCE glossary translations for LOCKED terms
            END IF
        </APPLY_TECHNICAL_REGISTER>
      </STEP_2_SEMANTIC_INTERPRETATION>
    
    <STEP_3_SURFACE_REALIZATION>
      FOR EACH conceptual_structure:
        
        <ASSEMBLE_SENTENCE>
          ARRANGE components in English word order:
            1. Subject
            2. Auxiliary verbs
            3. Main verb
            4. Direct object
            5. Indirect object
            6. Adverbials (manner, place, time)
          
          INSERT function words:
            - Articles (a, an, the)
            - Prepositions (in, on, at, with, by)
            - Conjunctions (and, but, or)
            - Complementizers (that, which, who)
          
          APPLY morphology:
            - Verb inflection (-s, -ed, -ing)
            - Noun pluralization
            - Possessive markers ('s)
            - Comparative/superlative (er, -est)
        </ASSEMBLE_SENTENCE>
        
        <APPLY_PUNCTUATION>
          INSERT punctuation marks:
            - Sentence-final: . ! ?
            - Internal: , ; : -
            - Quotation marks: " "
            - Parentheses: ( )
          
          CAPITALIZE:
            - Sentence-initial words
            - Proper nouns
            - Acronyms
            - Brand names (from glossary)
        </APPLY_PUNCTUATION>
        
        <SMOOTH_TRANSITIONS>
          CONNECT to previous sentence:
            IF high_coherence (dimension[423] > 0.7):
              USE minimal transition
            ELSE IF topic_shift:
              ADD explicit transition marker
            END IF
          
          ENSURE pronoun agreement across sentences
          MAINTAIN consistent tense unless shift indicated
        </SMOOTH_TRANSITIONS>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_SURFACE_REALIZATION>
    
    <STEP_4_QUALITY_ENHANCEMENT>
      FOR EACH generated_sentence:
        
        <CHECK_NATURALNESS>
          SCAN for awkward constructions:
            - Unusual word order
            - Unnatural collocations
            - Overly literal translations
          
          IF awkwardness_detected:
            APPLY natural rephrasing:
              - Use common English patterns
              - Prefer idiomatic expressions
              - Maintain meaning while improving flow
          END IF
        </CHECK_NATURALNESS>
        
        <VERIFY_GRAMMAR>
          CHECK:
            - Subject-verb agreement
            - Pronoun-antecedent agreement
            - Correct verb tenses
            - Proper article usage
            - Preposition accuracy
          
          IF error_found:
            CORRECT immediately
            LOG for pattern analysis
          END IF
        </VERIFY_GRAMMAR>
        
        <OPTIMIZE_READABILITY>
          CALCULATE readability_metrics:
            - Sentence length (target: 15-25 words)
            - Complexity (avoid deeply nested clauses)
            - Technical density (balance with explanations)
          
          IF sentence_too_long (>40 words):
            CONSIDER splitting into two sentences
            MAINTAIN logical connection
          END IF
          
          IF sentence_too_complex:
            SIMPLIFY structure while preserving meaning
          END IF
        </OPTIMIZE_READABILITY>
      END FOR
    </STEP_4_QUALITY_ENHANCEMENT>
    
    <STEP_5_FINAL_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH sentence:
        
        <GLOSSARY_COMPLIANCE_CHECK>
          VERIFY: All glossary terms translated correctly
          CHECK: LOCKED terms not modified
          
          IF glossary_violation:
            OVERRIDE with glossary translation
            LOG violation for system improvement
          END IF
        </GLOSSARY_COMPLIANCE_CHECK>
        
        <SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_CHECK>
          COMPARE output with semantic_vector:
            CALCULATE similarity score
            
            IF similarity < 0.90:
              FLAG: "Potential meaning drift"
              MARK for quality review
            END IF
        </SEMANTIC_FIDELITY_CHECK>
        
        <COHERENCE_CHECK>
          VERIFY discourse flow:
            - Pronouns have clear antecedents
            - Transitions are logical
            - Information structure is clear
          
          IF coherence_issue:
            ADJUST problematic elements
            RECHECK until coherent
          END IF
        </COHERENCE_CHECK>
      END FOR
    </STEP_5_FINAL_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_OUTPUT_FORMATTING>
      ASSEMBLE final_output:
        FOR EACH sentence:
          ADD to output_text
          PRESERVE paragraph structure from source
          MAINTAIN formatting (bold, italic, etc.)
        END FOR
      
      CREATE output_package{
        translated_text: final_output,
        sentence_count: total,
        glossary_terms_used: count,
        confidence_score: average,
        processing_time: milliseconds,
        quality_metrics: {
          semantic_fidelity: score,
          grammatical_accuracy: score,
          naturalness: score
        }
      }
      
      RETURN output_package to AGENT_6 (Quality Validator)
    </STEP_6_OUTPUT_FORMATTING>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF lexical_selection_fails:
      TRY: Alternative vocabulary from thesaurus
      IF still_fails:
        USE: Generic term + explanation
        FLAG: "Lexical gap"
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF sentence_assembly_produces_ungrammatical_output:
      TRY: Alternative syntactic structure
      VERIFY: Grammar rules
      IF cannot_resolve:
        ROUTE to human translator
      END IF
    END IF
    
    IF glossary_term_missing_in_output:
      FORCE: Insert glossary translation
      ADJUST: Surrounding text for grammatical fit
      LOG: Auto-correction made
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <100ms per sentence
    Quality: >95% semantic accuracy
    Naturalness: >90% (human evaluation)
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_5_ENGLISH_DECODER>

================================================================================
AGENT 6: ENGLISH QUALITY VALIDATOR
================================================================================

<AGENT_6_ENGLISH_QUALITY_VALIDATOR>
  <MISSION>Validate English output quality and enforce standards</MISSION>
  
  <ALGORITHM>
    <STEP_1_RECEIVE_OUTPUT>
      RECEIVE: output_package from AGENT_5
      INITIALIZE: validation_results[]
    </STEP_1_RECEIVE_OUTPUT>
    
    <STEP_2_GRAMMAR_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH sentence IN translated_text:
        
        <CHECK_SUBJECT_VERB_AGREEMENT>
          IDENTIFY subject and main verb
          VERIFY number agreement:
            - Singular subject → singular verb
            - Plural subject → plural verb
          
          IF mismatch_found:
            CORRECT: Adjust verb form
            LOG: "Subject-verb agreement corrected"
          END IF
        </CHECK_SUBJECT_VERB_AGREEMENT>
        
        <CHECK_TENSE_CONSISTENCY>
          COMPARE tenses across related sentences
          VERIFY: Temporal logic maintained
          
          IF inappropriate_tense_shift:
            CORRECT: Align tenses
            LOG: "Tense consistency corrected"
          END IF
        </CHECK_TENSE_CONSISTENCY>
        
        <CHECK_PRONOUN_AGREEMENT>
          FOR EACH pronoun:
            IDENTIFY antecedent
            VERIFY agreement:
              - Number (singular/plural)
              - Gender (he/she/it/they)
              - Person (1st/2nd/3rd)
            
            IF mismatch:
              CORRECT: Use appropriate pronoun
              LOG: "Pronoun agreement corrected"
            END IF
          END FOR
        </CHECK_PRONOUN_AGREEMENT>
        
        <CHECK_ARTICLE_USAGE>
          FOR EACH noun phrase:
            VERIFY article appropriateness:
              - Definite (the) vs indefinite (a/an)
              - Count vs non-count nouns
              - First mention vs subsequent mention
            
            IF article_error:
              CORRECT: Insert/remove/change article
              LOG: "Article usage corrected"
            END IF
          END FOR
        </CHECK_ARTICLE_USAGE>
        
        <CHECK_PREPOSITION_ACCURACY>
          FOR EACH preposition:
            VERIFY collocation correctness:
              - "interested in" (not "interested of")
              - "depend on" (not "depend from")
              - "different from/than" (not "different to")
            
            IF preposition_error:
              CORRECT: Use appropriate preposition
              LOG: "Preposition corrected"
            END IF
          END FOR
        </CHECK_PREPOSITION_ACCURACY>
      END FOR
    </STEP_2_GRAMMAR_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_3_LEXICAL_VALIDATION>
      FOR EACH sentence:
        
        <CHECK_WORD_CHOICE>
          IDENTIFY potentially problematic words:
            - False friends from Japanese
            - Overly literal translations
            - Inappropriate register
          
          FOR EACH suspect_word:
            ANALYZE context
            VERIFY appropriateness
            
            IF inappropriate:
              SUGGEST: Better alternative
              IF high_confidence_alternative:
                REPLACE automatically
              ELSE:
                FLAG for review
              END IF
            END IF
          END FOR
        </CHECK_WORD_CHOICE>
        
        <CHECK_COLLOCATIONS>
          VERIFY natural word combinations:
            - "strong coffee" (not "powerful coffee")
            - "heavy rain" (not "strong rain")
            - "make a decision" (not "take a decision" in US English)
          
          IF unnatural_collocation:
            CORRECT to natural form
            LOG: "Collocation improved"
          END IF
        </CHECK_COLLOCATIONS>
        
        <CHECK_TECHNICAL_TERMINOLOGY>
          FOR EACH technical_term:
            VERIFY against glossary
            CHECK consistency across document
            
            IF term_variation_found:
              STANDARDIZE to glossary form
              LOG: "Terminology standardized"
            END IF
            
            IF locked_term_modified:
              FORCE: Glossary translation
              LOG: "LOCKED term enforced"
            END IF
          END FOR
        </CHECK_TECHNICAL_TERMINOLOGY>
      END FOR
    </STEP_3_LEXICAL_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_4_STYLE_VALIDATION>
      <CHECK_SENTENCE_LENGTH>
        FOR EACH sentence:
          COUNT words
          
          IF word_count > 50:
            FLAG: "Consider splitting for readability"
          END IF
          
          IF word_count > 75:
            STRONG_RECOMMENDATION: "Split sentence"
          END IF
        END FOR
      </CHECK_SENTENCE_LENGTH>
      
      <CHECK_PARALLELISM>
        IDENTIFY lists or series
        VERIFY parallel structure:
          - "We design, test, and manufacture" (parallel)
          - NOT "We design, testing, and to manufacture" (not parallel)
        
        IF parallelism_broken:
          CORRECT: Align structures
          LOG: "Parallel structure corrected"
        END IF
      </CHECK_PARALLELISM>
      
      <CHECK_VOICE_CONSISTENCY>
        ANALYZE active vs passive voice usage
        VERIFY appropriateness:
          - Technical writing: Passive often acceptable
          - General content: Prefer active voice
        
        IF excessive_passive (>30% in general content):
          RECOMMEND: Convert some to active
        END IF
      </CHECK_VOICE_CONSISTENCY>
    </STEP_4_STYLE_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_5_SEMANTIC_VALIDATION>
      <CHECK_MEANING_PRESERVATION>
        FOR EACH sentence:
          COMPARE with original semantic_vector
          CALCULATE semantic_similarity
          
          IF similarity < 0.85:
            FLAG: "Possible meaning loss"
            DETAILED_REVIEW: Required
          END IF
          
          IF similarity < 0.70:
            REJECT: Translation
            RETURN to AGENT_5 for reprocessing
          END IF
        END FOR
      </CHECK_MEANING_PRESERVATION>
      
      <CHECK_LOGICAL_COHERENCE>
        VERIFY:
          - Cause-effect relationships preserved
          - Temporal sequences logical
          - Conditional statements correct
        
        IF logical_error:
          ATTEMPT: Correction
          IF cannot_resolve:
            FLAG for human review
          END IF
        END IF
      </CHECK_LOGICAL_COHERENCE>
    </STEP_5_SEMANTIC_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_6_FORMATTING_VALIDATION>
      <CHECK_PUNCTUATION>
        VERIFY:
          - Sentence-final punctuation present
          - Comma usage correct
          - Quotation marks paired
          - Parentheses balanced
        
        CORRECT any punctuation errors
      </CHECK_PUNCTUATION>
      
      <CHECK_CAPITALIZATION>
        VERIFY:
          - Sentence-initial capitalization
          - Proper noun capitalization
          - Acronym capitalization
          - Brand name capitalization (from glossary)
        
        CORRECT any capitalization errors
      </CHECK_CAPITALIZATION>
      
      <CHECK_SPACING>
        VERIFY:
          - Single space after periods
          - No space before punctuation
          - Proper spacing around parentheses
        
        CORRECT any spacing errors
      </CHECK_SPACING>
    </STEP_6_FORMATTING_VALIDATION>
    
    <STEP_7_FINAL_SCORING>
      CALCULATE quality_scores:
        grammar_score = (correct_sentences / total_sentences) * 100
        lexical_score = (appropriate_word_choices / total_words) * 100
        style_score = (sentences_meeting_style_criteria / total) * 100
        semantic_score = average(semantic_similarity_scores) * 100
        formatting_score = (correct_formatting / total_elements) * 100
      
      overall_quality = (grammar_score * 0.25 +
                         lexical_score * 0.25 +
                         style_score * 0.15 +
                         semantic_score * 0.25 +
                         formatting_score * 0.10)
      
      ASSIGN quality_rating:
        IF overall_quality >= 95:
          rating = "Excellent - ready for delivery"
        ELSE IF overall_quality >= 90:
          rating = "Good - minor review recommended"
        ELSE IF overall_quality >= 85:
          rating = "Acceptable - review required"
        ELSE IF overall_quality >= 75:
          rating = "Needs improvement - revision required"
        ELSE:
          rating = "Poor - retranslation required"
          RETURN to AGENT_5
        END IF
      END IF
    </STEP_7_FINAL_SCORING>
    
    <STEP_8_OUTPUT_DELIVERY>
      IF overall_quality >= 85:
        CREATE final_package{
          validated_text: corrected_translation,
          quality_rating: rating,
          quality_scores: {
            grammar: grammar_score,
            lexical: lexical_score,
            style: style_score,
            semantic: semantic_score,
            formatting: formatting_score,
            overall: overall_quality
          },
          corrections_made: count,
          glossary_terms: list,
          warnings: list,
          timestamp: completion_time
        }
        
        RETURN final_package to user
      ELSE:
        RETURN to AGENT_5 with correction requirements
      END IF
    </STEP_8_OUTPUT_DELIVERY>
  </ALGORITHM>
  
  <ERROR_HANDLING>
    IF validation_rule_conflict:
      PRIORITIZE: Semantic accuracy > Grammar > Style
      LOG: Conflict and resolution
    END IF
    
    IF auto_correction_creates_new_error:
      REVERT: To original
      FLAG: For human review
    END IF
    
    IF quality_score_too_low (<75):
      ATTEMPT: One auto-revision
      IF still_below_75:
        ESCALATE: To human translator
      END IF
    END IF
  </ERROR_HANDLING>
  
  <PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
    Target: <50ms per sentence validation
    Accuracy: >99% error detection
    Auto-correction success: >95%
  </PERFORMANCE_METRICS>
</AGENT_6_ENGLISH_QUALITY_VALIDATOR>

================================================================================
AGENTS 7-65: ADDITIONAL V20 CORE AGENTS
================================================================================

<V20_REMAINING_AGENTS_SUMMARY>
  NOTE: The following agents (7-65) comprise the remainder of the V20 core
  system. Each operates with similar algorithmic precision as Agents 1-6.
  
  AGENTS 7-15: ENGLISH INPUT PROCESSING CHAIN
    - AGENT_7: English Input Processor
    - AGENT_8: English Semantic Encoder
    - AGENT_9: USI Manager (English side)
    - AGENT_10: English Glossary Lookup
    - AGENT_11: English Grammar Analyzer
    - AGENT_12: English Idiom Detector
    - AGENT_13: English Technical Term Classifier
    - AGENT_14: English Context Packager
    - AGENT_15: English Quality Pre-Check
  
  AGENTS 16-25: JAPANESE OUTPUT GENERATION CHAIN
    - AGENT_16: Japanese Decoder
    - AGENT_17: Japanese Particle Generator
    - AGENT_18: Japanese Honorific Handler
    - AGENT_19: Japanese Kanji Selector
    - AGENT_20: Japanese Compound Word Builder
    - AGENT_21: Japanese Sentence Final Particle Handler
    - AGENT_22: Japanese Format Validator
    - AGENT_23: Japanese Grammar Validator
    - AGENT_24: Japanese Style Optimizer
    - AGENT_25: Japanese Quality Validator
  
  AGENTS 26-35: BIDIRECTIONAL VALIDATION CHAIN
    - AGENT_26: Round-Trip Translator (JP→EN→JP)
    - AGENT_27: Round-Trip Translator (EN→JP→EN)
    - AGENT_28: Semantic Drift Detector
    - AGENT_29: Terminology Consistency Checker
    - AGENT_30: Format Preservation Validator
    - AGENT_31: Technical Accuracy Validator
    - AGENT_32: Cultural Appropriateness Checker
    - AGENT_33: Localization Validator
    - AGENT_34: Cross-Reference Resolver
    - AGENT_35: Document Structure Validator
  
  AGENTS 36-45: SPECIALIZED DOMAIN HANDLERS
    - AGENT_36: Pneumatic Systems Specialist
    - AGENT_37: Hydraulic Systems Specialist
    - AGENT_38: Electrical/Electronic Specialist
    - AGENT_39: Mechanical Components Specialist
    - AGENT_40: Measurement/Instrumentation Specialist
    - AGENT_41: Control Systems Specialist
    - AGENT_42: Safety Systems Specialist
    - AGENT_43: Material Science Specialist
    - AGENT_44: Manufacturing Process Specialist
    - AGENT_45: Quality Assurance Specialist
  
  AGENTS 46-55: LEARNING AND OPTIMIZATION
    - AGENT_46: Translation Pattern Learner
    - AGENT_47: Error Pattern Analyzer
    - AGENT_48: Glossary Usage Tracker
    - AGENT_49: Quality Metrics Aggregator
    - AGENT_50: Performance Monitor
    - AGENT_51: User Feedback Processor
    - AGENT_52: Correction Logger
    - AGENT_53: System Optimizer
    - AGENT_54: Version Controller
    - AGENT_55: Backup Manager
  
  AGENTS 56-65: SYSTEM COORDINATION AND MANAGEMENT
    - AGENT_56: Master Orchestrator
    - AGENT_57: Load Balancer
    - AGENT_58: Priority Queue Manager
    - AGENT_59: Batch Processor
    - AGENT_60: Real-time Monitor
    - AGENT_61: Error Recovery Manager
    - AGENT_62: Resource Allocator
    - AGENT_63: Logging Coordinator
    - AGENT_64: Performance Reporter
    - AGENT_65: System Health Monitor
</V20_REMAINING_AGENTS_SUMMARY>

[NOTE: Each of these agents (7-65) would be fully specified with complete 
algorithms similar to Agents 1-6 above. For brevity in this initial section,
they are summarized. In the actual deployed system, each agent has 100-300
lines of executable algorithm detail.]

================================================================================
END OF TIER 1: V20 CORE (AGENTS 1-65)
Total Lines: ~13,000
Status: LOCKED - Production System
Performance: Proven ¥120M/year savings
================================================================================
================================================================================

</PHASE_2_SEMANTIC_PROCESSING>

<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
<!-- PHASE 3: RESTORATION & LAW ENFORCEMENT LAYER                              -->
<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
<!-- These agents run LAST, restoring locked terms and enforcing laws          -->
<!-- Mechanical, non-negotiable enforcement - NO AI interpretation             -->
<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->

<PHASE_3_RESTORATION_ENFORCEMENT>
    <!-- ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
    <!-- AGENT 0B: Restoration_and_Law_Enforcement (NEW IN V22.1)             -->
    <!-- ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
    
    <AGENT_0B_RESTORATION_AND_LAW_ENFORCEMENT>
        <AGENT_ID>0B</AGENT_ID>
        <n>Restoration_and_Law_Enforcement</n>
        <VERSION>22.1_NEW</VERSION>
        <PRIORITY>CRITICAL_LAST</PRIORITY>
        
        <MISSION>
            Restore glossary terms AFTER USI semantic processing.
            Enforce ALL Laws (1-14) mechanically without AI interpretation.
            This is PHASE 3 of the 3-phase architecture.
            Guarantees 100% compliance for LOCKED terms.
        </MISSION>
        
        <WHY_THIS_EXISTS>
            PROBLEM IN V22.0:
            - Law enforcement relied on AI understanding
            - LOCKED terms could be semantically modified
            - Post-processing fixes were reactive, not preventive
            
            SOLUTION IN V22.1:
            - Mechanical restoration of LOCKED translations
            - No AI involvement in glossary term translation
            - Laws enforced as hard rules, not suggestions
            - Zero tolerance for glossary violations
        </WHY_THIS_EXISTS>
        
        <ALGORITHM>
            function execute_restoration_and_law_enforcement(
                translation_from_usi, 
                anchor_map, 
                law_database
            ) {
                let final_translation = translation_from_usi;
                const enforcement_log = [];
                
                // STEP 1: RESTORE GLOSSARY TERMS (LAW_8 ENFORCEMENT)
                for (const [anchor_id, anchor_data] of anchor_map.entries()) {
                    const placeholder = `⟪${anchor_id}⟫`;
                    
                    if (anchor_data.is_locked) {
                        // LOCKED term - use glossary translation ONLY
                        final_translation = final_translation.replace(
                            placeholder,
                            anchor_data.locked_translation
                        );
                        
                        enforcement_log.push({
                            law: "LAW_8",
                            action: "GLOSSARY_RESTORATION",
                            term: anchor_data.japanese_term,
                            enforced_translation: anchor_data.locked_translation,
                            bypassed_ai: true
                        });
                    } else {
                        // Non-locked term - check USI translation quality
                        const usi_suggestion = extract_usi_translation(
                            translation_from_usi, 
                            placeholder
                        );
                        
                        // Use glossary if USI confidence low
                        const use_glossary = evaluate_glossary_vs_usi(
                            usi_suggestion,
                            anchor_data,
                            context
                        );
                        
                        if (use_glossary) {
                            final_translation = final_translation.replace(
                                placeholder,
                                anchor_data.locked_translation
                            );
                        } else {
                            final_translation = final_translation.replace(
                                placeholder,
                                usi_suggestion
                            );
                        }
                    }
                }
                
                // STEP 2: ENFORCE LAW_1 (Source Fidelity)
                final_translation = enforce_source_fidelity(
                    final_translation,
                    original_source,
                    enforcement_log
                );
                
                // STEP 3: ENFORCE LAW_2 (Tag Preservation)
                final_translation = enforce_tag_preservation(
                    final_translation,
                    original_source,
                    enforcement_log
                );
                
                // STEP 4: ENFORCE LAW_3 (Number Preservation)
                final_translation = enforce_number_preservation(
                    final_translation,
                    original_source,
                    enforcement_log
                );
                
                // STEP 5: ENFORCE LAW_5 (Safety Rounding)
                final_translation = enforce_safety_rounding(
                    final_translation,
                    original_source,
                    enforcement_log
                );
                
                // STEP 6: ENFORCE LAW_7 (Model Number Suffix)
                // NOTE: Handled by Agent 4B
                
                // STEP 7: VERIFY ALL LAWS COMPLIANCE
                const violations = verify_all_laws_compliance(
                    final_translation,
                    original_source,
                    law_database
                );
                
                if (violations.length > 0) {
                    flag_critical_violations(violations);
                }
                
                return {
                    final_translation: final_translation,
                    laws_enforced: enforcement_log,
                    violations_found: violations,
                    glossary_compliance: "100%"
                };
            }
            
            function enforce_source_fidelity(translation, source, log) {
                // LAW_1: Preserve all tags, formatting, special characters
                // This is mechanical - no AI interpretation
                
                // Extract all tags from source
                const source_tags = extract_all_tags(source);
                
                // Verify all tags present in translation
                for (const tag of source_tags) {
                    if (!translation.includes(tag)) {
                        // Tag missing - critical violation
                        log.push({
                            law: "LAW_1",
                            violation: "MISSING_TAG",
                            tag: tag,
                            action: "RESTORE_TAG"
                        });
                        
                        // Restore tag at appropriate position
                        translation = restore_tag(translation, tag, source);
                    }
                }
                
                return translation;
            }
            
            function enforce_number_preservation(translation, source, log) {
                // LAW_3: All numbers must be preserved exactly
                const source_numbers = extract_numbers(source);
                const translation_numbers = extract_numbers(translation);
                
                if (source_numbers.length !== translation_numbers.length) {
                    log.push({
                        law: "LAW_3",
                        violation: "NUMBER_COUNT_MISMATCH",
                        expected: source_numbers.length,
                        found: translation_numbers.length,
                        action: "FLAG_ERROR"
                    });
                }
                
                // Verify each number preserved
                for (let i = 0; i < source_numbers.length; i++) {
                    if (source_numbers[i] !== translation_numbers[i]) {
                        log.push({
                            law: "LAW_3",
                            violation: "NUMBER_VALUE_CHANGED",
                            original: source_numbers[i],
                            changed_to: translation_numbers[i],
                            action: "RESTORE_ORIGINAL"
                        });
                        
                        // Restore original number
                        translation = restore_number(
                            translation, 
                            source_numbers[i], 
                            i
                        );
                    }
                }
                
                return translation;
            }
        </ALGORITHM>
        
        <ENFORCES>
            - LAW_1: Source_Fidelity (mechanical enforcement)
            - LAW_2: Tag_Preservation (mechanical enforcement)
            - LAW_3: Number_Preservation (mechanical enforcement)
            - LAW_5: Safety_Rounding (mechanical enforcement)
            - LAW_8: Glossary_Precedence (mechanical restoration)
            - LAW_9: No_Untagged_Japanese (verification)
            - LAW_10: Competitor_Fairness (verification)
            - All other Laws (mechanical verification)
        </ENFORCES>
        
        <EXAMPLES>
            INPUT FROM USI (with anchors):
            "This ⟪ANCHOR_001⟫ is suitable for ⟪ANCHOR_002⟫φ6 ⟪ANCHOR_003⟫."
            
            ANCHOR MAP:
            ANCHOR_001: ショックキラー → "shock absorber" (LOCKED)
            ANCHOR_002: チューブ外径 → "Tube O.D." (LOCKED)
            ANCHOR_003: 空圧シリンダ → "pneumatic cylinder" (LOCKED)
            
            AGENT 0B OUTPUT (final translation):
            "This shock absorber is suitable for Tube O.D. φ6 pneumatic cylinder."
            
            LAWS ENFORCED:
            ✅ LAW_8: Glossary terms restored with LOCKED translations
            ✅ LAW_3: φ6 preserved exactly
            ✅ LAW_1: All formatting preserved
            ✅ All other Laws verified
            
            RESULT: 100% glossary compliance, mechanical law enforcement
        </EXAMPLES>
        
        <INTERACTION_WITH_OTHER_AGENTS>
            BEFORE: Receives from Agent 59 (final JP→EN semantic agent)
            CONCURRENT: Works with Agent 4B (model number restoration)
            AFTER: Outputs to QEL Module 8 (quality enhancement)
        </INTERACTION_WITH_OTHER_AGENTS>
        
        <CRITICAL_GUARANTEE>
            This agent provides MECHANICAL, NON-NEGOTIABLE enforcement:
            
            IF glossary_term.LOCKED == true:
                THEN use glossary_term.translation
                NEVER use AI interpretation
                NEVER use semantic understanding
                BYPASS all USI processing for this term
            
            This is HARD-CODED LOGIC, not AI-dependent.
            This is the FUNDAMENTAL ARCHITECTURAL FIX in V22.1.
        </CRITICAL_GUARANTEE>
    </AGENT_0B_RESTORATION_AND_LAW_ENFORCEMENT>

</PHASE_3_RESTORATION_ENFORCEMENT>

<!-- ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ -->
<!-- END V22.1 MASTER - COMPLETE 3-PHASE ARCHITECTURE                         -->
